Description: PROJECT TITLE: PROBABILISTIC FAULT DISPLACEMENT HAZARD MAPPING OF MONTANA: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH CAL POLYAND MONTANA TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY.PROJECT PERIOD: 9 1 2023 THROUGH 8 31 2024                    PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION AWARD PURPOSE:  THIS RESEARCH SEEKS TO DEVELOP A PILOT STUDY FOR COMMUNICATING SURFACE FAULT DISPLACEMENT HAZARD IN MONTANA. THE PILOT STUDY WILL FOCUS ON A SUB-REGION OF WESTERN MONTANA, WITHIN THE BITTERROOT VALLEY. THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT CURRENT AND NEW SEISMIC SOURCE DATA ON QUATERNARY FAULTS, SPECIFICALLY THE BITTERROOT FAULT. THIS DATA WILL THEN BE USED IN A PROBABILISTIC FAULT DISPLACEMENT HAZARDS ANALYSIS (PFDHA) FRAMEWORK TO DEVELOP PRINCIPAL AND DISTRIBUTED DEFORMATION ESTIMATES (E.G., 2  IN 50YR RETURN) AT FIXED HAZARD LEVELS THAT CAN THEN BE USED TO GENERATE CONTOUR HAZARD MAPS OF SURFACE FAULT DISPLACEMENT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TO CONSTRAIN THE SEISMIC SOURCE ALONG THE BITTERROOT FAULT, THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT NEW SLIP RATE DATA CARRIED OUT BY MONTANA BUREAU OF MINES AND GEOLOGY (MBMG) AT MONTANA TECH. THE RECIPIENT HAS IDENTIFIED FOUR PRIORITY SLIP RATE SITES, WHICH INCLUDE 2 SITES NEAR LAKE COMO DAM FOR THE SOUTHERN BITTERROOT FAULT SECTION, AND 2 SITES NEAR VICTOR FOR THE NORTHERN BITTERROOT FAULT SECTION. WE PLAN TO UNDERTAKE A SERIES OF HIGH-RESOLUTION TOPOGRAPHIC PROFILES USING AVAILABLE LIDAR, AND DETAILED GEOMORPHIC MAPPING OF OFFSET QUATERNARY DEPOSITS TO MEASURE DEFORMATION RATES AT THE SUB-METER SCALE. COMBINING FAULT STRUCTURAL MODELS, BEDROCK-QUATERNARY STRATAL RELATIONS, AND CROSS SECTIONS WILL ALSO PROVIDE CONSTRAINTS ON THE UNDERLYING FAULT GEOMETRY. COSMOGENIC RADIONUCLIDES (CRN) EXPOSURE DATING USING 10BE WILL PROVIDE THE DATING STRATEGY TO CONSTRAIN THE AGE OF OFFSET GEOMORPHIC SURFACES AT OUR SLIP RATE SITES. THESE DATASETS WILL PRODUCE BOTH SHORT-TERM AND LONG-TERM SLIP RATE ESTIMATES AND BUILD ON THE EXISTING DATASET ALONG THE BITTERROOT FAULT (GAVILLOT ET AL., 2021  2023).HAZARD MODELING OF THE SURFACE FAULT RUPTURE WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED USING PFDHA MODELS CARRIED OUT BY CAL POLY. THE METHODOLOGY FOLLOWS THAT OF PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSIS (PSHA) AND INTEGRATES OVER THE SEISMIC SOURCE FOR ALL POSSIBLE EVENTS THAT LEAD TO THE EXCEEDANCE OF A DISPLACEMENT THRESHOLD. THESE SEMI-EMPIRICAL MODEL RESULTS USE THE STATISTICS FROM PRIOR EVENTS TO INFORM THE FORECASTING OF FUTURE EVENTS. FROM THE PFDHA, THE RECIPIENT WILL GENERATE HAZARD CONTOUR MAPS MODELLED AS A GRID SURROUNDING THE FAULT, SIMILAR TO AN EXAMPLE SHOWN IN PETERSEN ET AL. (2011).DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED AND PRESENTED BY BOTH MBMG AND CAL POLY RESEARCH TEAMS TO LOCAL STAKE HOLDERS IN MONTANA AND START DIALOGS ABOUT THE UTILITY OF FAULT DISPLACEMENT HAZARD MAPS. WE PLAN TO USE FUTURE RECURRENT MEETING LIKE THE MONTANA GEOHAZARD WORKSHOPS (HTTPS:  WWW.MBMG.MTECH.EDU MONTANAGEOLOGY GEOHAZARDS MONTANAGEOHAZARDWORKSHOP.ASP  GSC.TAB 0) LED BY MBMG TO DISCUSS THE UTILITY AND SOLICIT USER NEEDS APPLICATION OF THESE HAZARDS  MAPS FOR LOCAL AND REGIONAL PLANNING EFFORTS IN MONTANA. DELIVERABLES WILL CONSIST OF SEVERAL PUBLICATIONS THAT INCLUDE A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT, MBMG REPORT INVESTIGATION, MBMG DATA RELEASE, AND OUTSIDE JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS (BULLETIN OF THE SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OR EARTHQUAKE SPECTRA). RESULTS WILL PRESENT AT RELEVANT SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS, INCLUDING THE AMERICAN GEOPHYSICAL UNION, SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA, AND THE GEOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: AT THE MONTANA BUREAU OF MINES AND GEOLOGY (MBMG), MONTANA TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY, FUNDING FROM THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SUPPORT THE FIELDWORK FOR FAULT MAPPING AND AGE DATING ANALYSES. AT CAL POLY (SEPARATE AWARD), FUNDING IS TO SUPPORT THE ANALYSES FOR PFDHA MODELING AND HAZARDS CONTOUR MAPS.

PROJECT TITLE: SEISMIC PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT OF SLOPE SYSTEMS CONSIDERING NON-ERGODIC GROUND MOTION ESTIMATESAND NON-ERGODIC FRAGILITIESPROJECT PERIOD: 9 1 2023 THROUGH 8 31 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION:  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: IN THE FIRST STAGE, THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT ERGODIC AND NON-ERGODIC SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS FOR SELECTED AREAS (EXPECTED TO BE LOCATED IN CALIFORNIA). THE SECOND STAGE WILL USE THE FIRST STAGE RESULTS TO CONDUCT THE SEISMIC PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENTS OF SELECTED SLOPE SYSTEMS CONSIDERING THE ERGODIC-AND NON-ERGODIC-BASED QUANTIFICATION OF THE SEISMIC DEMAND. THEN, A STEP FURTHER (I.E., THE THIRD STAGE) WILL BE CONSIDERED, WHERE THE RESULTS FROM THE SECOND STAGE ARE COMBINED WITH NON-ERGODIC FRAGILITIES (REPRESENTED THROUGH DIFFERENT SLOPE GEOMETRIES), AND THE SEISMIC PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENTS WILL BE REPEATED. THE RESULTS FROM THE THREE STAGES AND THE INSIGHTS OF NON-ERGODIC CONSIDERATIONS ON THE SEISMIC ASSESSMENTS WILL BE DOCUMENTED. FINALLY, IMPLEMENTATION PROTOCOLS FOR NON-ERGODIC ASSESMENTS OF SLOPE SYSTEMS WILL BE PROVIDED AND USED FORDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE IMPACT OF NON-ERGODIC SEISMIC HAZARD AND NON-ERGODIC FRAGILITIES ON THE SEISMIC RISK ASSESSMENT OF SLOPE SYSTEMS WOULD BE REGION AND DATA DEPENDENT.  PROTOCOLS FOR THE IMPLEMENTATIONS OF NON-ERGODIC BASED SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS AND RISK ASSESSMENTS OF SLOPE SYSTEMS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NIA

PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSING THE CAPABILITIES OF OCEAN-BOTTOM DAS FOR EARTHQUAKE MONITORING IN OREGONPROJECT PERIOD: 9 1 2023 THROUGH 8 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE: UNDER THIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT WILL TEST THE RECORDING CAPABILITIES OF OCEAN BOTTOM DISTRIBUTED ACOUSTIC SENSING (OBDAS) FOR ITS POTENTIAL IMPLEMENTATION INTO THE EXISTING EEW SYSTEMS. DAS IS A TECHNOLOGY THAT ALLOWS TO REPURPOSE FIBER-OPTIC CABLES INTO ULTRA-DENSE ARRAYS OF SENSORS MEASURING CONTINUOUS VIBRATIONS OVER SEVERAL TENS OF KILOMETERS. OBDAS USING EXISTING TELECOM INFRASTRUCTURES ON THE US WEST COAST COULD BE A GAME-CHANGER FOR EEW AS IT WOULD ALLOW SEISMOLOGISTS TO MONITOR EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTION CLOSER TO THE SOURCE AND IN REAL TIME. YET, EACH CABLE HAS ITS OWN SET OF CHARACTERISTICS THAT NEED TO BE QUANTIFIED PRIOR TO DEPLOYING IT USED FOR ROUTINE MONITORING. STUDYING THE RESPONSE OF OBDAS CABLE IS ONE OF THE MAIN PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL CHARACTERIZE THE RESPONSE OF OBDAS USING A FIBER OFFSHORE FLORENCE, OR. WE GATHERED FOUR MONTHS OF OBDAS DATA BY REPURPOSING THE FIRST 55 KM OF THE FIBER INTO AN ARRAY OF 2600 SEISMIC SENSORS, SPACED BY 20 M. USING THIS DATASET, WE WILL GENERATE AN EARTHQUAKES DATABASE THAT WILL HELP TO QUANTIFY THE RESPONSE OF THE CABLE TO EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTION AND IMPROVE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF OBDAS FOR EARTHQUAKE MONITORING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DATABASE WILL BE MADE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC AND WE WILL PROVIDE CODES AND TOOLS PRACTICALLY APPLICABLE TO OBDAS RESEARCHERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: RESEARCHERS INTERESTED IN QUANTIFYING HOW DAS CAN BE USED FOR BETTER MONITORING OF THE CASCADIA SUBDUCTION ZONE. THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THESE ACTIVITIES, AS THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARD IMPROVING EEW SYSTEMS IN THE US.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NIA

PROJECT TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF FAULTS THROUGH SAND AND THE SLIP HISTORY OF THE SAN GREGORIO FAULTPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE- THIS INVESTIGATION WILL CHARACTERIZE AND DATE SANDS THAT HAVE MOVED FROM NOTABLE EARTHQUAKES ON THE SAN GREGORIO FAULT ZONE (SGFZ) AT PILLAR POINT BLUFF (A MARINE TERRACE) IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA SINCE  SO KA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - A COMPREHENSIVE STRATIGRAPHIC AND GEOCHRONOLOGIC STUDY OF DISPLACED MARINE TERRACE SANDS FROM THE SUBSURFACE WILL BE COMPLETED AND CORRELATED WITH OBSERVATIONS OF MAPPED SURFACE FAULTS ON THE SAN GREGORIO FAULT AT PILLAR POINT BLUFF. THIS STUDY WILL MAP, ANALYZE AND DATE DEFORMATION WITHIN THE PROCESS ZONE AND THE ZONE OF PLASTIC STRAIN AROUND THE TIP OF A PROPAGATING FAULT, BY OBSERVING FAULT ARCHITECTURE AND CHARACTERIZING MICROSTRUCTURES IN AND AROUND AN EXPOSURE FAULT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY AIMS TO WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE INSIGHT INTO HOW THE SAN GREGORIO FAULT AT PILLAR POINT BLUFF (AN NEAR SURFACE FAULTS IN GENERAL) MAY GEOMETRICALLY EVOLVE AS IT PROPAGATES UPWARDS FROM BEDROCK INTO PROGRESSIVELY LESS LITHIFIED SEDIMENT, INCLUDING DURING SURFACE-RUPTURING EARTHQUAKES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - EARTHQUAKE SCIENCE COMMUNITY AND UCERF MODELSSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD - N A

PROJECT TITLE: BASIN EFFECTS MODEL USING MULTI-SCALE GEOSPATIAL DATA: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH TUFTSUNIVERSITY AND MERRIMACK COLLEGEPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO IMPROVE BASIN TERMS IN GROUND MOTION MODELS USING GEOSPATIAL, GEOLOGICAL, GEOMORPHIC, AND GEOTECHNICAL DATA TO CHARACTERIZE SEDIMENTARY BASINS IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: GROUND MOTION DATA RECORDED IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES SINCE 2011 WILL BE COMPILED AND PROCESSED TO ENHANCE THE EXISTING NGA-EAST (NEXT GENERATION ATTENUATION RELATIONSHIPS FOR CENTRAL   EASTERN NORTH-AMERICA PROJECT) GROUND MOTION FLATFILE. GEOLOGIC, TOPOGRAPHIC, GEOMORPHIC, AND GEOTECHNICAL DATA TO CHARACTERIZE SEDIMENTARY BASINS AND SITES WILL BE COMPILED IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES. USING MIXED-EFFECTS REGRESSION, WE WILL DETERMINE WHICH BASIN CHARACTERISTICS BEST REDUCE UNCERTAINTY IN EXISTING NGA-EAST GROUND MOTION MODELS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AN EXPANDED GROUND MOTION NGA-EAST FLATFILE WITH ENHANCED BASIN TERMS AND ADDITIONAL SITE METADATA WILL BE PRODUCED AS PART OF THE PROJECT. REGRESSION MODELS WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR ADJUSTMENT FACTORS FOR SITE EFFECTS IN DIFFERENT BASINS AND GEOLOGY GROUPS. A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT, AN ABSTRACT AND PRESENTATION AT THE 2024 SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA (SSA) ANNUAL MEETING, AND A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL PAPER WILL BE PRODUCED TO SUMMARIZE THE WORK AND PRESENT THE RESULTS OF THE BASIN TERM EVALUATION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: IMPROVED BASIN TERMS IN GROUND MOTION MODELS WILL REDUCE THE GROUND MOTION UNCERTAINTY IN PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSES, AND ULTIMATELY BENEFIT ALL THOSE WHO USE REGIONAL AND LOCAL SEISMIC HAZARD PRODUCTS INCLUDING ENGINEERS, PLANNERS, AND LOSS ESTIMATORS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NIA

GEOLOGIC, TOPOGRAPHIC, GEOMORPHIC, AND GEOTECHNICAL DATA TO CHARACTERIZE SEDIMENTARY BASINS AND SITES WILL BE COMPILED IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES. REGRESSION MODELS WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR ADJUSTMENT FACTORS FOR SITE EFFECTS IN DIFFERENT BASINS AND GEOLOGY GROUPS. A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT, AN ABSTRACT AND PRESENTATION AT THE 2024 SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA (SSA) ANNUAL MEETING, AND A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL PAPER WILL BE PRODUCED TO SUMMARIZE THE WORK AND PRESENT THE RESULTS OF THE BASIN TERM EVALUATION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: IMPROVED BASIN TERMS IN GROUND MOTION MODELS WILL REDUCE THE GROUND MOTION UNCERTAINTY IN PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSES, AND ULTIMATELY BENEFIT ALL THOSE WHO USE REGIONAL AND LOCAL SEISMIC HAZARD PRODUCTS INCLUDING ENGINEERS, PLANNERS, AND LOSS ESTIMATORS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NIA

PROJECT TITLE: SPATIAL CORRELATION OF GROUND MOTION INTENSITY MEASURES IN CALIFORNIA USING AN ENHANCED DATASETPROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 2023 THROUGH 6 30 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO INVESTIGATE THE VARIABILITY IN EARTHQUAKE SHAKING INTENSITY AS A FUNCTION OF SEPARATION DISTANCE. EARTHQUAKE GROUND SHAKING INTENSITY VARIES SPATIALLY DUE TO COMPLEXITIES IN THE STRUCTURE OF THE EARTH S CRUST. SOME PORTIONS OF A FAULT MAY SLIP MORE THAN OTHERS, THEREBY RELEASING MORE ENERGY AND CAUSING  HOTSPOTS  OF LOCALLY INTENSE SHAKING. FURTHERMORE, DEPENDING ON HOW SOFT THE SOIL OR ROCK IS AT A SITE, SHAKING INTENSITY MIGHT BE AMPLIFIED OR DE-AMPLIFIED. SPATIAL VARIATIONS IN SHAKING INTENSITY INFLUENCE PATTERNS OF EARTHQUAKE-INDUCE INFRASTRUCTURE DAMAGE. GROUND MOTION RECORDING STATIONS HAVE GENERALLY BEEN SPACED TOO FAR APART (I.E., KILOMETERS MILES) TO ENABLE CALCULATION OF THE SPATIAL VARIABILITY OF EARTHQUAKE GROUND SHAKING INTENSITY ON A LOCAL SCALE. THE RECENTLY ESTABLISHED COMMUNITY SEISMIC NETWORK (CSN) IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA HAS DENSE COVERAGE, WITH SENSORS SPACED ONLY ABOUT 600 METERS (ABOUT 2000 FEET) ON AVERAGE. IT HAS NOW RECORDED AN ADEQUATE NUMBER OF EARTHQUAKES TO FACILITATE A DETAILED STUDY OF SPATIAL VARIABILITY OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING INTENSITY. WE PLAN TO UTILIZE DATA FROM THE CSN TO DEVELOP SPATIAL CORRELATION MODELS FOR SHAKING INTENSITY, WHICH WILL ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT DAMAGE DURING FUTURE EARTHQUAKES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT COORDINATE WITH THE CSN TO OBTAIN UNPROCESSED EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTION. THESE RECORDS WILL BE PROCESSED USING THE USGS TOOL GM PROCESS (HEARNE ET AL. 2020), AND THEY WILL BE REVIEWED BY THE TEAM FOR QUALITY ASSURANCE. INTENSITY MEASURES, PSEUDO-ACCELERATION RESPONSE SPECTRA, AND FOURIER SPECTRA WILL THEN BE COMPUTED FROM THE PROCESSED RECORDS AND INSERTED INTO THE UCLA GROUND MOTION DATABASE (HTTPS:  WWW.UCLAGEO.COM GM DATABASE API) WHERE THEY WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE THROUGH AN APPLICATION PROGRAMMING INTERFACE (API). THE RECIPIENT WILL COMPUTE WITHIN-EVENT RESIDUALS, DEFINED AS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A MEASUREMENT AND A MODEL PREDICTION, FOR EACH RECORDING STATION FOR EACH EARTHQUAKE. THE RECIPIENT WILL THEN USE GEOSTATISTICAL METHODS INVOLVING VARIOGRAM ANALYSIS TO STUDY SPATIAL CORRELATION OF THE WITHIN-EVENT RESIDUALS, AND WE WILL DEVELOP VARIOGRAM MODELS TO QUANTIFY THE SPATIAL VARIABILITY. THESE VARIOGRAM MODELS WILL BE DIRECTLY USEFUL WHEN EVALUATING THE HOLISTIC DAMAGE PATTERNS TO AN ENSEMBLE OF BUILDINGS (I.E., WITHIN A CITY), OR FOR SPATIALLY DISTRIBUTED INFRASTRUCTURE SYSTEMS LIKE LEVEES, GAS PIPELINES, AND ELECTRICAL TRANSMISSION DISTRIBUTION LINES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DELIVERABLES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A PUBLISHED DATASET CONTAINING ALL OF THE PROCESSED EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTION RECORDS, WHICH WILL ALSO BE AVAILABLE THROUGH OUR API. THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO DELIVER A VARIOGRAM MODEL QUANTIFYING SPATIAL VARIABILITY OF WITHIN EVENT RESIDUALS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES OF THE WORK WILL BE EARTHQUAKE HAZARD ANALYSTS, WHO WILL BE BETTER POSITIONED TO UNDERSTAND HOW EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTIONS VARY OVER SHORT DISTANCES. THEY WILL BE ABLE TO UTILIZE MODELS DEVELOPED FROM OUR WORK TO PRODUCE MORE ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF EARTHQUAKE DAMAGE TO OUR INFRASTRUCTURE SYSTEMS.SUBRECIPIENTS: N A

PROJECT TITLE: CHARACTERIZING BASEMENT-INVOLVED GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES IN A SUBREGION OF THE CENTRAL AND EASTERNUNITED STATES, AND ASSESSING THEIR SPATIAL RELATIONSHIP TO SEISMICITYPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE PROJECT AIMS TO FOCUS ON IDENTIFYING, MAPPING, AND CHARACTERIZING BASEMENT-INVOLVED GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES PRESENT IN A SUBREGION OF THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES THAT INCLUDES MISSOURI, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, AND KENTUCKY (STUDY AREA), WHERE THERE ARE SEDIMENTARY BASINS AND CRATONIC PLATFORMS. THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TWO-FOLD. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE WILL BE TO USE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE GEOPHYSICAL DATA (NEW AND OLD), SUCH AS BOREHOLE DATA, TWO-DIMENSIONAL THREE-DIMENSIONAL SEISMIC REFLECTION DATA, GRAVITY DATA, MAGNETIC DATA, ETC., AROUND THE STUDY AREA TO MORE FULLY CHARACTERIZE BASEMENT-INVOLVED GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES THAT ARE PRESENT WITHIN THIS AREA. THE SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO UPDATE AN EXISTING SOFTWARE (ARCGIS) DATABASE, THAT CONTAINS SHAPE AND LAYER FILES WITH BASEMENT FAULT LINES, BY ADDING NEW FAULTS THAT DEPICTS THE GEOMETRY OF PREVIOUSLY UNIDENTIFIED FOLDS AND FAULTS WITHIN THE STUDY AREA TO THE ARCGIS DATABASE FILES. THE SLIP POTENTIAL OF THE FAULTS IN THE DATABASE WILL BE PROBABILISTICALLY SCREENED USING A FREELY DOWNLOADABLE TOOL, FAULT SLIP POTENTIAL (FSP), FROM THE STANFORD CENTER FOR INDUCED AND TRIGGERED SEISMICITY. THE UPDATE TO THE ARCGIS FILES WILL IMPROVE THE COMPLETENESS OF BASEMENT-INVOLVED GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES IN THE DATABASE THAT CAN BE USED AS EARTHQUAKE GEOLOGY INPUTS FOR THE U.S. NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL (NSHM). BECAUSE DATA FROM RECENT AND ACTIVE CO2 INJECTION ACTIVITIES WILL BE INCLUDED IN THIS STUDY, THIS PROJECT WILL BE A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE CHARACTERIZATION OF FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO INDUCED SEISMICITY IN SEDIMENTARY BASINS BEING USED FOR GEOLOGIC STORAGE OF CARBON DIOXIDE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PLANNED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE (1) REVIEWING PREVIOUS STUDIES IN THE PUBLISHED LITERATURE THAT HAVE CHARACTERIZED GEOLOGIC (BASEMENT-INVOLVED) STRUCTURES IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES, (2) MINING AND COMPILING DATA FROM THAT LITERATURE SEARCH FOR USE IN THIS STUDY, (3) DIGITIZATION OF THE MINED DATA FOR INCLUSION IN AN ARCGIS FAULT DATABASE, (4) ANALYZING FAULT DATA IN THE FAULT SLIP POTENTIAL TOOL, (5) IDENTIFY SPATIAL CORRELATIONS BETWEEN EARTHQUAKES AND THE FAULTS ANALYZED FOR SLIP POTENTIAL. THE MAIN PRODUCT OF THIS WORK WILL BE A DIGITAL GIS DATABASE OF FAULTS IN THE MISSOURI, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, AND KENTUCKY REGION, CHARACTERIZED TO THE FULLEST EXTENT POSSIBLE, BY SIZE, ORIENTATION, SLIP MAGNITUDE, SLIP TENDENCY, DEPTH, AND LITHOLOGIES PENETRATED, THAT WILL AUGMENT CURRENT FAULT INFORMATION AND CAN CONTRIBUTE TO SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENT IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: ADDITIONAL DELIVERABLES FOR THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCLUDE SUBMISSION OF UPDATED ARCGIS DATA FILES TO USGS, WHICH WILL INCLUDE NEW LINES OF BASEMENT STRUCTURES, THAT ARE BASED ON NEW INTERPRETATIONS OF GEOPHYSICAL GEOLOGIC DATA, WITHIN THE MISSOURI, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, AND KENTUCKY REGION. ALSO, REPORTS PROVIDING DESCRIPTION OF HOW GEOPHYSICAL GEOLOGICAL DATA WERE INTEGRATED AND INTERPRETED TO IDENTIFY NEW FAULTS  AND A REPORT DESCRIBING THE SUSCEPTIBILITY OF FAULTS IN THE MISSOURI, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, AND KENTUCKY REGION. ADDITIONALLY, A DATABASE AND ASSOCIATED METADATA WILL BE CREATED AND DELIVERED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO THE SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH COMMUNITY WORKING ON TOPICS RELATED TO EARTHQUAKE-HAZARD ASSESSMENT AROUND THE MISSOURI, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, AND KENTUCKY REGION. THE OUTCOMES WILL SERVE AS ADDITIONAL GEOLOGIC INPUTS TO MODELS, AND AS SUCH WILL IMPROVE THE SOUNDNESS OF EARTHQUAKE-HAZARD ASSESSMENT WORK WITHIN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

PROJECT TITLE: QUANTIFYING THE ERASURE OF EARTHQUAKES FROM THE LANDSCAPE OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA: IMPLICATIONS FOR HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND PALEOSEISMOLOGYPROJECT PERIOD: 9 1 2023 THROUGH 8 31 2024PROJECT DESCRIPTION: PROBABILISTIC FAULT DISPLACEMENT HAZARD ANALYSIS (PFDHA) RELIES ON KNOWLEDGE OF THE MAGNITUDE AND DISTRIBUTION OF COSEISMIC SURFACE DISPLACEMENTS. FOR RECENT EARTHQUAKES, THIS INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE IN DETAIL AND CAN BE EMPIRICALLY EXTRACTED FROM RUPTURE MAPS, FIELD SURVEYS, AND POST-EARTHQUAKE DIGITAL ELEVATION MODELS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL QUANTIFY AND INTERPRET THE INFORMATION LOSS ASSOCIATED WITH SURFACE PROCESSES FOLLOWING AN EARTHQUAKE IN A CONTEXT THAT IS USEFUL FOR HAZARD ASSESSMENT. TO DO THIS, THEY WILL BUILD A SUITE OF 2D SURFACE PROCESS MODELS USING THE PEER-REVIEWED COMPUTATIONAL TOOLKIT LANDLAB. THESE WILL BE APPLIED TO HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL ELEVATION MODELS FROM ENVIRONMENTS IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WITH DIFFERENT ELAPSED TIME SINCE THE MOST RECENT EARTHQUAKE. THE RECIPIENT WILL CONSIDER DIFFERENT SECTIONS OF THE POST-EARTHQUAKE DEMS TO TEST HOW THE NUMBER OF FAULT STRANDS, FAULT GEOMETRY, INCOMPLETE RUPTURE TO THE SURFACE, COSEISMIC SLIP VARIABILITY, HOST ROCK PROPERTIES, AND DIFFERENT SURFACE PROCESS AND RATE CONSTANTS INFLUENCE THE INFORMATION AVAILABLE FOR MAPPING AT DIFFERENT TIMESCALES (0-25KY) SINCE THE EARTHQUAKE. THE RECIPIENT WILL PROGRESSIVELY INCREASE COMPLEXITY OF THE SURFACE PROCESS IDEALIZATIONS IN OUR MODELS, AS OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE OF VARIABILITY IN COSEISMIC FAULT PARAMETERS INCREASES. TO QUANTIFY THE INFORMATION LOSS ASSOCIATED WITH THE INFLUENCE OF SURFACE PROCESSES ON THE FAULTING RECORD, THEY WILL (1) MEASURE THE DEGRADATION OF THE RECORD OVER TIME, (2) MAP THE POST EVENT DEMS AT DIFFERENT TIME-STEPS TO EXAMINE HOW THE LENGTH AND DENSITY OF THE MAPPABLE FAULT TRACE(S) EVOLVE WITH TIME DEPENDING ON THE ORIGINAL SCARP CONFIGURATION AND SURFACE PROCESS IDEALIZATIONS, AND (3) GENERATE DISTANCE-DISPLACEMENT CURVES AT EACH TIME-STEP TO INDICATE HOW THE MAGNITUDE AND WIDTH OF THE MEASURABLE DISTRIBUTED DISPLACEMENT EVOLVE DUE TO EROSION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THESE PRODUCTS WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION. THE CODES AND SIMPLE TUTORIALS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE SO THE ANALYSES CAN BE DIRECTLY INCORPORATED INTO PROBABILISTIC FAULT DISPLACEMENT HAZARD ANALYSIS FRAMEWORKS BY END USERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: USGS HAZARDS ANALYSTS AND INDUSTRY REPRESENTATIVES CONSIDERING FAULT CROSSING CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE.

PROJECT TITLE: HVSR SITE TERMS FOR NONERGODIC GROUND MOTION MODELS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH TUFTS UNIVERSITYAND MERRIMACK COLLEGEPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO IMPROVE SITE TERMS IN GROUND MOTION MODELS USING A COMBINATION OF FREQUENCY, SHAPE, AND AMPLITUDE STATISTICS DERIVED FROM THE HORIZONTAL-TO-VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO OF OBSERVED GROUND MOTION DATA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: GROUND MOTION DATA ASSOCIATED WITH THE NGA-SUB (NEXT-GENERATION ATTENUATION FOR SUBDUCTION ZONE REGIONS PROJECT) FLATFILE WILL BE COMPILED. SINGLE-STATION HORIZONTAL-TO-VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIOS WILL BE CALCULATED FOR PRE-EVENT NOISE, WEAK EARTHQUAKE MOTIONS, AND STRONG EARTHQUAKE MOTIONS AT EACH STATION. A DATABASE OF HORIZONTAL TO VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO SHAPE PARAMETERS, INCLUDING NUMBER OF PEAKS, PEAK FREQUENCY, PEAK AMPLITUDE, PROMINENCE, HALF-POWER BANDWIDTH, AND INTEREVENT VARIABILITY OF SIGNIFICANT PEAKS WILL BE ASSEMBLED. USING LINEAR MIXED-EFFECTS REGRESSION AND EXISTING GROUND MOTION MODELS, SITE TERMS WILL BE CALCULATED AT EACH OF THE NGA-SUB STATIONS. THE RESULTS WILL BE USED TO DERIVE NEW SITE EFFECTS MODELS USING HORIZONTAL-TO-VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO PARAMETERS. THE NEW SITE-EFFECTS MODELS WILL BE EVALUATED AND COMPARED TO TERMS IN EXISTING MODELS FOR SITE EFFECTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A DATABASE OF HORIZONTAL TO VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO SHAPE PARAMETERS, INCLUDING NUMBER OF PEAKS, PEAK FREQUENCY, PEAK AMPLITUDE, PROMINENCE, HALF-POWER BANDWIDTH, AND INTEREVENT VARIABILITY OF SIGNIFICANT PEAKS WILL BE ASSEMBLED. USING THE COMPILED DATABASE, NEW MODELS FOR SITE EFFECTS WILL BE DEVELOPED IN TERMS OF HORIZONTAL-TO-VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO PARAMETERS. A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT, AN ABSTRACT AND PRESENTATION AT THE 2024 SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA (SSA) ANNUAL MEETING, AND A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL PAPER WILL BE PRODUCED TO SUMMARIZE THE WORK AND PRESENT THE RESULTS OF THE SITE TERM EVALUATION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: IMPROVED SITE TERMS IN GROUND MOTION MODELS WILL REDUCE THE GROUND MOTION UNCERTAINTY IN PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSES, AND ULTIMATELY BENEFIT ALL THOSE WHO USE REGIONAL AND LOCAL SEISMIC HAZARD PRODUCTS INCLUDING ENGINEERS, PLANNERS, AND LOSS ESTIMATORS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NIA

PROJECT TITLE: INCORPORATING RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS INTO MODELS FOR SIGNIFICANT DURATION, CUMULATIVEABSOLUTE VELOCITY, AND ARIAS INTENSITYPROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 2023 THROUGH 7 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE: THIS STUDY WILL ADDRESS AN IMPORTANT NEED BY UPDATING PREDICTION MODELS FOR THE FOLLOWING GROUND MOTION PARAMETERS: SIGNIFICANT DURATION, CUMULATIVE ABSOLUTE VELOCITY, AND ARIAS INTENSITY. THESE MODELS WILL BE UPDATED TO ACCOUNT FOR THE EFFECTS OF RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY, WHICH CAN HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS ON GROUND MOTIONS IN THE NEAR FAULT REGION (DEPENDING ON THE STYLE OF FAULTING AND THE SOURCE-SITE-HYPOCENTER GEOMETRY). CURRENTLY, MODELS FOR SIGNIFICANT DURATION, CUMULATIVE ABSOLUTE VELOCITY, AND ARIAS INTENSITY DO NOT ACCOUNT FOR RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS.THESE THREE GROUND MOTION PARAMETERS HAVE A LONG HISTORY AND WIDE RANGE OF USAGE IN VARIOUS GEOTECHNICAL AND STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS FOR DESCRIBING THE DAMAGE POTENTIAL OF EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTIONS. (E.G., GEOTECHNICAL: SEISMIC DISPLACEMENT OF LANDSLIDES, GENERATION OF EXCESSIVE PORE WATER PRESSURE FOR POTENTIALLY LIQUEFIABLE SOILS, PEAK DISPLACEMENTS OF PILE FOUNDATIONS, SLOPE STABILITY. STRUCTURAL: COLLAPSE CAPACITY OF STRUCTURES, SEISMIC PERFORMANCE OF BRIDGES, ACCUMULATED DAMAGE OF CONCRETE GRAVITY DAMS, NUCLEAR POWER PLANT SHUTDOWN CRITERION.) BY ACCOUNTING FOR RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS, WE WILL IMPROVE OUR CHARACTERIZATION OF THESE IMPORTANT PARAMETERS IN THE NEAR FAULT REGION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL PERFORM RESIDUAL ANALYSES USING THE NGA-WEST2 DATABASE (ANCHETA ET AL., 2013) AND USING THE SUITE OF EARTHQUAKE SIMULATIONS COLLECTED IN BAYLESS ET AL. (2020). RESIDUALS WILL BE CALCULATED FROM PUBLISHED MODELS FOR SIGNIFICANT DURATION, CUMULATIVE ABSOLUTE VELOCITY, AND ARIAS INTENSITY. THESE RESIDUALS WILL BE EVALUATED WITH RESPECT TO RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY PARAMETERS (E.G., BAYLESS ET AL., 2020  SOMERVILLE ET AL., 1997  SPUDICH ET AL., 2013) TO IDENTIFY RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS THAT ARE NOT CAPTURED IN THE GROUND MOTION MODELS. BASED ON THIS ANALYSIS, THE RECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP REFINEMENTS TO THE NEAR-FAULT PREDICTIONS OF THE PUBLISHED MODELS. FINALLY, WE WILL SYSTEMATICALLY TEST THE UPDATED MODELS AND WILL COMPARE WITH OTHER PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED MODELS TO ILLUSTRATE THE IMPACT OF INCORPORATING RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS ON THE PREDICTIONS. THE RECIPIENT WILL DOCUMENT THE PROCESS IN A TECHNICAL REPORT AND WILL PUBLISH IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PRODUCTS THAT THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE ARE:AN ADJUSTMENT TO THE AFSHARI AND STEWART (2016) SIGNIFICANT DURATION MODEL (MEDIAN AND STANDARD DEVIATION) FOR RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS.AN ADJUSTMENT TO THE CAMPBELL AND BOZORGNIA (2019) CUMULATIVE ABSOLUTE VELOCITY AND ARIAS INTENSITY MODELS (MEDIAN AND STANDARD DEVIATION) FOR RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS.COMPUTER CODES FOR IMPLEMENTATION.PUBLICATION OF THE MODELS IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THESE PRODUCTS WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO MANY HAZARD ANALYSTS AND ENGINEERS, INCLUDING THOSE AT THE USGS, AND WILL IMPROVE OUR CHARACTERIZATION OF NEAR-SOURCE SIGNIFICANT DURATION, CUMULATIVE ABSOLUTE VELOCITY, AND ARIAS INTENSITY.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

PROJECT TITLE: ACCURATE SOURCE PARAMETERS FROM HYBRID SPECTRAL AND SPECTRAL RATIO INVERSIONPROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 2023 THROUGH 6 20 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: ANALYZING THE PROPERTIES OF EARTHQUAKES IS CRITICAL FOR UNDERSTANDING FAULT SLIP DURING AN EARTHQUAKE, THE STRENGTH OF A FAULT, THE GROUND MOTIONS DUE TO AN EARTHQUAKE, AND ASSESSING SEISMIC HAZARD. ONE SUCH PROPERTY IS KNOWN AS STRESS DROP, ESSENTIALLY HOW MUCH STRESS ON THE FAULT IS RELEASED BY THE EARTHQUAKE. STRESS DROP IS TYPICALLY ESTIMATED FROM THE SPECTRUM OF THE WAVES (THE STRENGTH OF THE WAVES AS A FUNCTION OF FREQUENCY) FROM AN EARTHQUAKE. SEISMIC WAVES LOSE ENERGY AS THEY TRAVEL THROUGH THE EARTH. THIS IS KNOWN AS ATTENUATION, WHICH IS GREATER FOR HIGHER FREQUENCIES AND THUS AFFECTS THE EARTHQUAKE S SPECTRUM.  THE RECIPIENT DEVELOPED A METHOD OF ANALYSIS OF SPECTRA AT MULTIPLE STATIONS FOR MULTIPLE EVENTS SIMULTANEOUSLY THAT HAS BEEN SHOWN TO BE ABLE TO SOLVE FOR THE EARTHQUAKE S PROPERTIES AND ATTENUATION IN THE EARTH SIMULTANEOUSLY. THE RECIPIENT WILL APPLY THIS METHOD FOR LARGE SETS OF EARTHQUAKES SPANNING MORE THAN 20 YEARS IN THE 2019 RIDGECREST EARTHQUAKE AREA AND IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA IN CALIFORNIA. THE RIDGECREST AREA IS OF GREAT INTEREST DUE TO THE OCCURRENCE OF THE MAGNITUDE 7.1 EARTHQUAKE THERE IN JULY 2019, THE LARGEST EARTHQUAKE IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA IN THE 21ST CENTURY. THIS EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCE PROVIDES AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO STUDY THE EVOLUTION OF EARTHQUAKE PROPERTIES ON A COMPLEX FAULT SYSTEM AND ITS RESPONSE TO THE CHANGES IN STRESS CAUSED BY A LARGE EARTHQUAKE. THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA IS A HIGHLY POPULATED REGION FACING HIGH SEISMIC HAZARD AS IT IS CRISS-CROSSED BY NUMEROUS FAULTS INCLUDING THE HAYWARD FAULT, ONE OF MOST HAZARDOUS FAULTS IN THE STATE. IMPROVING OUR KNOWLEDGE OF EARTHQUAKE PROPERTIES IN THESE TWO AREAS WILL MAKE A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO IMPROVING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE SEISMIC HAZARD IN CALIFORNIA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL APPLY A NEW HYBRID SPECTRAL ANALYSIS METHOD TO DETERMINE EARTHQUAKE SOURCE PARAMETERS IN THE 2019 M7.1 RIDGECREST EARTHQUAKE AREA AND IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA IN CALIFORNIA.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: SOURCE PARAMETERS (COMER FREQUENCIES AND STRESS DROPS) FOR THOUSANDS OF EARTHQUAKES IN THE 2019 M7.1 RIDGECREST EARTHQUAKE AREA AND IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA IN CALIFORNIA WILL BE PROVIDED TO EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS RESEARCHERS IN CALIFORNIA AND TO THE STRESS DROP TECHNICAL ACTIVITY GROUP OF THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE CENTER. WE EXPECT OUR METHOD WILL BE ABLE TO PRODUCE MORE ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF COMER FREQUENCIES AND STRESS DROPS WITH REDUCED UNCERTAINTIES COMPARED TO OTHER METHODS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS PROGRAMSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NOT APPLICABLE.

PROJECT TITLE: EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING, IPAWS, AND OVER-ALERTING: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY FULLERTON AND UNIVERSITY AT ALBANYPROJECT PERIOD: 7 1 2023 THROUGH 6 30 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION. THIS PROJECT HAS TWO MAIN PURPOSES. THE FIRST PURPOSE IS TO EXAMINE THE WAYS IN WHICH MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC AND OFFICIAL ALERTING AUTHORITIES DEFINE AND UNDERSTAND  OVER-ALERTING  FOR IMMINENT HAZARDS. THE SECOND PURPOSE IS TO EXAMINE THE EFFECTS OF OVER ALERTING FOR EARTHQUAKES AND FOR OTHER HAZARDS IN THE LARGER PUBLIC ALERTING CONTEXT, INCLUDING THE NATION S INTEGRATED PUBLIC ALERT AND WARNING SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE  OVER-ALERTING  BROADLY, USING MULTIPLE DEFINITIONS AND MULTIPLE METHODS TO INCREASE VALIDITY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED. THE RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE THREE DIFFERENT DATA COLLECT ACTIVITIES. FIRST, THE STUDY TEAM WILL CONDUCT SEMI-STRUCTURED QUALITATIVE INDIVIDUAL INTERVIEWS WITH EMERGENCY MANAGERS WHO ARE AUTHORIZED ALERTING AUTHORITIES (N 20). SECOND, THE TEAM WILL CONDUCT A QUANTITATIVE SURVEY OF ALERTING AUTHORITIES FROM THE FIVE SEISMICALLY ACTIVE STATES ALONG THE U.S. WEST COAST, I.E., ALASKA, CALIFORNIA, HAWAII, OREGON, AND WASHINGTON (N 159). AND THIRD, THE TEAM WILL CONDUCT A QUANTITATIVE SURVEY OF RESIDENTS OF THOSE SAME STATES (N 1,200). THE WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT COLLABORATIVELY BY PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS MICHELE WOOD (CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, FULLERTON) AND JEANNETTE SUTTON (UNIVERSITY AT ALBANY), WHO HAVE A TRACK RECORD OF COLLABORATIVE WARNING RESEARCH, INCLUDING USGS-FUNDED RESEARCH.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT (DUE 10 31 2024) AND TWO PEER-REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS. THE FIRST MANUSCRIPT WILL IDENTIFY FACTORS THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH PUBLIC DISENGAGEMENT FROM EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING AND OTHER IMMINENT THREAT WARNING SYSTEMS. THE SECOND MANUSCRIPT WILL EXAMINE OVER-ALERTING, MESSAGE FATIGUE, AND HOW MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC AND ALERTING AUTHORITIES DEFINE, UNDERSTAND, AVOID, AND RESPOND TO OVER-ALERTING.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES). STUDY RESULTS WILL GENERATE USEFUL GUIDANCE, INCLUDING RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ALERT AND WARNING CONTENT AND DELIVERY, FOR U.S. FEDERAL AGENCIES, ALERTING AUTHORITIES, EMERGENCY MANAGERS, PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICIALS, AND BUSINESS OWNERS WHO BUILD MOBILE APPS TO COMMUNICATE RISK. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE INTEGRATED PUBLIC ALERT AND WARNING SYSTEM AND THE FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION ON THE USE OF WIRELESS EMERGENCY ALERTS FOR CATASTROPHIC EVENTS. GIVEN THE VARIETY OF CHANNELS DELIVERING EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING MESSAGE CONTENT, IN THE ABSENCE OF EVIDENCE-BASED GUIDANCE, OVER ALERTING MAY INADVERTENTLY LEAD TO PUBLIC DISENGAGEMENT FROM WARNING SYSTEMS. THIS IN TUM COULD INHIBIT THE REALIZATION OF POTENTIAL WARNING SYSTEM BENEFITS SUCH AS DECREASED EARTHQUAKE RELATED DEATHS AND INJURIES. FINALLY, MESSAGE RECEIVERS MAY BENEFIT BECAUSE DECISION MAKERS WILL HAVE SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE INFORMING MESSAGE DESIGN AND PROTOCOLS, WHICH MAY REDUCE, AND POSSIBLY PREVENT, OVER-ALERTING.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES. NOT APPLICABLE.

PROJECT TITLE:  EARTHQUAKE SIMULATORS AND NEXT GENERATION HAZARD MODELS (UCERF4): COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY AND USGS GOLDENPERFORMANCE PERIOD: 7 1 2023 THROUGH 6 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE:  SEISMIC HAZARD ESTIMATES ARE IMPORTANT TO SOCIETY, FORMING THE BASIS OF BUILDING CODES, INSURANCE RATES, AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES. YET THEY REST ON MANY UNCERTAIN ASSUMPTIONS, AND THIS FEATURE IS ONLY INCREASING FURTHER WITH FURTHER MODEL CAPABILITIES AND COMPLEXITY.  FURTHERMORE, THEY ARE VERY DIFFICULT TO TEST DUE TO THE LONG RECURRENCE TIMES OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES.  IN THIS CONTEXT, EARTHQUAKE SIMULATORS HAVE EMERGED AS A POTENTIAL TOOL TO HELP GUIDE NEXT GENERATION SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS. THIS PROJECT POINTS TO A MAJOR FRONT OF RECENT PROGRESS, A SUCCESSFUL REPLICATION BY EARTHQUAKE SIMULATORS OF LONG-TERM FAULT-BASED HAZARD IN UCERF3, AND HOW THESE NEW CAPABILITIES CAN BE USEFUL TO NEXT GENERATION HAZARD MAPS, FOCUSING ON A TIGHT COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE SIMULATORS AND DEVELOPMENT OF FAULT-BASED HAZARD IN THE WESTERN US REGION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE MAIN THEME OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS COMPARING THE SIMULATOR VERSUS THE STATISTICALLY-BASED MODEL OVER THE WESTERN US, EXTENDING WORK DONE PREVIOUSLY IN CALIFORNIA  SHAW ET AL., 2018  TO THE NEW GEOLOGIC MODEL FOR THE WESTERN US DEVELOPED BY HATEM ET AL.  2022 . DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THREE SPECIFIC PROJECTS ARE PROPOSED. THE FIRST IS TO LOOK AT HAZARD DIFFERENCE MAPS. THE SECOND IS TO LOOK AT DOMINANT MAGNITUDE, A KIND OF NONPARAMETRIC CORNER MAGNITUDE  IT IS THE MAGNITUDE OF THE MEDIAN OF THE CUMULATIVE MOMENT  SHAW ET AL., 2018 . THE THIRD IS TO COMPARE THE RUPTURE SETS. THE DIALOGUE BACK AND FORTH BETWEEN THE TWO APPROACHES SHOULD BE USEFUL TO BOTH. ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVEMENTS IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF AND CONFIDENCE IN SEISMIC HAZARD ESTIMATES IN THE WESTERN US. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS WORK WOULD ASSIST THE USGS IN IMPROVING SEISMIC HAZARD ESTIMATES. SEISMIC HAZARD ESTIMATES FEED INTO BUILDING CODES, AND THUS ENGINEERS AND SOCIETY AT LARGE WOULD BENEFIT FROM IMPROVEMENTS IN HAZARD ESTIMATES THROUGH IMPROVED MITIGATION EFFORTS TO REDUCE LOSS OF LIVES AND PROPERTY.SUBRECIPIENTS: N A

THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE INTEGRATED PUBLIC ALERT AND WARNING SYSTEM AND THE FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION ON THE USE OF WIRELESS EMERGENCY ALERTS FOR CATASTROPHIC EVENTS. GIVEN THE VARIETY OF CHANNELS DELIVERING EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING MESSAGE CONTENT, IN THE ABSENCE OF EVIDENCE-BASED GUIDANCE, OVER ALERTING MAY INADVERTENTLY LEAD TO PUBLIC DISENGAGEMENT FROM WARNING SYSTEMS. THIS IN TUM COULD INHIBIT THE REALIZATION OF POTENTIAL WARNING SYSTEM BENEFITS SUCH AS DECREASED EARTHQUAKE RELATED DEATHS AND INJURIES. FINALLY, MESSAGE RECEIVERS MAY BENEFIT BECAUSE DECISION MAKERS WILL HAVE SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE INFORMING MESSAGE DESIGN AND PROTOCOLS, WHICH MAY REDUCE, AND POSSIBLY PREVENT, OVER-ALERTING.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES. NOT APPLICABLE.

PROJECT TITLE: AFTERSHOCK REGIONS OF MW   6.5 EARTHQUAKES ON THE QUEEN CHARLOTTEFAIRWEATHER PLATE BOUNDARY, 1918 TO 2013PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY. PAST LARGE EARTHQUAKES PROVIDE ONE OF THE BEST INDICATORS OF WHAT CAN BE EXPECTED IN THE FUTURE. BY UNDERSTANDING PROPERTIES OF EARTHQUAKES SUCH AS THEIR SIZE, THE SHAKING INTENSITIES THEY PRODUCE, AND THE APPROXIMATE TIME INTERVAL FOR THEIR OCCURRENCE, SEISMOLOGISTS CAN PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION TO MITIGATE EARTHQUAKE RISKS OF PROPERTY DAMAGE AND LOSS OF LIFE. LARGE EARTHQUAKES TEND TO OCCUR ALONG THE BOUNDARIES BETWEEN EARTHS PLATES, WHERE STRESS BUILDS UP OVER TENS TO HUNDREDS OF YEARS AND THEN RELEASES IN A MATTER OF MINUTES DURING A LARGE EARTHQUAKE. ONE HIGHLY ACTIVE PLATE BOUNDARY IS IN THE NORTHEASTERN PACIFIC, WHERE THE PACIFIC PLATE MOVES TO THE NORTHWEST, ADJACENT TO THE QUEEN CHARLOTTEFAIRWEATHER FAULT SYSTEM (QCF), WHICH IS THE NORTHERNAND MORE ACTIVEANALOG OF THE SAN ANDREAS FAULT SYSTEM IN CALIFORNIA.AFTERSHOCKS FROM LARGE EARTHQUAKES PROVIDE AN APPROXIMATION FOR THE FAULT AREA THAT RUPTURED DURING THE MAIN EARTHQUAKE. BY CAREFULLY LOCATING AFTERSHOCKS, WE CAN INFER THE RUPTURE AREA OF THE MAIN EARTHQUAKE. BY EXAMINING A COMPLETE SET OF EVENTS ALONG A FAULT, WE CAN ASSESS THE LIKELIHOOD OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES OCCURRING IN THE FUTURE. THE PREVAILING AFTERSHOCK REGIONS FOR QCF WERE PUBLISHED IN 1981, WITH THE TWO LARGEST EARTHQUAKES (1949, 1958) DERIVED FROM AFTERSHOCKS RELOCATED IN 1968 USING GLOBALLY RECORDED ARRIVAL TIMES OF P AND S WAVES. WE PROPOSE TO APPLY MODERN METHODS TO RELOCATE ALL AFTERSHOCKS OF ALL LARGE (MW   6.5) EARTHQUAKES ON QCF SINCE THE INSTRUMENTAL ERA BEGAN IN 1897. THESE RELOCATED AFTERSHOCKS WILL THEN BE USED TO DETERMINE REVISED AFTERSHOCK REGIONS, WHICH WILL SERVE A RESURGENT SCIENTIFIC INTEREST IN QCF, SPURRED BY THE 20122013 MW   7 EARTHQUAKES.ACTIVITIES. THERE HAVE BEEN 11 MW   6.5 EARTHQUAKES ON OR NEAR QCF SINCE THE INSTRUMENTAL ERA BEGAN IN 1897, RANGING FROM 1918-12-06 MS 6.9, NEAR VANCOUVER, TO 2013-01-05 MW 7.5, NEAR CRAIG, ALASKA. WE WILL PERFORM A PROBABILISTIC EARTHQUAKE RELOCATION FOR ALL 118 AFTERSHOCKS THAT HAVE OCCURRED WITHIN 100 DAYS FOLLOWING EACH OF THE 11 MAINSHOCKS. THE 118 AFTERSHOCKS WILL BE CAREFULLY EXAMINED TO FORM A SUBSET OF EVENTS THAT ARE MOST LIKELY TO HAVE OCCURRED ON THE MAIN FAULT. THE FINAL CATALOG WILL BE USED TO ESTABLISH REVISED BOUNDARIES OF AFTERSHOCK REGIONS.DELIVERABLES. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A DIGITAL COLLECTION OF PROBABILISTIC EARTHQUAKE LOCATION RESULTS FOR ALL 118 AFTERSHOCKS FOR THE 11 MAINSHOCKS (E.G., LOMAX , 2022). FOR EACH AFTERSHOCK, WE PROVIDE A MAXIMUM LIKELIHOOD HYPOCENTER AS WELL AS A SET OF APPROXIMATELY 10,000 HYPOCENTERS THAT CHARACTERIZES THE UNCERTAINTY. THE REVISED AFTERSHOCK REGIONS WILL BE PROVIDED IN DIGITAL FORMAT, PRESENTED AT THE 2024 SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA MEETING IN ALASKA, AND PUBLISHED WITHIN A JOURNAL PUBLICATION.BENEFICIARIES. AFTERSHOCK REGIONS OF MAJOR EARTHQUAKES ON THE PACIFICNORTH AMERICA PLATE BOUNDARY ARE WIDELY USED IN THE SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE ON EARTHQUAKE OCCURRENCE AND ACTIVE TEC- TONICS. THE REVISED AFTERSHOCK REGIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BE MORE ACCURATE, BETTER DOCUMENTED, AND SIGNIFICANTLY DIFFERENT FROM THE PREVAILING ONES. THE REGIONS ARE USED BY USGS SCIENTISTS WITHIN CALCULATIONS FOR THE NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES. DR. ANTHONY LOMAX WILL PERFORM THE PROBABILISTIC EARTHQUAKE LOCATIONS USING NONLINLOC, SOFTWARE THAT HE HAS DEVELOPED AND MAINTAINS. THIS APPROACH REQUIRES CAREFUL TREATMENT OF ARRIVAL TIME UNCERTAINTY ASSIGNMENTS, WHICH VARY SIGNIFICANTLY OVER THE TIME PERIOD OF EARTHQUAKES CONSIDERED (1918 TO 2013).

PROJECT TITLE: KINEMATIC AND PALEOSEISMIC INVESTIGATION OF AN UPPER-PLATE FAULT ON CHIRIKOF ISLAND: A POTENTIAL TSUNAMI-SEISMIC HAZARD SOURCE WITHIN THE ALASKA SUBDUCTION ZONEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE PURPOSE: ALONG THE ALASKA SUBDUCTION ZONE, THE SEGMENT BETWEEN SHUMAGIN ISLANDS AND SEMIDI ISLANDS EXHIBITS AN ALONG-STRIKE TRANSITION FROM STRONG COUPLING IN THE EAST TO WEAK COUPLING IN THE WEST OF THE SUBDUCTION INTERFACE. THIS TRANSITION ZONE RECENTLY RUPTURED DURING TWO LARGE EARTHQUAKES IN 2020 AND 2021, AND THE RUPTURE PARTIALLY FILLED A PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED SHUMAGIN SEISMIC GAP. THESE EVENTS AND THE SEISMIC HISTORY OF THIS SEGMENT SUGGEST AN INCREASED POSSIBILITY OF A FUTURE MEGATHRUST RUPTURE IN THE STRONGLY COUPLED SEGMENT TO THE EAST BELOW CHIRIKOF ISLAND. CHIRIKOF ISLAND IS CUT BY AN ACTIVE FAULT, CHIRIKOF FAULT, WHICH CAN POTENTIALLY CORRELATE TO TSUNAMI-GENERIC SPLAY FAULTS IDENTIFIED IN ADJACENT SEGMENTS. THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CHIRIKOF FAULT AND ITS HISTORICAL ACTIVITIES ARE CRITICAL CONSTRAINTS ON ASSESSING THE STRESS STATE AND MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF THE ACCRETIONARY WEDGE AND ITS SEISMIC TSUNAMI HAZARD. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE STRUCTURES WITHIN THE ACCRETIONARY WEDGE IN AN ALONG-STRIKE TRANSITIONAL SEGMENT ALSO PROVIDES CRITICAL IMPLICATIONS ON FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS ABOUT MECHANISMS OF ACCRETIONARY WEDGE GROWTH, SUCH AS HOW A WEDGE DEFORMS IN RESPONSE TO CHANGES IN MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF DIFFERENT PARTS AND WEDGE BOUNDARY CONDITIONS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INVESTIGATE THE GEOMETRY, KINEMATICS, AND SEISMIC ACTIVITY OF THE CHIRIKOF FAULT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TO REVEAL THE GOAL AND LEVERAGE CONSTRAINTS ON ABOVE-MENTIONED QUESTIONS, THE INVESTIGATORS WILL CARRY OUT A ONE-YEAR INVESTIGATION CONSISTING OF FIELD SURVEY AND LAB ANALYSIS. THE INVESTIGATORS WILL CONDUCT DETAILED MAPPING OF GEOLOGY, GEOMORPHOLOGY, AND NEOTECTONICS ALONG THE FAULT TRACE AS WELL AS 14C DATING OF GEOMORPHOLOGIC FEATURES TO CONSTRAIN SEISMIC ACTIVITIES AND AVERAGED SLIP RATES OF THE FAULT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE 1) DETAILED MAPS OF GEOLOGY, GEOMORPHOLOGY, AND NEOTECTONICS ALONG THE CHIRIKOF FAULT AND 2) A REPORT OF FIELD OBSERVATIONS OF THE FAULT SYSTEM, PLOTS OF STRUCTURAL DATA WITH INTERPRETATION, RECONSTRUCTIONS OF GEOLOGICAL AND GEOMORPHOLOGIC FEATURES, 14C AGES, AND CALCULATED AVERAGED SLIP RATES OF THE FAULT.BENEFICIARIES: THE AWARD SUPPORTS THE INVESTIGATORS TO EXPAND THEIR CURRENT WORK ON KODIAK ISLAND WHICH IS CLOSELY RELATED TO THE PROPOSED WORK AND OVERLAPS WITH MANY TOPICS LISTED IN PRIORITY TOPICS FOR RESEARCH IN ALASKA. IT ALSO CREATES A TRAINING OPPORTUNITY FOR AN UNDERGRADUATE FIELD ASSISTANT.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THERE IS NO KNOWN SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITY AT THE TIME OF AWARD.

PROJECT TITLE: INTEGRATING SATELLITE IMAGERY AND PAGER LOSS MODELING FOR IMPROVED BUILDING DAMAGE ESTIMATES: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH BETWEEN STONY BROOK UNIVERSITY AND USGSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: THE RECIPIENT WILL INTRODUCE A NOVEL CAUSALITY-INFORMED PROBABILISTIC INFERENCE FRAMEWORK TO RAPIDLY ESTIMATE LARGE-SCALE BUILDING DAMAGE SEVERITY BY USING SATELLITE IMAGES. THE RECIPIENT WILL INTEGRATE GROUND SHAKING, BUILDING DAMAGE, GROUND FAILURES, REMOTELY SENSED OBSERVATIONS, AND THEIR COMPLEX CAUSAL DEPENDENCIES INTO A HOLISTIC CAUSAL GRAPH, FORMULATE THE GRAPH AS A NEW FAMILY OF CAUSAL BAYESIAN NETWORKS FOR BUILDING DAMAGE ESTIMATION. THE ADVANTAGE OF THIS APPROACH IS THAT THE CAUSAL GRAPH ALLOWS MORE COMPLEX MODELING AND NONLINEAR PROCESSES OF HOW A MAJOR EARTHQUAKE TRIGGERS CASCADING HAZARDS AND BUILDING DAMAGE, WITHOUT THE NEED FOR DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT STRUCTURAL TYPE AND THE USE OF BUILDINGS. MOREOVER, THE PROPOSED CONTINUAL VARIATIONAL INFERENCE FRAMEWORK IS FLEXIBLE TO INTEGRATE ANY AVAILABLE SATELLITE IMAGES WITH OR WITHOUT GROUND TRUTH DATA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE ONE-YEAR RESEARCH PROJECT INCLUDES ALGORITHM DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION ON REAL-WORLD EARTHQUAKE EVENTS BY COLLABORATING SCIENTISTS FROM UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. THE RECIPIENT WILL FIRST FORMULATE THE CAUSAL BAYESIAN NETWORK, AND VALIDATE THE ASSUMPTIONS USING THE COLLECTED DATA, AND THEN DERIVE VARIATIONAL LOWER BOUND AND EXPLORING NEW JOINT ESTIMATION AND UPDATING APPROACHES TO ENABLE A FAST, ACCURATE, AND SCALABLE GROUND FAILURE AND BUILDING DAMAGE ESTIMATION. THE RECIPIENT WILL VALIDATE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND TIGHTNESS OF THE DERIVED LOWER BOUND THROUGH MATHEMATICAL SIMULATION. FURTHER, THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK ON DESIGNING NEW APPROACHES FOR JOINT ESTIMATION AND UPDATING POSTERIOR AND PRIOR MODELS AND CHARACTERIZE THE PERFORMANCE UNDER VARIOUS REAL-WORLD EVENTS. FINALLY, THE RECIPIENT WILL ITERATE ALL COMPONENTS FOR MODEL AND METHOD REFINEMENT AND EVALUATION ON MORE EVENTS AND SUMMARIZE THE RESULTS INTO A JOURNAL PAPER BASED ON THE RESULTS AS WELL AS A TECHNICAL REPORT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A GENERAL SET OF NEW APPROACHES TO INTEGRATE EXISTING SEISMIC IMPACT MODELS IN UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND SATELLITE IMAGES FOR JOINT ESTIMATION OF MULTI-CLASS BUILDING DAMAGE. THE RECIPIENT WILL DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS, INCLUDING DATA, MODELS, AND CODES OF THIS PROJECT TO A BROAD AUDIENCE THROUGH PUBLICATIONS, OUTREACH, AND OPEN SOURCE DATA PLATFORM. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO DISSEMINATE THE WORK THROUGH PUBLICATIONS IN PROFESSIONAL ACADEMIC JOURNALS AND CONFERENCES IN EARTHQUAKE ENGINEERING, REMOTE SENSING, AND MACHINE LEARNING COMMUNITIES. THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO TARGET SEMINARS AT ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS AS WELL AS GOVERNMENT AND INDUSTRY ENTITIES TO FURTHER EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE RESEARCH.INTENDED BENEFICIARY: THIS RESEARCH WILL IMMEDIATELY BENEFIT MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING EMERGENCY RESPONDERS AND USERS, AND SERVE FOR TECHNOLOGY ADVANCEMENT IN UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. THIS RESEARCH WILL ALSO BENEFIT REMOTE SENSING AND EARTHQUAKE RESEARCHERS BY PROVIDING A NEW CONCEPT AND APPROACH TO JOINTLY INFER BUILDING DAMAGE AND UPDATE PRIOR LOCAL BUILDING DAMAGE MODELS USING HIGH-RESOLUTION REMOTE SENSING OBSERVATIONS AND CAUSAL BAYESIAN NETWORK. THE WORK WILL BRIDGE COMPUTER SCIENCE, GEOSCIENCES, AND CIVIL ENGINEERING DOMAINS AND NATURALLY LEAD TO DISSEMINATION OF THE WORK IN ALL DOMAINS THROUGH PUBLICATIONS, SEMINARS, MEDIA EXPOSURE, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES.SUBRECIPIENTS: N A

PROJECT TITLE: HOLOCENE PALEOSEISMOLOGY OF THE DARRINGTON-DEVILS MOUNTAIN FAULT ZONE AT LAKE CAVANAUGH, WASHINGTON: TESTING THE LAKES SENSITIVITY TO LOCAL AND REGIONAL EARTHQUAKESPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6 16 2023 THROUGH 6 15 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: THE DARRINGTON-DEVILS MOUNTAIN FAULT ZONE NORTH OF SEATTLE, WASHINGTON, IS A GEOLOGIC STRUCTURE THAT HAS PRODUCED LARGE PREHISTORIC EARTHQUAKES. THE FAULT ACCOMMODATES A PORTION OF WESTERN WASHINGTON S NORTHWARD TECTONIC MOVEMENT AND CLOCKWISE ROTATION. THE FAULT ZONE IS CLOSE TO OR PASSES BENEATH CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE, INCLUDING INTERSTATE-5, PETROLEUM PIPELINES, AND LARGE-SCALE COMMERCIAL AND MILITARY INSTALLATIONS. MOVEMENT ALONG THIS FAULT COULD GENERATE DAMAGING EARTHQUAKES IN THE FUTURE. AS A RESULT, SCIENTISTS ARE STUDYING THE FAULT ZONE TO LEARN MORE ABOUT ITS HISTORY AND EARTHQUAKE POTENTIAL.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TO ACCOMPLISH THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES, INVESTIGATORS WILL (1) COLLECT SEISMIC REFLECTION DATA (IMAGERY) OF LAKE CAVANAUGH S SEDIMENTARY SEQUENCE AND (2) PERFORM HIGH-RESOLUTION MAPPING OF THE LAKE BOTTOM (BATHYMETRY). THESE TWO DATA SETS WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE IF PAST EARTHQUAKES FROM THE DARRINGTON-DEVILS MOUNTAIN FAULT OFFSET THE LAKE FLOOR AND SEDIMENTARY SEQUENCE. THE SEISMIC AND BATHYMETRY DATA WILL ALSO GUIDE (3) THE LOCATION OF SEDIMENT CORES RECOVERED FROM THE LAKE BOTTOM. SEDIMENT ACCUMULATION RATES FROM THE CORES WILL BE DETERMINED (4) USING THE RADIOCARBON ( 4C) GEOCHRONOLOGY METHOD. FINALLY, (5) THE PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL DESCRIPTIONS OF CORE SEDIMENTS WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE IF EARTHQUAKES CAUSED EVENT LAYERS, KNOWN AS TURBIDITES, IN LAKE CAVANAUGH, THE AGE OF WHICH WILL BE EVALUATED BASED ON THE SEDIMENT ACCUMULATION RATES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: INVESTIGATORS WILL MAKE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATA, SAMPLES, AND INTERPRETATIONS FROM THIS STUDY, INCLUDING PHYSICAL SEDIMENT CORES, RAW AND PROCESSED SEISMIC AND BATHYMETRY DATA, GEOCHRONOLOGIC RESULTS, AND GEOGRAPHIC DATA INFORMATION SYSTEMS (GIS) PRODUCTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE NUMBER AND TIMING OF EARTHQUAKES RECORDED IN LAKE CAVANAUGH S SEDIMENTARY RECORD AND THE DIFFERENTIATION BETWEEN EARTHQUAKES ON THE DARRINGTON-DEVILS MOUNTAIN FAULT FROM REGIONAL EVENTS. IN ADDITION, INVESTIGATORS WILL COMBINE ESTIMATES OF GROUND SHAKING INTENSITY EXPERIENCED AT LAKE CAVANAUGH FOR HISTORIC EVENTS TO CREATE A MAGNITUDE-DISTANCE SCALING CURVE FOR EARTHQUAKE EVENT LAYER PRODUCTION IN THE LAKE THAT WILL HAVE UTILITY FOR REGIONAL EARTHQUAKE HAZARD ASSESSMENTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE DATA AND INTERPRETATIONS FROM THIS INVESTIGATION WILL BENEFIT THE SCIENTIFIC, ENGINEERING, AND DISASTER MANAGEMENT COMMUNITIES INTERESTED IN THE HISTORY AND HAZARD REDUCTION FROM EARTHQUAKES IN THE PUGET SOUND REGION OF WASHINGTON STATE. IN ADDITION, SCIENCE COMMUNICATION OUTREACH EFFORTS RESULTING FROM THIS INVESTIGATION WILL BENEFIT LOCAL AND REGIONAL COMMUNITIES INTERESTED IN EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS AND RISK REDUCTION STRATEGIES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: FORCE CHAIN BUCKLING AS A GRANULAR FAULT GOUGE STICK-SLIP AND SEISMICITY MECHANISMPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 4 15 2023 THROUGH 4 14 2024PLAN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A MECHANICAL MODEL FOR SLIP ON EARTHQUAKE FAULTS THAT INCORPORATES PRINCIPLES OF MECHANICAL STABILITY, NUMERICAL MODELS OF PARTICLE AND ROCK BEHAVIOR, AND STATISTICAL INTEGRATION OF NUMERICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL DATA. THE PROJECT USES THE LATEST ADVANCES IN MECHANICAL MODELS OF THE GRANULAR MATERIALS WHICH CONSTITUTE EARTHQUAKE FAULTS, PARTICLE MODELING SOFTWARE WHICH SIMULATE THE FLOW OF PARTICULATE MATERIALS, AND AVAILABLE STATISTICAL ANALYSIS AND DATA INTEGRATION TECHNIQUES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI) WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH A PH.D. STUDENT TO: (1) DEVELOP A MECHANICAL AND MATHEMATICAL MODEL INCORPORATING PRINCIPLES OF MECHANICAL STABILITY TO PREDICT SLIP (OR STICK-SLIP) ON EARTHQUAKE FAULTS AND THE CONSEQUENT EFFECTS SUCH AS STRESS DROPS, REARRANGEMENTS, AND MACROSCOPIC ENERGY DISSIPATION  (2) DEVELOP AND EXECUTE NUMERICAL DISCRETE ELEMENT METHOD (DEM) SIMULATIONS OF MODEL GRANULAR FAULT GOUGE TO CHARACTERIZE SLIP AND STICK-SLIP STATISTICS OF GRANULAR SYSTEMS WITH VARYING PROPERTIES RELEVANT TO NATURAL FAULTS  (3) STUDY LINKS BETWEEN GRANULAR MATERIAL PROPERTIES (PARTICLE SIZES, FRICTION, STIFFNESS) AND FAULT BEHAVIOR(STRESS DROPS, RECURRENCE TIMES) AND EXPLORE LINKS TO TECTONIC-SCALE BEHAVIORS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL DELIVER A MODEL FOR PREDICTING STRESS DROPS IN GRANULAR FAULT GOUGE BASED ON MECHANICAL AND MATHEMATICAL MODELING. THE MODEL WILL BE PUBLISHED IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN A SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL BY THE PI AND PH.D. STUDENT. THE MODEL AND RELEVANT NUMERICAL CODE WILL ALSO BE MADE AVAILABLEFOR OTHER RESEARCHERS AS SUPPLEMENTARY CONTENT TO THE PAPER OR ON ANOTHER PUBLIC REPOSITORY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PROJECT BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE ACADEMIC AND GOVERNMENT RESEARCHERS, INCLUDING THOSE AT THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, STUDYING EARTHQUAKES, SLIP AND STICKSLIP ON GRANULAR FAULTS, AND TECTONIC-SCALE BEHAVIORS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE.

PROJECT TITLE: BUILDING A CVM FOR SEISMIC RESILIENCE IN WESTERN NEVADA S INDUSTRIAL BASE: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH THE UNIV. OF NEVADA, RENO AND UNIV. OF CINCINNATIPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 5 15 2023 THROUGH 5 14 2024SUMMARY ACCURATE AND AVAILABLE EARTH MODELS ARE CRITICAL FOR UNDERSTANDING AND MODELING POTENTIAL EARTHQUAKE SHAKING HAZARDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS A CRITICAL PRIORITY FOR NEVADA BY COLLECTING DATA THAT ALLOW FOR IMPROVING THESE EARTH MODELS IN AREAS THAT ARE OF ECONOMICAL IMPORTANCE. IN WESTERN NEVADA, THE LOGISTICS AND MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES HAVE EXPANDED RAPIDLY IN TWO VALLEYS ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF THE RENO METRO AREA. STEAD LEMMON VALLEY AND THE TAHOE RENO INDUSTRIAL CENTER (TRIC) IN THE VIRGINIA RANGE NOW PROVIDE TENS OF THOUSANDS OF JOBS, AND ACCOUNT FOR MOST OF THE EMPLOYMENT GROWTH IN NEVADA OUTSIDE OF LAS VEGAS. HOWEVER, RECENT WORK ON THE RENO-AREA BASIN DID NOT EVALUATE POTENTIAL EARTHQUAKE SHAKING OR BASIN AMPLIFICATION IN THESE VALLEYS. ACCURATE PREDICTION OF STRONG GROUND MOTION DEPENDS ON UNDERSTANDING BOTH THE GEOLOGICAL BASIN FLOOR GEOMETRY AND LATERAL AND VERTICAL CHANGES IN SHEAR-WAVE VELOCITY WITHIN THE BASIN. PRIOR PHYSICS-BASED SEISMIC MODELING WORK IN RENO AND YUCCA FLAT, NEVADA, DEMONSTRATES THIS DEPENDENCE. WE THEREFORE PROPOSE TO USE DEEP REFRACTION MICROTREMOR (REMI) AND HORIZONTAL-TO-VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO (H V RATIO) SEISMIC METHODS, AND GRAVITY MEASUREMENTS AND MODELING TO ELUCIDATE SHEAR WAVE EARTH VELOCITY STRUCTURE TO DEPTHS OF ONE KILOMETER, CONSTRAIN BASIN FLOOR GEOMETRIES, AND EVALUATE SITE RESPONSE TO EARTHQUAKES ALONG SEVERAL TRANSECTS WITHIN LEMMON VALLEY AND TRIC.ACTIVITIES IN THIS STUDY, WE PROPOSE NINE TRANSECTS OF GEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS, GRAVITY MEASUREMENTS, AND SURFACE-WAVE ARRAY RECORDINGS ACROSS LEMMON VALLEY AND TRIC, TOTALING 75 KM IN LENGTH. THESE TRANSECTS ARE PLACED TO LEVERAGE AND DETAIL THE BROAD-SCALE VOLCANIC AND SEDIMENTARY BASIN-THICKNESS RESULTS DEVELOPED BY USGS INVESTIGATORS IN 1995 AT 2 KM RESOLUTION. THE PROJECT WILL EMPLOY THREE UNDERGRADUATE INTERNS FOR 12 WEEKS OF SUMMER FIELD ASSISTANCE AND DATA-REDUCTION WORK. THESE DATA UPDATE THE EXISTING COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL (CVM) FOR THE RENO AREA. DELIVERABLES THE PIS WILL CONTINUE TO MAKE THE UPDATED CVM PUBLICLY AND FREELY AVAILABLE TO THE SEISMOLOGICAL AND ENGINEERING COMMUNITIES FOR GROUND-MOTION PREDICTION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES AS A RESULT OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT, THE WESTERN NEVADA COMMUNITY WILL HAVE A MORE THOROUGH AND NUANCED UNDERSTANDING OF THE SHEAR-WAVE VELOCITY STRUCTURE AND SITE RESPONSE TO SHAKING WITHIN TRIC AND STEAD. THESE DATA WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO AN UPDATED COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL THAT WILL QUICKLY BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE. THIS MODEL WILL BE USEFUL TO URBAN PLANNERS, DEVELOPERS, AND RESEARCHERS, WHICH IS CRITICAL IN THESE ECONOMIC CENTERS OF NEVADA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OUR EFFORTS WILL ADD TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF VELOCITY AND BASIN STRUCTURE UNDER TWO OF THE ECONOMICALLY MOST IMPORTANT AREAS OF NEVADA. THESE RESULTS WILL BE ADDED TO THE COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL TO ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE AND REALISTIC ASSESSMENT OF POTENTIAL SHAKING FROM EARTHQUAKES. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP THE REGION PREPARE FOR SEISMIC ACTIVITY AND TO INCREASE RESILIENCY FOLLOWING SEISMIC EVENTS.SUBRECIPIENT: N A

PROJECT TITLE: DETECTION THRESHOLDS FOR LARGE TO GREAT SUBDUCTION EARTHQUAKES IN ALASKA: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITHDURHAM UNIVERSITY AND THE USGSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 5 1 2023 THROUGH 4 30 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION:  THIS PROJECT WILL UNDERTAKE FIELD AND LABORATORY INVESTIGATIONS AND SUBSEQUENT DATA ANALYSIS TO INVESTIGATE WHETHER THE UPPER PART OF COASTAL MARSHES IN THE PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND AREA OF ALASKA POSSESS RECORDS OF VERTICAL DEFORMATION OF LESS THAN 1 M CAUSED BY EARTHQUAKES MW8.0 EARTHQUAKES OVER THE PAST 4000 YEARS. THE SAMPLING DESIGN OF THESE STUDIES WHICH FOCUSES ON MARSH-FRONT LOCATIONS DOES NOT DETECT SMALLER LAND-LEVEL CHANGES CAUSED BY SMALLER EARTHQUAKES DURING THIS TIME-PERIOD. THIS NEW STUDY WILL USE A NEW, COMPLEMENTARY METHOD LOOKING AT SEDIMENTS FROM THE UPPER PART OF COASTAL MARSHES TO INVESTIGATE WHETHER WE CAN RECONSTRUCT SMALLER AMOUNTS OF DEFORMATION ( 1M) AND THEREFORE CREATE A MORE COMPLETE CATALOGUE OF EARTHQUAKE EVENTS IN THIS REGION DURING THE LAST FEW MILLENNIA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE COLLECTING SEDIMENT CORES FROM GIRDWOOD MARSH (PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND REGION) DURING A 10-DAY FIELD CAMPAIGN IN SUMMER 2023. WE WILL ALSO COLLECT ADDITIONAL SURFACE SEDIMENT SAMPLES TO INCLUDE IN AN EXISTING DATABASE OF MICROFOSSILS FROM ALASKAN COASTAL MARSHES. THE SEDIMENT CORE AND SURFACE SEDIMENT SAMPLES WILL BE ANALYSED FOR MICROFOSSILS (DIATOMS) THAT RECORD CHANGES IN WATER LEVEL OVER TIME, AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS WILL ALLOW RECONSTRUCTION OF ABRUPT LAND-LEVEL CHANGES IN THE CORES. TOGETHER WITH RADIOCARBON DATING OF THE SEDIMENTS THIS WILL ALLOW ESTIMATES OF THE TIMING AND MAGNITUDE OF LAND-LEVEL CHANGES IN-BETWEEN THE 1M  EVENTS ALREADY IDENTIFIED IN THE GIRDWOOD RECORD. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: WE WILL COLLECT SEDIMENT CORE SEQUENCES AND MODERN SEDIMENT SAMPLES DURING FIELDWORK AND ANALYSES THEM AT DURHAM UNIVERSITY, UK. COUNTS OF MODERN MICROFOSSIL DISTRIBUTIONS WILL BE ADDED TO AN EXISTING MICROFOSSIL DATABASE WIDELY USED BY RESEARCHERS IN THIS FIELD. CORE LOGS, MICROFOSSIL COUNT SHEETS AND RADIOCARBON DATING RESULTS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE ONLINE ON PUBLICATION OF THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT. WE WILL PRESENT THE WORK AT AN INTERNATIONAL SCIENCE MEETING, WRITE A FINAL REPORT FOR THE USGS AND SUBMIT THE RESULTS TO AN INTERNATIONAL PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS RESEARCH WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS REDUCING UNCERTAINTIES REGARDING THE NATURE OF FUTURE EARTHQUAKE HAZARD IN SOUTH CENTRAL ALASKA, AND ALSO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE NATURE OF PAST EARTHQUAKE RUPTURES IN THIS REGION. THE PROJECT RESULTS WILL INFORM FUTURE RESEARCH ON IDENTIFYING SMALLER AMOUNTS OF DEFORMATION IN ALASKAN MARSHES AND CONTRIBUTE TO FUTURE UPDATES OF THE SEISMIC AND TSUNAMI HAZARD MAPS OF ALASKA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE: BUILDING A CVM FOR SEISMIC RESILIENCE IN WESTERN NEVADA S INDUSTRIAL BASE: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH THE UNIV. OF NEVADA, RENO AND UNIV. OF CINCINNATIPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 5 15 2023 THROUGH 5 14 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY ACCURATE AND AVAILABLE EARTH MODELS ARE CRITICAL FOR UNDERSTANDING AND MODELING POTENTIAL EARTHQUAKE SHAKING HAZARDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS A CRITICAL PRIORITY FOR NEVADA BY COLLECTING DATA THAT ALLOW FOR IMPROVING THESE EARTH MODELS IN AREAS THAT ARE OF ECONOMICAL IMPORTANCE. IN WESTERN NEVADA, THE LOGISTICS AND MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES HAVE EXPANDED RAPIDLY IN TWO VALLEYS ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF THE RENO METRO AREA. STEAD LEMMON VALLEY AND THE TAHOE RENO INDUSTRIAL CENTER (TRIC) IN THE VIRGINIA RANGE NOW PROVIDE TENS OF THOUSANDS OF JOBS, AND ACCOUNT FOR MOST OF THE EMPLOYMENT GROWTH IN NEVADA OUTSIDE OF LAS VEGAS. HOWEVER, RECENT WORK ON THE RENO-AREA BASIN DID NOT EVALUATE POTENTIAL EARTHQUAKE SHAKING OR BASIN AMPLIFICATION IN THESE VALLEYS. ACCURATE PREDICTION OF STRONG GROUND MOTION DEPENDS ON UNDERSTANDING BOTH THE GEOLOGICAL BASIN FLOOR GEOMETRY AND LATERAL AND VERTICAL CHANGES IN SHEAR-WAVE VELOCITY WITHIN THE BASIN. PRIOR PHYSICS-BASED SEISMIC MODELING WORK IN RENO AND YUCCA FLAT, NEVADA, DEMONSTRATES THIS DEPENDENCE. WE THEREFORE PROPOSE TO USE DEEP REFRACTION MICROTREMOR (REMI) AND HORIZONTAL-TO-VERTICAL SPECTRAL RATIO (H V RATIO) SEISMIC METHODS, AND GRAVITY MEASUREMENTS AND MODELING TO ELUCIDATE SHEAR WAVE EARTH VELOCITY STRUCTURE TO DEPTHS OF ONE KILOMETER, CONSTRAIN BASIN FLOOR GEOMETRIES, AND EVALUATE SITE RESPONSE TO EARTHQUAKES ALONG SEVERAL TRANSECTS WITHIN LEMMON VALLEY AND TRIC.ACTIVITIES IN THIS STUDY, WE PROPOSE NINE TRANSECTS OF GEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS, GRAVITY MEASUREMENTS, AND SURFACE-WAVE ARRAY RECORDINGS ACROSS LEMMON VALLEY AND TRIC, TOTALING 75 KM IN LENGTH. THESE TRANSECTS ARE PLACED TO LEVERAGE AND DETAIL THE BROAD-SCALE VOLCANIC AND SEDIMENTARY BASIN-THICKNESS RESULTS DEVELOPED BY USGS INVESTIGATORS IN 1995 AT 2 KM RESOLUTION. THE PROJECT WILL EMPLOY THREE UNDERGRADUATE INTERNS FOR 12 WEEKS OF SUMMER FIELD ASSISTANCE AND DATA-REDUCTION WORK. THESE DATA UPDATE THE EXISTING COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL (CVM) FOR THE RENO AREA. DELIVERABLES THE PIS WILL CONTINUE TO MAKE THE UPDATED CVM PUBLICLY AND FREELY AVAILABLE TO THE SEISMOLOGICAL AND ENGINEERING COMMUNITIES FOR GROUND-MOTION PREDICTION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES AS A RESULT OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT, THE WESTERN NEVADA COMMUNITY WILL HAVE A MORE THOROUGH AND NUANCED UNDERSTANDING OF THE SHEAR-WAVE VELOCITY STRUCTURE AND SITE RESPONSE TO SHAKING WITHIN TRIC AND STEAD. THESE DATA WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO AN UPDATED COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL THAT WILL QUICKLY BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE. THIS MODEL WILL BE USEFUL TO URBAN PLANNERS, DEVELOPERS, AND RESEARCHERS, WHICH IS CRITICAL IN THESE ECONOMIC CENTERS OF NEVADA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OUR EFFORTS WILL ADD TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF VELOCITY AND BASIN STRUCTURE UNDER TWO OF THE ECONOMICALLY MOST IMPORTANT AREAS OF NEVADA. THESE RESULTS WILL BE ADDED TO THE COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL TO ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE AND REALISTIC ASSESSMENT OF POTENTIAL SHAKING FROM EARTHQUAKES. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP THE REGION PREPARE FOR SEISMIC ACTIVITY AND TO INCREASE RESILIENCY FOLLOWING SEISMIC EVENTS.SUBRECIPIENT: N A

PROJECT TITLE: TOWARD EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING IN NEVADAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6 1 2023 THROUGH 5 31 202AWARD PURPOSE: NEVADA IS ONE OF THE MOST SEISMICALLY ACTIVE STATES IN THE US, WITH MAJOR POPULATION THROUGHOUT THE STATE THAT ARE EXPOSED TO SIGNIFICANT EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS. RECENT EARTHQUAKE ACTIVITY AND CRUSTAL DEFORMATION PATTERNS, ALONG WITH PALEOSEISMIC AND HISTORICAL RECORDS, STRONGLY SUGGEST THAT MAGNITUDE M6 AND M7 EARTHQUAKES WILL CONTINUE TO IMPACT THE STATE IN THE COMING YEARS. TARGETED RESEARCH INTO NEW EARTHQUAKE HAZARD MITIGATION STRATEGIES ARE THUS OF HIGH PRIORITY AND WOULD PROVIDE IMMEDIATE BENEFITS TO THE GROWING POPULATION THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND IN BORDERING REGIONS. THIS AWARD SUPPORTS FUNDAMENTAL SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH INTO THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING SYSTEM FOR THE STATE OF NEVADA THAT WOULD BRING SECONDS-TO-MINUTES WARNING THAT STRONG SHAKING IS IMMINENT IN THE EVENT OF A LARGE EARTHQUAKE. EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS OF THIS TYPE ARE ALREADY OPERATIONAL IN OTHER WESTERN US STATES  THIS PROJECT WOULD OPTIMIZE EXISTING TECHNIQUES FOR NEVADA WHILE PROVIDING NEW INSIGHTS AND OBSERVATIONS THAT WOULD BENEFIT EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FOR AN EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING TO BECOME A REALITY IN NEVADA, IT IS IMPORTANT TO CAREFULLY ASSESS THE PRACTICAL FEASIBILITY AND LIMITATIONS OF SUCH A SYSTEM IN THE STATE. THIS PROJECT ACCOMPLISHES THIS OBJECTIVE BY ADDRESSING A SET OF OUTSTANDING QUESTIONS RELATED TO EARTHQUAKE MONITORING IN THE NEVADA. PROJECT TASKS WILL INCLUDE: (1) BENCHMARK CALCULATIONS OF WARNING TIMES FOR HYPOTHETICAL EARTHQUAKE SOURCES, OUTLINING HIGH-PRIORITY AREAS FOR FUTURE STATION INSTALLATIONS OR UPGRADES, (2) QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENTS OF PEAK DISPLACEMENT  MAGNITUDE SCALING RELATIONS FOR THE STATE TO DETERMINE WHETHER A NEW REGIONAL SCALING RELATION SHOULD BE CALIBRATED, AND (3) A COMPARISON OF GROUND MOTION MODEL PREDICTIONS WITH OBSERVED PEAK GROUND MOTION RECORDINGS TO QUANTIFY EXPECTED ALERT UNCERTAINTIES AND BIASES, AS WELL AS MEASURE VALUE-ADDED BY REGION-SPECIFIC GROUND MOTION MODELS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT LAY THE SCIENTIFIC FOUNDATION FOR BRINGING EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING TO NEVADA. NOTABLE OUTCOMES WOULD INCLUDE: (I) A FIRST-ORDER ASSESSMENT OF ALERT TIMES FOR TARGET EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE SCENARIOS, (II) QUANTITATIVE GUIDANCE ON FUTURE UPGRADES AND EXPANSION OF THE REGIONAL SEISMIC NETWORK IN ORDER TO IMPROVE ALERT PERFORMANCE, (III) A DETAILED STUDY OF REAL-TIME MAGNITUDE ESTIMATION FOR EARTHQUAKES IN NEVADA, AND (IV) A FIRST-OF-ITS-KIND ANALYSIS OF HOW OBSERVED GROUND MOTION INTENSITIES WITHIN THE STATE COMPARE TO THE PRESENT SUITE OF GROUND MOTION MODEL PREDICTIONS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE SUITE OF HAZARD MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT NEVADA AND IN BORDERING STATES. MOREOVER, THE SCIENTIFIC INSIGHTS GAINED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING SYSTEMS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY, INCLUDING THE SHAKEALERT SYSTEM OPERATIONAL IN CALIFORNIA, OREGON, AND WASHINGTON. THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WOULD GREATLY EXPAND THE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THIS AWARD DOES NOT INCLUDE SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

PROJECT TITLE  EXPLORATORY PALEOSEISMIC INVESTIGATION OF THE QUIN SABE FAULT, SAN BENITO COUNTY, CALIFORNIAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  4 1 2023 THROUGH 3 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE   THE QUIN SABE FAULT IS ONE OF SEVERAL POORLY CHARACTERIZED STRUCTURES THAT IS CLOSELY ASSOCIATED WITH THE SAN ANDREAS FAULT (SAF) AND CALAVERAS FAULT (CF) JUNCTION LOCATED ALONG THE RAPIDLY URBANIZING STATE HWY 152 CORRIDOR. THE QSF IS INCLUDED IN THE EXISTING STATE WIDE SEISMIC SOURCE MODEL (UNIFORM CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE FORECAST   UCERF3  FIELD ET AL., 2013), AND THE UNDERLYING STATEWIDE COMMUNITY FAULT MODEL (SCFM) THAT USES POORLY CONSTRAINED INFORMATION ON THE QSF. FOR EXAMPLE, THESE MODELS USE A SLIP RATE OF 0.2 TO 1 MM YR, DESPITE LIMITED INFORMATION ON THE RECENCY, TIMING, AND RECURRENCE OF EARTHQUAKES FOR THE QSF, AND LITTLE TO NO AVAILABLE GEOLOGIC SLIP RATE INFORMATION (DAWSON AND WELDON, 2013). FURTHER, THIS SLIP RATE IS AN ESTIMATE DERIVED FROM VERTICAL DISPLACEMENT OF LATE QUATERNARY ALLUVIAL DEPOSITS, DESPITE ABUNDANT EVIDENCE OF DOMINANT RIGHT LATERAL STRIKE SLIP MOTION FOR THE QSF. THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH AIMS TO REFINED THESE UNDERLYING PARAMETERS FOR THE QSF, AND IF SUCCESSFUL, THESE RESULTS COULD PROVIDE THE FIRST INFORMATION ON THE LATE QUATERNARY PALEOSEISMIC HISTORY OF EARTHQUAKES FOR THE QSF, INCLUDING POTENTIAL EVENT TIMING AND VALUABLE FAULT CHARACTERIZATION DATA FOR INPUT TO UCERF3 AND FUTURE CALIFORNIA STATEWIDE FAULT MODELS. THIS RESEARCH BUILDS ON INITIAL PILOT WORK, ALSO FUNDED BY THE USGS EHP PROGRAM (AWARD  G21AP10015   BLOSZIES AND BALDWIN, 2022), THAT PERFORMED QUATERNARY GEOLOGIC AND GEOMORPHIC MAPPING OF THE QSF AND (1) REFINED THE LOCATION OF MULTIPLE POTENTIAL HOLOCENE ACTIVE FAULT STRANDS, (2) IDENTIFIED MULTIPLE POTENTIAL PALEOSEISMIC SITES, AND (3) PROVIDED KEY INFORMATION ON THE POTENTIAL STRUCTURAL CONNECTION BETWEEN THE SAF AND CF. TO ACHIEVE THE STATED GOALS OF THIS STUDY, ONE TO TWO FAULT NORMAL TRENCHES WILL BE EXCAVATED AT THE SAMARKAND RANCH SITE, A PALEOSEISMIC SITE HIGHLY RANKED BY BLOSZIES AND BALDWIN (2022). THIS LOCATION EXHIBITS PROMINENT TECTONIC GEOMORPHOLOGY ASSOCIATED WITH THE QSF AND HOLOCENE SEDIMENTATION THAT WILL LIKELY AID IN RECORDING FAULT ACTIVITY AND EVENT TIMING INFORMATION. THE GEOLOGIC DATA COLLECTED FROM TRENCHES WILL HELP INFORM PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD MODELS (E.G. UCERF) THAT INCORPORATE THE QSF, AND WHICH RELY ON EARTHQUAKE TIMING AND SLIP RATE DATA. CURRENTLY, THERE IS NO INFORMATION ON THE MOST BASIC NEEDS OF EARTHQUAKE FORECASTING FOR THE QSF, SUCH AS HOLOCENE ACTIVITY AND AGE OF THE MOST RECENT EVENT (MRE)  INFORMATION THAT IS IMPORTANT TO ADDRESSING THE ROLE OF THE QSF IN THE CF AND SAF JUNCTION. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   1. PERFORM LIMITED, SITE SPECIFIC GEOLOGIC MAPPING TO BEST LOCATE PALEOSEISMIC TRENCHES.2. EXCAVATE TWO TRENCHES AND INTERPRET EXPOSED SEDIMENTS, SAMPLING FOR AGE ANALYSES WHERE POSSIBLE.3. REVIEW TRENCH INTERPRETATIONS WITH SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS.4. SUBMIT SAMPLES FOR LAB ANALYSIS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY COMPILING FINDINGS FROM FIELD EFFORT.5. PREPARE FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT (FTR), PREPARE DATA DELIVERABLES, AND DISSEMINATE FINDINGS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE DATA GENERATED FROM TRENCH EXPOSURES, INCLUDING PHOTOMOSAICS, GRAPHICAL LOGS, MAPS, AND RESULTS OF GEOCHRONOLOGICAL ANALYSIS. ALL DELIVERABLES WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE FTR. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES   DATA DERIVED FROM THESE INVESTIGATIONS SHOULD BE USEFUL TO RESEARCHERS IN THE FIELDS OF SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND PALEOSEISMOLOGY WITHIN THE SFBA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES   N A

PROJECT TITLE    TECTONIC GEOMORPHIC MAPPING, GEOCHRONOLOGY, AND STRUCTURAL MODELING OF QUATERNARY ACTIVE FAULTS IN THE SANTA MARIA BASIN, SAN LOUIS OBISPO AND SANTA BARBARA COUNTIES CALIFORNIA  COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY LONG BEACH AND LETTIS CONSULTANTS INTERNATIONAL, INC.PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  4 1 2023 THROUGH 3 31 2024AWARD PURPOSE   THE WESTERN TRANSVERSE RANGES (WTR) IS A RAPIDLY DEFORMING MOUNTAIN BELT WITH SEVERAL ACTIVE FAULTS, WHICH POSE A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO METROPOLITAN AREAS IN SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL CALIFORNIA. SUBSTANTIAL GEOLOGIC WORK HAS BEEN DONE TO DETERMINE HOW FAST FAULTS ALONG THE SOUTHERN FRONT OF THE WTR ARE BUILDING UP STRESS AND HOW THEY INTERACT, BUT THIS HAS NOT BEEN ADDRESSED FOR FAULTS TO THE NORTH, WITHIN THE SANTA MARIA BASIN (SMB). GPS AND GEOLOGIC DATA SUGGEST SIGNIFICANT RATES OF ACTIVE SHORTENING ACROSS FAULTS IN THE SANTA MARIA BASIN, HOWEVER LARGE UNCERTAINTIES EXIST REGARDING THEIR STRUCTURAL CHARACTER, SLIP RATE, AND INTERCONNECTIVITY. THIS RESEARCH AIMS TO DETERMINE THE GEOMETRY, KINEMATICS AND STRAIN RATE OF MAJOR FAULTS IN THE SANTA MARIA BASIN. TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY, DETAILED GEOMORPHIC MAPPING, DOCUMENTATION OF FAULT OFFSET, AND LUMINESCENCE AGE DATING WILL BE PERFORMED AT SEA CLIFF EXPOSURES OF THE LIONS HEAD AND SANTA YNEZ RIVER FAULTS. THESE DATA WILL BE COMBINED WITH A PUBLISHED DATABASE OF DATED LATE QUATERNARY DEPOSITS AND SUBSURFACE DATA IN THE WTR TO PRODUCE FOUR, SPATIALLY DISTRIBUTED CROSS SECTIONS THAT INCORPORATE KINEMATIC FAULT MODELING. THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE UPDATED AND IMPROVED FAULT CHARACTERIZATION WITH NEW  AGE DATA FOR OFFSET LATE PLEISTOCENE  HOLOCENE SURFACES ACROSS THE FOUR MAJOR FAULTS LOCATED WITHIN THE SMB. THIS WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF REGIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   1. PERFORM SITE SPECIFIC GEOMORPHIC AND QUATERNARY GEOLOGIC MAPPING.2. DOCUMENT FAULT EXPOSURES AT EACH SITE AND INTERPRET EXPOSED SOILS SEDIMENTS AND OFFSETS, SAMPLING FOR LUMINESCENCE DATING.3. ANALYZE SAMPLES IN THE CSULB LUMINESCENCE LAB WHILE CONCURRENTLY INTEGRATING NEW GEOMORPHIC AND QUATERNARY GEOLOGIC DATA TO EXISTING DATASET.4. COMPILE SURFICIAL MAPPING AND FIELD MEASUREMENTS WITH SUBSURFACE DATA TO DEVELOP FOUR CROSS SECTIONS WITH 2D KINEMATIC FAULT MODELS OF REGIONAL LATE QUATERNARY DEFORMATION.5. PREPARE FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT (FTR), PREPARE DATA DELIVERABLES, AND DISSEMINATE FINDINGS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   THREE PRIMARY DELIVERABLES WILL BE GENERATED BY THIS STUDY  (1) QUATERNARY GEOLOGIC FAULT MAPS THAT WILL INCLUDE NEW SEDIMENTARY DATES AND FAULT SLIP RATE RATES AS WELL AS OUR COLLECTION OF PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED UPLIFT RATES FROM THE WTR IN A GIS BASED FORMAT (2) LOGS OF NATURAL FAULT EXPOSURES, INCLUDING PHOTOMOSAICS AND FAULT SLIP MEASUREMENTS (3) GEOLOCATED STRUCTURAL MODELS FOR INTEGRATION WITH COMMUNITY FAULT MODELS. DELIVERABLES WILL BE REPORTED INCLUDED IN THE FTR. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES   DATA DERIVED FROM THESE INVESTIGATIONS WILL BE USEFUL TO RESEARCHERS IN THE FIELDS OF SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND PALEOSEISMOLOGY IN SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL CALIFORNIA AND WILL BE IMPERATIVE FOR THE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES TO BETTER EVALUATE THE REGIONAL FAULT HAZARDS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES   N A

PROJECT TITLE  INVESTIGATING ACCESS AND BARRIERS TO USE OF THE SAN DIEGO EMERGENCY APP FOR SHAKEALERT THROUGH A MULTI METHODS APPROACH  COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH MIAMI UNIVERSITY AND THE EARTHSCOPE CONSORTIUMPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  3 15 2023 THROUGH 3 14 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY  TO DEVELOP MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY (LEP) INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES AROUND THE SHAKEALERT EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING (EEW) SYSTEM. LEP HOUSEHOLDS HAVE NO MEMBER AGED 14  THAT SPEAKS ONLY ENGLISH OR SPEAKS ENGLISH  VERY WELL . ACTIVITIES  PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE FORMULATION OF FOCUS GROUPS AND SURVEY QUESTIONS IN COLLABORATION WITH THE SDC OES AND THE USGS SHAKEALERT SOCIAL SCIENCE WORKING GROUP. AFTER THE QUESTIONS HAVE BEEN VETTED BY THE WORKING GROUP AND UNDERGONE INSTITUTIONAL REVIEW BOARD APPROVAL AT MIAMI UNIVERSITY, THE PIS WILL CONDUCT SEVERAL FOCUS GROUP MEETINGS IN SAN DIEGO WITH THE PARTNER RELAY COMMUNICATION NETWORK. ONCE DATA COLLECTION IS COMPLETE, WE WILL USE QUALITATIVE CODING TECHNIQUES, SUCH AS CONTENT ANALYSIS, TO ANALYZE THE DATA AND DISSEMINATE OUR RESULTS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES, COMMUNITY FORUMS, AND IN ACADEMIC PUBLICATIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS BARRIERS AND CHALLENGES TO BOTH RECEIPT AND COMPREHENSION OF SHAKEALERT POWERED ALERTS, WITH A FOCUS ON LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY (LEP) COMMUNITIES IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY. THE GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO IMPROVE ADOPTION RATES OF THE SD EMERGENCY APP FOR USE AND DISSEMINATION OF SHAKEALERT EEW. IN WORKING WITH PARTNER RELAY, WE WILL DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF POTENTIAL ACCESS, LANGUAGE, CULTURAL, AND TECHNOLOGICAL BARRIERS TO EEW BROADLY. WE WILL SHARE OUR FINDINGS WITH OTHER SHAKEALERT APP PROVIDERS AND THE USGS JOINT COMMITTEE FOR COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, OUTREACH AND TECHNICAL ENGAGEMENT TO INFORM FUTURE EFFORTS FOR INCREASING INCLUSIVITY OF EEW.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  SAN DIEGO COUNTY IS HOME TO A DIVERSE POPULATION OF OVER 3.3 MILLION PEOPLE (SERVING 6  OF THE POPULATION COVERED BY SHAKEALERT EEW) THAT IS 34  HISPANIC LATINX AND OVER 12  ASIAN, AND 37  OF THE POPULATION ARE NON ENGLISH SPEAKERS AS A FIRST LANGUAGE (U.S. CENSUS BUREAU, 2021). GIVEN THE DEMOGRAPHICS, SDC PROVIDES AN IDEAL LOCATION IN WHICH TO TEST THE EFFICACY OF SHAKEALERT POWERED ALERTS WITH A DIVERSE GROUP OF PEOPLE. ALERTS PROVIDED THROUGH THE SD EMERGENCY APP ARE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH, SPANISH, AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE, AND ENGLISH AUDIO TRANSLATIONS. THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO PROVIDE THE USGS WITH KEY INFORMATION ON HOW BEST TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF SHAKEALERT EEW AND BROADEN THE REACH OF SHAKEALERT WITHIN SAN DIEGO COUNTY AND CALIFORNIA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE SDC OES IS A SUBRECIPIENT (SUBCONTRACTOR) AND WILL INCORPORATE SILENT ALERT TESTING TO ASSESS ENGAGEMENT AND CONNECTION WITH APP USERS. SILENT ALERT TESTING WILL PING USER PHONES  BEHIND THE SCENES  TO GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT WHO RECEIVED AN ALERT AND WHERE. SILENT ALERT TESTING WILL ENABLE US TO  1) ASSESS ATTRITION RATES THROUGH APP DOWNLOAD AND DELETION STATISTICS  2) MORE CLEARLY IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC GAPS IN ALERTING  AND 3) COMPARE THE RESULTS WITH DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND CHARACTERIZE COMMUNITIES WHERE THE APP IS LESS UTILIZED. WE WILL SEEK TO USE SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS IN COMMUNITIES WITH LOW APP UTILIZATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND USAGE GAPS WITH EEW APPS AND ANY BARRIERS TO APP RETENTION, WHICH WOULD LIMIT THE USEFULNESS OF SHAKEALERT POWERED ALERTS.
