WE WILL SHARE OUR FINDINGS WITH OTHER SHAKEALERT APP PROVIDERS AND THE USGS JOINT COMMITTEE FOR COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, OUTREACH AND TECHNICAL ENGAGEMENT TO INFORM FUTURE EFFORTS FOR INCREASING INCLUSIVITY OF EEW.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  SAN DIEGO COUNTY IS HOME TO A DIVERSE POPULATION OF OVER 3.3 MILLION PEOPLE (SERVING 6  OF THE POPULATION COVERED BY SHAKEALERT EEW) THAT IS 34  HISPANIC LATINX AND OVER 12  ASIAN, AND 37  OF THE POPULATION ARE NON ENGLISH SPEAKERS AS A FIRST LANGUAGE (U.S. CENSUS BUREAU, 2021). GIVEN THE DEMOGRAPHICS, SDC PROVIDES AN IDEAL LOCATION IN WHICH TO TEST THE EFFICACY OF SHAKEALERT POWERED ALERTS WITH A DIVERSE GROUP OF PEOPLE. ALERTS PROVIDED THROUGH THE SD EMERGENCY APP ARE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH, SPANISH, AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE, AND ENGLISH AUDIO TRANSLATIONS. THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO PROVIDE THE USGS WITH KEY INFORMATION ON HOW BEST TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF SHAKEALERT EEW AND BROADEN THE REACH OF SHAKEALERT WITHIN SAN DIEGO COUNTY AND CALIFORNIA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE SDC OES IS A SUBRECIPIENT (SUBCONTRACTOR) AND WILL INCORPORATE SILENT ALERT TESTING TO ASSESS ENGAGEMENT AND CONNECTION WITH APP USERS. SILENT ALERT TESTING WILL PING USER PHONES BEHIND THE SCENES TO GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT WHO RECEIVED AN ALERT AND WHERE. SILENT ALERT TESTING WILL ENABLE US TO  1) ASSESS ATTRITION RATES THROUGH APP DOWNLOAD AND DELETION STATISTICS  2) MORE CLEARLY IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC GAPS IN ALERTING  AND 3) COMPARE THE RESULTS WITH DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND CHARACTERIZE COMMUNITIES WHERE THE APP IS LESS UTILIZED. WE WILL SEEK TO USE SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS IN COMMUNITIES WITH LOW APP UTILIZATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND USAGE GAPS WITH EEW APPS AND ANY BARRIERS TO APP RETENTION, WHICH WOULD LIMIT THE USEFULNESS OF SHAKEALERT POWERED ALERTS.

TITLE  CONSTRAINING COSEISMIC SURFACE DISPLACEMENT AND FAULT SLIP FROM TOPOGRAPHIC DIFFERENCING FOR THE 1983 M6.9 BORAH PEAK, IDAHO, EARTHQUAKEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  3 1 2023 THROUGH 2 29 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION  THE M6.9 1983 BORAH PEAK, IDAHO, EARTHQUAKE RUPTURED 35 KM OF THE LOST RIVER FAULT IN ONE OF THE LARGEST RECENT OBLIQUE NORMAL FAULT EARTHQUAKES IN THE UNITED STATES. THE 2015 INTERMOUNTAIN WEST WORKSHOP IDENTIFIED THE LOST RIVER FAULT AS THE TOP OF FIVE FAULTS OF CONCERN FOR IDAHO BASED ON THE HAZARD, THE RISK POSED TO NEARBY POPULATIONS, AND THE POTENTIAL FOR NEW SCIENCE. THE LOST RIVER FAULT IS CONSIDERED HAZARDOUS DUE TO ITS QUATERNARY SLIP RATE OF   0.2 TO 0.3 MM YR AND THE 2.6 M PEAK VERTICAL DISPLACEMENT AT THE EARTH S SURFACE IN THE 1983 EARTHQUAKE. IDAHO NATIONAL LABS IS A CRITICAL NATIONAL FACILITY AS THE NATION S LEADER IN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND IS LOCATED 140 KM FROM THE 1983 RUPTURE. THE NEW AVAILABILITY OF HIGH RESOLUTION TOPOGRAPHY DATA FROM BEFORE AND AFTER THE M6.9 1983 BORAH PEAK EARTHQUAKE PRESENTS A CRITICAL OPPORTUNITY TO APPLY NEW GEODETIC TECHNIQUES TO RESOLVE THE COSEISMIC DEFORMATION FIELD AND GAIN A NEW UNDERSTANDING OF FAULT BEHAVIOR IN THE EARTH S CRUST. THE RESEARCHERS WILL RESOLVE THE NEAR  AND FAR FIELD VERTICAL COSEISMIC DEFORMATION FIELD AND SOLVE FOR THE DISTRIBUTED FAULT SLIP THROUGHOUT THE SEISMOGENIC ZONE FOR THE 1983 BORAH PEAK EARTHQUAKE. THE RESEARCHERS WILL PERFORM VERTICAL DIFFERENCING AT THE METER SCALE BASED ON TOPOGRAPHY MEASURED FROM PRE EARTHQUAKE AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHS AND POST EARTHQUAKE LIDAR TOPOGRAPHY COLLECTED IN 2020 THROUGH THE USGS S 3D ELEVATION PROGRAM. BECAUSE THE EARTHQUAKE OCCURRED BEFORE THE COLLECTION OF MODERN GEODETIC DATASETS, THE PROCESSING WILL BE CHALLENGING, AND THE RESEARCHERS WILL EXPLORE METHODS TO IMPROVE THE GEOREFERENCING AND REMOVE VEGETATION. FOR THE EARTHQUAKE SOURCE INVERSION, THE FAULT PLANE WILL SPAN THE THOUSAND SPRING AND WARM SPRING FAULT SEGMENTS AS WELL AS THE TRANS BASIN WILLOW CREEK HILLS. THE RESEARCHERS WILL EXPLORE SEVERAL FAULT GEOMETRIES INCLUDING A PLANAR AND LISTRIC FAULT. THE RESEARCHERS WILL EXAMINE VARIATIONS IN SLIP ALONG STRIKE AND WITH DEPTH, AND IN PARTICULAR, THE MAGNITUDE AND DEPTH OF THE MAXIMUM SLIP AND VARIATIONS IN SLIP ALONG SEGMENT BOUNDARIES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE RESEARCHERS WILL CONSTRAIN (1) ON  AND OFF  FAULT DEFORMATION, (2) SLIP VARIATIONS AT FAULT SEGMENT BOUNDARIES, AND (3) THE FAULT GEOMETRY FOR THE BASIN BOUNDING FAULT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE VERTICAL CHANGE DEFORMATION FIELD AND THE SLIP INVERSION RESULTS (FAULT PLANE, SLIP MAGNITUDE AND  UNCERTAINTY) WILL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE WITH THE PUBLICATION OF THE WORK. THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE A COSEISMIC DEFORMATION FIELD AND DISTRIBUTED SLIP INVERSION FOR ONE THE LARGEST NORMAL FAULT EARTHQUAKES IN THE UNITED STATES THAT WAS RECORDED GEODETICALLY. THE WORK WILL ADVANCE THE USE OF GEODETIC METHODS TO RESOLVE CRUSTAL DEFORMATION FOR CHALLENGING OLDER EARTHQUAKES. THE CHANGE MAP WILL SUPPORT MEASURING COSEISMIC SLIP WITHOUT THE IMPACT OF EARLIER EARTHQUAKES OR EROSIONAL GRADIENTS THAT LIKELY AFFECT SLIP MEASUREMENTS MADE FROM PURELY POST EARTHQUAKE OBSERVATIONS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THE USGS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS WORKING IN SEISMIC HAZARD OF THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  NONE

PROJECT TITLE:  USING REPEATING FORESHOCKS AS CREEP METERS AT DEPTH TO TEST AN ASEISMIC PRE-SLIP MODEL FOR SOMELARGE EARTHQUAKESPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 5 1 2023 THROUGH 4 30 2024AWARD PURPOSE:  AN UNANSWERED QUESTION IS HOW DO LARGE EARTHQUAKES INITIATE AND CAN THEIR NUCLEATION PROCESS BE DISTINGUISHED FROM SMALL EARTHQUAKES  THE EXISTENCE OF FORESHOCKS BEFORE SOME LARGE EARTHQUAKES IS ONE OF THE BEST DOCUMENTED OBSERVABLES PRECEDING MAINSHOCKS AND THEREFORE MAY OFFER CLUES INTO THESE PROCESSES. THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED WORK IS TO TEST THE HYPOTHESIS USING THE SCIENTIFIC METHOD THAT FOR SOME LARGE EARTHQUAKES ASEISMIC PRE-SLIP OCCURS ON THE FAULT SURFACE AS A NUCLEATION PHASE OR STATICALLY LOADING AND TRIGGERING THE MAINSHOCK.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE REPEATING EARTHQUAKES WILL BE COMPARED TO THE INTERSECTION OF EVENTS IN A CATALOG OF FORESHOCK MAINSHOCK SEQUENCES FOR ALL OF NORTHERN CALIFORNIA WITH MAINSHOCK MAGNITUDES GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO 4. CERTAIN WELL-DEFINED PREDICTIONS OF THE ASEISMIC PRE-SLIP AND CASCADE MODELS WILL BE EXAMINED. THESE INCLUDE NINE TESTS THAT WOULD SHOW EVIDENCE IN SUPPORT OF THE HYPOTHESIS OR NOT SUCH AS THE FOLLOWING: ARE REPEATING FORESHOCKS PRESENT BEFORE LARGE EARTHQUAKES INDICATING ASEISMIC SLIP SURROUNDING ASPERITIES  IF PRESENT IS THE SLIP ACCELERATING  IF THE SLIP RATE INCREASES WHAT IS ITS DURATION AND TIME HISTORY  IS THERE A MIGRATIONOR LOCALIZATION IN SPACE OF HYPOCENTERS SHOWING SLIP CLOSE TO THE MAINSHOCK HYPOCENTER AS TIME APPROACHES  OR ALTERNATIVELY IS THE ZONE ENCLOSING THE FORESHOCK HYPOCENTERS FARTHER AWAY IN SPACE AND TIME FROM THE MAINSHOCK HYPOCENTER  DOES THE SIZE OF THE FORESHOCK ZONE SCALE WITH MAINSHOCK SEISMIC MOMENT  IS THERE A DIFFERENCE IN THE SLIP BEHAVIORS AND PRESENCE OF REPEATING FORESHOCKS FOR DIFFERENT TECTONIC REGIONS  WHAT PERCENTAGES OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES DEMONSTRATE THESE BEHAVIORS  SEVERAL ISOLATED CASE STUDIES FOR SOME LARGE EARTHQUAKES HAVE ALREADY DEMONSTRATED  SUCCESS IN FINDING REPEATING FORESHOCKS IN SUPPORT OF THE ASEISMIC PRE-SLIP MODEL. THIS PROJECT WILL DO IT ON A MUCH BROADER SCALE FOR MANY MORE MAINSHOCKS AND DIFFERENT TECTONIC ENVIRONMENTSTHAT ARE PRESENT IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA. THIS WILL HELP TO UNDERSTAND HOW UBIQUITOUS THE ASEISMIC PRE-SLIP PHENOMENON OBSERVED IN THE ISOLATED CASE STUDIES IS AND TO QUANTIFY THE STATISTICS OF IT FOR A BROAD REGION IMPORTANT FOR SEISMIC HAZARD IN THE UNITED STATES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A DELIVERABLE WILL BE TO EXPAND A REPEATING FORESHOCK CATALOG ON A LARGE SCALE. IT IS STILL NOT KNOWN HOW LARGE EARTHQUAKES INITIATE AND THEREFORE IT IS IMPORTANT TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE AND INSIGHT INTO THE PHYSICAL PROCESSES FOR FORESHOCK OCCURRENCE AND DETERMINE IF THEY ARE DIFFERENT THAN OTHER EARTHQUAKES. FORESHOCKS ARE THE MOST OBVIOUS AND WELL RECORDED PRECURSORS TO SOME LARGE EARTHQUAKES. IT IS ESSENTIAL TO UNDERSTAND THE PHYSICAL MECHANISMS FOR THEIR OCCURRENCE. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE IMPLICATIONS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL BEAR DIRECTLY ON THE QUESTION OF EARTHQUAKE PREDICTABILITY, THUS HAVING BROAD IMPACT AND INTEREST, BUT ESPECIALLY AMONG HAZARD FORECASTING ANALYSTS, GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES, AND POLICY MAKERS.SUBRECIPIENTS: N A

PROJECT TITLE: TOWARD MULTISCALE EVALUATIONS OF LATERAL SPREADING: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY, AND BUCKNELL UNIVERSITYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 5 16 2023 THROUGH 5 15 204PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY: LIQUEFACTION-INDUCED LATERAL SPREADING OCCURS WHEN LOSS OF SHEAR STRENGTH MAKES SOIL ACT AS A LIQUID, CAUSING GROUND FAILURES SUCH AS SURFACE CRACKS AND LANDSLIDES. THESE LIQUEFACTION-INDUCED LATERAL DISPLACEMENTS (LDS) REPRESENT A MAJOR GEOHAZARD IN EARTHQUAKE-PRONE REGIONS LEADING TO SIGNIFICANT HUMAN AND ECONOMIC LOSSES. CURRENT PREDICTIVE MODELS ONLY FOCUS ON GEOTECHNICAL (I.E., SUBSURFACE CHARACTERIZATION) AND SEISMOLOGICAL CONSIDERATIONS (I.E., GROUND MOTION INTENSITY), AND DO NOT EXPLICITLY ACCOUNT FOR GEOLOGIC FEATURES THAT CAN CONTROL LATERAL GROUND DEFORMATIONS, EVEN THOUGH GEOLOGIC CONDITIONS PLAY A CRUCIAL ROLE IN LIQUEFACTION OCCURRENCE, SEVERITY AND SPATIAL EXTENT. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO FILL THIS GAP BY DEVELOPING A MODEL THAT INCORPORATES RELEVANT GEOMORPHIC (I.E., SURFICIAL GEOLOGIC) VARIABLES IN LATERAL SPREADING ESTIMATION. GEOMORPHIC VARIABLES CAPTURE THE SURFICIAL PROCESSES AND ENVIRONMENTS THAT IMPACT LIQUEFACTION-PRONE SEDIMENTS, AND THEY CAN OFTEN BE ASSESSED FROM PUBLICLY AVAILABLE REMOTE SENSING DATA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PROPOSED PROJECT PLAN ADDRESSES THESE CRITICAL NEEDS AND INCLUDES A TASK 0, WHICH REFERS TO WORK ALREADY COMPLETED BY THE PI AND CO-PIS AND THAT WILL INFORM THREE NEW TASKS:DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO IMPROVE REGIONAL-SCALE ESTIMATES OF LDS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW PREDICTIVE MODEL THAT CAN BE USED FOR LD RISK MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING BY GOVERNMENTAL GEOHAZARDS AGENCIES. SPECIFIC DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROPOSAL INCLUDE: (1) A NEW EMPIRICAL PREDICTIVE MODEL OF LDS THAT INCLUDES GEOMORPHIC VARIABLES, (2) A NEW CURATED ELECTRONIC DATABASE OF LDS AND ASSOCIATED GEOTECHNICAL, GEOMORPHIC, AND GROUND MOTION METADATA, AND (3) ADVANCES TOWARD IMPROVED REGIONAL-SCALE GROUND FAILURE HAZARD ASSESSMENTS USING SITE-SPECIFIC AND GEOSPATIAL DATAINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: PUBLIC SOCIETY AT LARGE WILL BENEFIT FROM REDUCED SEISMIC RISK AND CONSEQUENCES FROM EARTHQUAKE INDUCED GEOHAZARDS AS A RESULT OF THIS STUDY. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROPOSED GEOSPATIAL ANALYTICS FRAMEWORK COULD BE USED TO INVESTIGATE OTHER GEOHAZARDS AT MULTIPLE SCALES, WHICH WOULD DIRECTLY BENEFIT RESEARCHERS, PRACTITIONERS AND ACADEMICS CURRENTLY STUDYING LANDSLIDES, SITE RESPONSE, AND LIQUEFACTION TRIGGERING. LIKEWISE, THE NEXT GENERATIONS OF STUDENTS AND EARLY CAREER PROFESSIONALS WILL BENEFIT FROM CURATED AND WELL DOCUMENTED CASE STUDIES THAT CAN BE USED TO ADVANCE THE STATE OF THE ART IN LATERAL SPREADING.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N A

PROJECT TITLE DATA DRIVEN ANALYSES OF DAS FOR EEWPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  2 15 2023 THROUGH 2 14 2024PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY   EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING GIVES PEOPLE PRECIOUS TIME TO RESPOND TO INCOMING EARTHQUAKE SHAKING.  ITS ACCURACY DEPENDS ON THE NUMBER OF SENSORS AVAILABLE NEAR THE EARTHQUAKE BEING WARNED ABOUT.  INCREASING SENSOR DENSITY IS EXPENSIVE FOR CONVENTIONAL INSTRUMENTATION, SO THIS PROJECT LOOKS INTO  A NEW TECHNOLOGY THAT TURN PRE EXISTING FIBER OPTIC CABLES INTO SEISMIC SENSORS. THESE ARE THE SAME  CABLES THAT PROVIDE HIGH SPEED INTERNET TO OUR COMMUNITIES. THE FIBER SENSING TECHNOLOGY HAS BEEN  USED FOR MANY DIFFERENT RESEARCH APPLICATIONS, BUT NOT FOR EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING YET, BECAUSE  OF CHALLENGES IN CALIBRATING THE MEASURED AMPLITUDES. IN THIS PROJECT, THE FIRST STEP WILL BE TAKEN TO  CALIBRATE THE FIBER SENSING AMPLITUDES, SO THAT IT WILL BE POSSIBLE TO INTEGRATE THEM INTO EARTHQUAKE  EARLY WARNING IN THE FUTURE. FAST COMPUTER PROGRAMS WILL ALSO BE DEVELOPED TO PROCESS FIBER SENSING  DATA EFFICIENTLY, IN ORDER TO MEET THE SPEED REQUIREMENT OF EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   PUBLICATIONS THAT SUMMARIZE THE FINDINGS ABOUT WHETHER DISTRIBUTED ACOUSTIC SENSING IS A  SUITABLE TECHNOLOGY FOR EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING, AS WELL AS PATHWAYS TOWARDS BROAD  APPLICATIONS OF DISTRIBUTED ACOUSTIC SENSING IN EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING. COMPUTER PROGRAMS  THAT CAN DEMONSTRATE HOW TO APPLY DISTRIBUTED ACOUSTIC SENSING IN EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING, IN  PARTICULAR  RAPID EARTHQUAKE DETECTION, LOCATION, AND MAGNITUDE ESTIMATION.INTENDED BENEFICIARY   UNITED STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, WHICH IS RESPONSE FOR DEVELOPING, MAINTAINING, AND IMPROVING  THE EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING SYSTEM  OTHER RESEARCHERS WHO WANTS TO EXPLORE DISTRIBUTED  ACOUSTIC SENSING IN EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING  GENERAL PUBLIC WHO MAY BENEFIT FROM THE FASTER  AND MORE ACCURATE EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING USING THE FIBER SENSING TECHNOLOGY.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  THE PI AND A POSTDOC RESEARCHER AT CALTECH WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE DAS DATA COLLECTED BY THE  PI S TEAM IN RIDGECREST, OWENS LAKE, LONG VALLEY, AND OFFSHORE CASCADIA AREAS TO EVALUATE DAS  FOR EEW SYSTEMATICALLY. THE FINDINGS WILL BE PRESENTED IN ACADEMIC CONFERENCES, PUBLISHED IN  PEER REVIEWED JOURNALS, AND SUMMARIZED IN THE FINAL GRANT REPORT.

PROJECT TITLE REGIONALIZATION OF EARTHQUAKE SOURCE AND GROUND MOTION MODELS OF SUBDUCTION INTERFACE EARTHQUAKES PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE 1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023AWARD PURPOSE IN SKARLATOUDIS ET AL (2016  SEA16), RECIPIENT DEVELOPED A SET OF GLOBAL SCALING RELATIONS, WITH SEISMIC MOMENT(M0), OF PHYSICAL SOURCE PROPERTIES SUCH AS EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE AREA (S), TOTAL ASPERITY AREA (SA), SLIP (D),AND FAULT WIDTH (W), FOR LARGE SUBDUCTION INTERFACE EVENTS. THE RESULTING SET OF RELATIONS SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCED THE ALEATORY VARIABILITY IN THE PREDICTION OF THESE SOURCE PARAMETERS. SINCE THE PUBLICATION OF THIS WORK, RESEARCHERS AND INSTITUTES WORLDWIDE HAVE BEEN USING THESE SCALING RELATIONS TO PREDICT GROUND MOTIONS AND TSUNAMIS FROM GREAT SUBDUCTION EARTHQUAKES FOR VARIOUS APPLICATIONS (E.G. US NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS  NSHM). IN THE TIME SINCE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE DATABASE USED IN SEA16, 79 ADDITIONAL SUBDUCTION INTERFACE EVENTS WITH PUBLISHED FINITE FAULT SOLUTIONS HAVE BEEN CATALOGUED IN THE USGS FINITE FAULT DATABASE, THE ONLINE DATABASE OF FINITE FAULT RUPTURE MODELS (MAI AND THINGBAIJAM, 2014), AND THE NEXT GENERATION ATTENUATION SUBDUCTION (NGA SUB) DATABASE, NEARLY TREBLING THE AVAILABLE DATA. IN THE RECIPIENTS SEARCH FOR SUBDUCTION INTERFACE EVENTS, THEY USE THE SLAB2.0 (HAYES, 2018) SUBDUCTION ZONE GEOMETRIES. MOREOVER, AS PART OF THE NGA SUB, STRONG REGIONAL DIFFERENCES IN THE GROUND MOTIONS EXPECTED FROM VARIOUS SUBDUCTIONZONES HAVE BEEN QUANTIFIED. THE OBSERVED REGIONALIZATION OF GROUND MOTIONS IS LIKELY THE RESULT OF DIFFERENCES IN THE GEOLOGICAL, GEOMETRICAL, AND MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF THE PLATE INTERFACE AND THE KINEMATIC AND DYNAMIC PROCESSES OF MEGATHRUST RUPTURE GENERATION IN EACH REGION (E.G. CAMPBELL, 2020 HEURET ET AL., 2011  SCHAFER AND WENZEL, 2019  AND SCHELLART AND RAWLINSON, 2013). ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  AUGMENT THE EXISTING DATABASE OF SUBDUCTION INTERFACE EVENTS WITH THE ADDITIONAL MODELS THAT BECAME AVAILABLE IN RECENT YEARS AND UPDATE SET OF GLOBAL SCALING RELATIONS  DOING SO WILL IMPROVE THE PREDICTIONS OF THE VARIOUS SOURCE PROPERTIES AND FURTHER MINIMIZE THE ASSOCIATED UNCERTAINTIES. MOREOVER, FOR THE SUBDUCTION ZONES WITH ADEQUATE NUMBER OF EARTHQUAKES IN THE DATABASE, DEVELOP REGIONALIZED SCALING RELATIONS AND SEEK PHYSICAL EXPLANATIONS FOR THE OBSERVED REGIONAL DIFFERENCES INSUBDUCTION INTERFACE GROUND MOTIONS BY SEARCHING FOR CORRELATIONS WITH THE MANY PARAMETERS THAT WERE CONSIDERED BY SCHELLART AND RAWLINSON (2013), HEURET ET AL. (2011) AND SCHAFER AND WENZEL (2019).DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS AN IMPORTANT NEED BY IMPROVING MODELS FOR SUBDUCTION EARTHQUAKE GROUNDMOTIONS THAT EMBODY REGIONAL VARIATION IN EARTHQUAKE SOURCE CHARACTERISTICS. THE PRODUCTS THAT THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE ARE  (1) GLOBAL AND REGIONALIZED SOURCE SCALING RELATIONS OF SUBDUCTION EARTHQUAKES  (2) EVIDENCE PROVIDING A PHYSICAL BASIS FOR THE OBSERVED VARIATIONS IN REGIONALIZED NGA SUB GROUNDMOTION MODELS FOR INTERFACE EARTHQUAKES  AND (3) PUBLICATION OF SUBDUCTION SOURCE SCALING RELATIONS AND CORRELATIONS BETWEEN PHYSICAL SOURCEPROPERTIES AND REGIONAL GROUND MOTION MODELS IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THESE PRODUCTS WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO MANY HAZARD ANALYSTS AND ENGINEERS, INCLUDING THOSE AT THE USGS, AND WILL IMPROVE OUR CHARACTERIZATION OF SUBDUCTION GROUND MOTIONS AND TSUNAMI GENESIS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  NONE

PROJECT TITLE INVESTIGATING SHEAR STRENGTH PROXIES FOR USE IN REGIONAL SEISMIC LANDSLIDE ASSESSMENTSPEROD OF PERFORMANCE  1 9 2023 THROUGH 1 8 2024DESCRIPTION  SEISMIC LANDSLIDE HAZARD MAPS EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL FOR EARTHQUAKE INDUCED LANDSLIDES. THESE MAPS PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION TO LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, DEVELOPERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC ABOUT SEISMIC LANDSLIDE HAZARDS AND EARTHQUAKE EFFECTS, AND ALSO CAN BE DEVELOPED IMMEDIATELY AFTER AN EARTHQUAKE TO PREDICT ZONES OF EXPECTED LANDSLIDES FOR THAT EARTHQUAKE GIVEN THE GROUND SHAKING INTENSITY PROVIDED BY SHAKEMAP. CRITICAL INPUTS FOR SEISMIC LANDSLIDE MAPS ARE THE SHEAR STRENGTH PARAMETERS OF THE GEOLOGIC MATERIALS. THE SHEAR STRENGTH PARAMETERS ARE ASSIGNED TO THE MAPPED GEOLOGIC UNITS BASED ON A LIMITED AMOUNT OF LABORATORY MEASURED SHEAR STRENGTH DATA, AND A SINGLE SET OF SHEAR STRENGTH PARAMETERS IS ASSIGNED TO EACH GEOLOGIC UNIT. DREYFUS ET AL. (2013) DEMONSTRATED THAT THE SPATIAL VARIATION IN SHEAR STRENGTH PROPERTIES SHOULD BE INCORPORATED TO MORE ACCURATELY PREDICT EARTHQUAKE INDUCED LANDSLIDES.ACTIVITIES  THIS WORK WILL INVESTIGATE APPROACHES TO MODEL THE SPATIAL VARIATION IN SHEAR STRENGTH WITHIN A GEOLOGIC UNIT AND WILL EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF INCORPORATING SPATIAL VARIATIONS IN SHEAR STRENGTH ON THE PREDICTED LANDSLIDE DISTRIBUTIONS. VARIOUS PROXIES FOR SHEAR STRENGTH WILL BE INVESTIGATED, FROM TOPOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS SUCH AS SLOPE AND SURFACE ROUGHNESS TO SATELLITE REMOTE SENSING PARAMETERS. THE SIX QUADRANGLES THAT EXPERIENCED LANDSLIDES DURING THE NORTHRIDGE EARTHQUAKE WILL BE USED TO INVESTIGATE THE SHEAR STRENGTH PROXIES USING SHEAR STRENGTH DATA FROM THE BOREHOLE DATABASE OF THE CALIFORNIA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. THE INVENTORY OF LANDSLIDES FROM THE NORTHRIDGE EARTHQUAKE WILL THEN BE USED TO EVALUATE THE IMPROVEMENTS IN SEISMIC LANDSLIDE PREDICTIONS WHEN INCORPORATING SPATIAL SHEAR STRENGTH VARIATIONS. SPECIFIC TASKS INCLUDE  (1) INITIAL ANALYSIS OF PREDICTIONS OF NORTHRIDGE LANDSLIDE DISTRIBUTION, (2) COLLECT DATA TO EVALUATE SHEAR STRENGTH PROXIES, (3) IDENTIFY BEST PROXIES FOR SHEAR STRENGTH VARIABILITY, AND (4) COMPUTE LANDSLIDE PREDICTIONS USING SHEAR STRENGTH PROXIES.DELIVERABLES OUTCOMES  THIS RESEARCH WILL IDENTIFY PARAMETERS THAT CAN BE USED TO REPRESENT SPATIAL VARIATIONS IN SHEAR STRENGTH WITHIN GEOLOGIC UNITS FOR SEISMIC LANDSLIDE ASSESSMENT. THESE PARAMETERS WILL BE DERIVED FROM TOPOGRAPHIC AND OR REMOTE SENSING DATA THAT ARE AVAILABLE NATION WIDE, AND CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP FUTURE SEISMIC LANDSLIDE MAPS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THIS WORK RESPONDS DIRECTLY TO THE USGS ENGINEERING SEISMOLOGY AND IMPACTS (ESI) RESEARCH PRIORITY TOPIC RELATED TO ESTIMATION OF THE OCCURRENCE OF GROUND FAILURE (LANDSLIDES) USING MECHANISTIC METHODS THAT ARE APPLICABLE AT REGIONAL SCALES. THUS, BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE USGS AND ALL RESIDENTS LIVING IN AREAS SUSCEPTIBLE TO SEISMIC LANDSLIDES.

PROJECT TITLE TOWARDS A MULTI DECADAL MACHINE LEARNING BASED EARTHQUAKE CATALOG FOR NORTHERN CALIFORNIAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE EARTHQUAKE MONITORING, AND IN PARTICULAR TO IMPROVE THE  ABILITY TO DETECT AND LOCATE SMALL EARTHQUAKES USING MACHINE LEARNING SO THAT A MORE  COMPLETE PICTURE OF EARTHQUAKE ACTIVITY CAN BE OBTAINED. BECAUSE IT IS NOT KNOWN AHEAD OF TIME WHEN EARTHQUAKES  ARE GOING TO HAPPEN, EARTHQUAKE CATALOGS MUST BE DEVELOPED BY ANALYZING GROUND MOTION AT ALL  TIMES. THIS IS DONE BY SEARCHING SEISMOMETER OUTPUT OF GROUND MOTION FOR POSSIBLE SEISMIC WAVES.  OVER THE PAST SEVERAL YEARS, MACHINE LEARNING HAS PROVEN TO BE EXCEPTIONALLY GOOD AT FINDING  SUCH SEISMIC WAVE ARRIVALS  HOWEVER, IT S NOT ENOUGH TO FIND WAVE ARRIVALS BECAUSE WE DON T KNOW  AHEAD OF TIME HOW MANY EARTHQUAKES ARE GENERATING THEM, AND IT IS NOT KNOWN WHERE THOSE  EARTHQUAKES ARE LOCATED. THE PROBLEM IS COMPLICATED BY NOISE IN THE DATA, SUCH AS AUTOMOBILE  TRAFFIC, THAT CAN FOOL ANY MEASUREMENT SYSTEM INTO THINKING A SEISMIC WAVE HAS BEEN RECORDED FROM  AN EARTHQUAKE. TO DEVELOP AN EARTHQUAKE CATALOG, POSSIBLE WAVE ARRIVAL TIMES MUST BE SORTED INTO  THOSE THAT ARE GENERATED BY REAL EARTHQUAKES AND THOSE THAT ARE THE RESULT OF MEASUREMENT ERROR.  THIS PROCESS IS CALLED  ASSOCIATION.  THE RECIPIENT HAS DEVELOPED AN IMPROVED ASSOCIATION METHOD THAT USES A STATE OF THE ART ARTIFICIAL  INTELLIGENCE APPROACH KNOWN AS  GRAPH NEURAL NETWORKS  THAT IS SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO WORK WITH  MEASUREMENTS THAT HAVE THIS CHARACTER. UNDER THIS PROJECT THE RECIPIENT WILL APPLY THIS METHOD TO ALL AVAILABLE CONTINUOUS WAVEFORM DATA FROM THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA SEISMIC NETWORK (NCSN), WHICH DATES  BACK APPROXIMATELY 20 YEARS. THIS SHOULD GIVE A MUCH MORE COMPLETE VIEW OF EARTHQUAKE  ACTIVITY THAN AVAILABLE AT PRESENT. THE FOCUS OF THE INITIAL EFFORT ON THE PERIOD SPANNING THE 2003  SAN SIMEON AND 2004 PARKFIELD EARTHQUAKES. THESE EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCES WILL PROVIDE BOTH  INTERESTING SCIENTIFIC TARGETS AND PROLIFIC AFTERSHOCK SEQUENCES THAT WILL TEST THE EFFECTIVENESS OF OUR  APPROACH.  THE PROJECT HAS TWO LONG TERM GOALS  (1) TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE CATALOG FOR ALL AVAILABLE  CONTINUOUS SEISMIC DATA FROM THE NCSN AND (2) TO WORK TOWARDS USING THESE APPROACHES FOR  IMPROVED REAL TIME EARTHQUAKE MONITORING. THE IMMEDIATE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK WILL BE  EARTHQUAKE SCIENTISTS, WHO WILL GAIN BETTER INSIGHT INTO EARTHQUAKE PROCESSES FROM A MORE COMPLETE  EARTHQUAKE CATALOG. THE EVENTUAL BENEFICIARIES WILL BE BOTH THE PUBLIC AND THE PRIVATE SECTORS, WHO WILL HAVE A BETTER BASIS FOR DECISION MAKING BASEDON AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF EARTHQUAKES.

PROJECT TITLE HIGH PRECISION 3D GRAVITY INVESTIGATION OF THE 2020 MW5.1 SPARTA, NC EPICENTRAL AND AFTERSHOCKZONEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023THE MAGNITUDE 5.1 SPARTA, NC EARTHQUAKE WAS THE LARGEST EASTERN U.S. SHOCK IN THE PAST DECADE, CAUSING AT LEAST  24 MILLION IN DAMAGE AND CREATING THE FIRST OBSERVED SURFACE RUPTURE EAST OF THE MISSISSIPPI. IT OCCURRED ON THE SHALLOW ( 1 KM), PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN LITTLE RIVER FAULT AND SET OFF ABOUT 300 SIMILARLY SHALLOW AFTERSHOCKS THAT ILLUMINATE A NETWORK OF DISTINCT, CROSS CUTTING FAULTS. BECAUSE DAMAGING EARTHQUAKES IN THE CEUS ARE SO RARE, AND THIS SURFACE RUPTURE IS UNIQUE, THIS DISASTER PROVIDES AN IMPORTANT OPPORTUNITY TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE FORCES AND FAULTS RESPONSIBLE FOR INTRAPLATE EARTHQUAKES. TO MAP AND CHARACTERIZE THE FAULT ZONE IN THREE DIMENSIONS, THE RECIPIENT WILL MEASURE AND MODEL IMPERCEPTIBLE VARIATIONS IN THE PULL OF GRAVITY DUE TO DIFFERENCES IN THE ROCK TYPES ON EITHER SIDE OF FAULTS AND DUE TO THE DAMAGED ZONE ALONG FAULTS. REGULARLY SUCH STUDIES IN SUPPORT OF MAJOR CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS, GEOHAZARDS INVESTIGATIONS, AND GEOTHERMAL PROSPECTING, AMONG OTHER APPLICATIONS, AND HAVE DEVELOPED AN EXTENSIVE TOOLKIT OF GRAVITY BASED METHODS SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED FOR FAULT AND FAULT ZONE IMAGING WILL BE CONDUCTED. SHALLOW FAULTS LIKE THE LITTLE RIVER FAULT CREATE ESPECIALLY HIGH AMPLITUDE, NARROW GRAVITY SIGNALS THAT ARE VERY SENSITIVE INDICATORS OF SUBSURFACE STRUCTURE. WE PROPOSE A MICROGAL PRECISION GRAVITY SURVEY REPRODUCIBLY MEASURING GRAVITY VARIATIONS OF PARTS IN 1 BILLION OF THE SPARTA EPICENTRAL AND AFTERSHOCK ZONE. GOALS INCLUDE MAPPING THE LITTLE RIVER FAULT ZONE IN 3D AND DELINEATING THE COMPLEX NETWORK OF FAULTS ILLUMINATED BY AFTERSHOCKS WITH DECAMETER RESOLUTION. ONE KEY OUTCOME OF THIS WORK WILL BE TO ASCERTAIN THE SEISMOGENIC POTENTIAL OF THE LITTLE RIVER FAULT BY DETERMINING WHETHER THERE ARE PERSISTENT STRUCTURAL OR LITHOLOGIC BARRIERS TO RUPTURE THAT LIMIT EARTHQUAKES NEAR M5, STEPS OR OVERLAPS THAT TYPICALLY SEGMENT THE FAULT BUT COULD LINK IN A LARGE FUTURE EARTHQUAKE, OR NO PARTICULAR FEATURES THAT WOULD PREVENT LONGER RUPTURES AND THUS LARGER FUTURE EARTHQUAKES. A SECOND LINE OF INVESTIGATION WILL FOCUS ON HOW SLIP AT DEPTH WAS TRANSFERRED TO THE SURFACE AND PARTITIONED ACROSS THE SHALLOW NETWORK OF ANTECEDENT FAULTS, AND HOW UP DIP SLIP TRANSFER MAY INFLUENCE THE PROBABILITY OF SURFACE RUPTURES AND THE OUTSIZED DAMAGE THEY CAUSE. FINALLY, SYNTHESIZING PRELIMINARY WORK DOCUMENTING REGIONAL GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES, THE PROPOSED GRAVITY IMAGING OF THE EPICENTRAL ZONE, AND GEOMECHANICAL CONSTRAINTS WILL DETERMINE IF THE LITTLE RIVER FAULT IS AN ISOLATED SEISMOGENIC STRUCTURE OR IF THERE ARE ADDITIONAL FAULTS IN THE REGION CAPABLE OF SIMILAR OR LARGER EARTHQUAKES IN THE FUTURE. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL THEREFORE IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE SPARTA EARTHQUAKE AND HAZARDS ASSOCIATED WITH THE NEWLY IDENTIFIED LITTLE RIVER FAULT, REGIONAL HAZARDS ALONG THE CENTRAL SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN FRONT, AND INTRAPLATE EARTHQUAKE SOURCE PROCESSES NATIONWIDE.

PROJECT TITLE CONSTRAINTS ON STRESS HETEROGENEITY FROM MODELING INDUCED SEISMICITY ON ROUGH FAULTS IN OKLAHOMAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023PROJECT DESCRIPTION EARTHQUAKES OCCUR WHEN STRESSES ON FAULTS REACH THE FRICTIONAL RESISTANCE FOR RAPID SLIP. MOST EARTHQUAKES ARREST BEFORE GROWING TO LARGE MAGNITUDE BECAUSE STRESS WITHIN THE EARTH IS SPATIALLY HETEROGENEOUS. THE MAGNITUDE OF THIS HETEROGENEITY, HOWEVER, IS POORLY UNDERSTOOD. NUMERICALLY MODELING OF SLIP ON GEOMETRICALLY ROUGH (FRACTAL) FAULTS, WITH LABORATORY DERIVED FRICTION LAWS, SIMULATES BEHAVIOR SIMILAR TO THAT OBSERVED IN NATURE. THE RECIPIENT WILL PERTURB THESES MODELS BY SIMULATING THE EFFECTS OF INJECTING FLUIDS INTO THE SUBSURFACE AND COMPARE THE SIMULATED EARTHQUAKES WITH OBSERVATIONS OF ANTHROPOGENICALLY INDUCED EARTHQUAKES IN OKLAHOMA. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE MAGNITUDE OF STRESS HETEROGENEITY ON ACTUAL FAULTS, WHICH WILL BENEFIT REGULATORS TASKED WITH MITIGATING HUMAN INDUCED SEISMICITY AS WELL AS THE BROADER SEISMOLOGICAL COMMUNITY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED WE WILL COMPARE SIMULATIONS WITH INDUCED SEISMICITY IN CENTRAL OKLAHOMA, WHERE HYPOCENTERS ARE ARRAYED IN PLANAR STRUCTURES CONSISTING OF UP TO HUNDREDS OF EVENTS.DELIVERABLE EXPECTED OUTCOMES AN OUTCOME OF THIS WORK WILL BE TO QUANTIFY THE MAGNITUDE OF STRESS HETEROGENEITY, FRICTION PARAMETERS, AND RELATIVE TIME IN THE EARTHQUAKE CYCLE THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE OKLAHOMA DATA.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT REGULATORS TASKED WITH MITIGATING HUMAN INDUCED SEISMICITY BUT IMPROVING OUR UNDERSTANDING THE PORE PRESSURE PERTURBATIONS THAT TRIGGER SEISMICITY. IT WILL FURTHER BENEFIT THE BROADER SEISMOLOGICAL COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING CONSTRAINTS ON STRESS ROUGHNESS ON TECTONIC FAULTS, WHICH HAS IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR THE SIZE OF FUTURE EARTHQUAKES.SUBRECIPIENTS  N A

PROJECT TITLE INCLUDING CYBERSHAKE 3 D SIMULATIONS INTO NON ERGODICGROUND MOTION MODELS FOR THE LOS ANGELES REGIONPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023OVER THE LAST DECADE, THERE HAS BEEN A MOVE FROM USING GLOBAL AVERAGE GROUND MOTION MODELS (GMMS) INPROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD (PSHA) TO USING NON ERGODIC GMMS THAT ACCOUNT FOR THE SYSTEMATIC ANDREPEATABLE EFFECTS FOR A SPECIFIC SITE AND A SPECIFIC SOURCE LOCATION. THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED STUDY IS TO DEVELOP NON ERGODIC GMMS FOR SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA THAT COMBINE AN ERGODIC GMM WITH NON ERGODICSITE AND PATH EFFECTS FROM THE CYBERSHAKE (V15.4) 3 D SIMULATIONS (SCEC, 2019) AND FOR EMPIRICALGROUND MOTION DATA.THE NEW APPROACH FOR ESTIMATING NON ERGODIC PATH TERMS WILL BE APPLIED TO THE CYBERSHAKE (V15.4)SIMULATIONS DEVELOPED BY SCEC TO DEVELOP A NON ERGODIC PATH TERMS FOR PERIODS FROM 1 10 SEC WHICHREFLECTS THE PERIOD RANGE FOR WHICH THE 3 D EFFECTS ARE ONLY INCLUDED IN THE SIMULATIONS. FOR NON ERGODICSITE AND PATH TERMS FOR THE SHORTER PERIODS, THE NEW APPROACH FOR PATH EFFECTS WILL ALSO BE APPLIED TO THEAVAILABLE EMPIRICAL GROUND MOTION DATA FOR THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA REGION. THE EMPIRICAL DATA IS MUCHSPARSER IN THE SPATIAL COVERAGE THAN THE SIMULATION DATA, BUT THESE DATA PROVIDE SOME CONSTRAINTS ON THEPATH TERMS AT SHORT SPECTRAL PERIODS. COMBINING THE NON ERGODIC PATH AND SITE TERMS FROM THESE TWO DATASETS WILL LEAD A BROADBAND NON ERGODIC GMM FOR THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA REGION.THE DELIVERABLES OF THE PROJECT WILL BE A SET OF SPATIALLY VARYING SITE AND PATH TERMS AND THE ASSOCIATEDREDUCTION IN THE ALEATORY VARIABILITY THAT APPLY TO ERGODIC GMMS FOR A SUITE OF SITES ON A 5X5 KM GRID FORTHE REGION BETWEEN 32.5 AND 36.0 LATITUDE AND  121.5 AND  116 LONGITUDE. THE NON ERGODIC GMMS WILLCOVER THE PERIOD RANGE OF 0 TO 10 SEC. BOTH THE MEDIAN AND EPISTEMIC UNCERTAINTY IN THE SITE AND PATHEFFECTS WILL BE DEVELOPED. IN REGIONS OUTSIDE OF THE SPATIAL DOMAIN OF THE SIMULATIONS, THE MEAN PATHEFFECTS WILL GO BACK TO ZERO AND THE EPISTEMIC UNCERTAINTY IN THE PATH EFFECT WILL BE LARGE. IN THIS MANNER,THE NON ERGODIC MODEL PROVIDES A SMOOTH TRANSITION FROM REGIONS WITH DATA (OBSERVATIONS OF SIMULATIONS)TO DATA WITHOUT DATA, AVOIDING THE NEED TO SET SHARP BOUNDARIES FOR THE APPLICATION OF THE NON ERGODICGMMS.THE INTENDED USERS OF THE RESULTS INCLUDE THE USGS AS PART OF TRIAL APPLICATIONS OF NON ERGODIC GMMSFOR THE RESEARCH MAPS FOR THE NSHM PROJECT. OTHER INTENDED USERS INCLUDE CONSULTANTS INVOLVED IN SEISMICHAZARD STUDIES IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA.

PROJECT TITLE GEOMETRIC PARAMETERIZATION OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA SEDIMENTARY BASINS FOR SITE RESPONSE ANALYSISAND MODELINGPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023GROUND MOTION MODELS AND SIMULATION PLATFORMS SERVE AS THE PRIMARY BASIS FOR SEISMIC HAZARD DESCRIPTION IN THE  WESTERN US. SPECIFICALLY, THEY ARE THE TOOLS USED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE USGS NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD  MODEL (NSHM). THE LAST VERSION IN 2018 (PETERSON ET AL. 2020) DEBUTED THE INCORPORATION OF BASIN EFFECTS  CONDITIONED ON ISOSURFACE DEPTHS BUT THE LIMITATIONS IN ADEQUATELY DESCRIBING TRUE SITE RESPONSE REMAIN. THE RECIPIENT HAS RECENTLY DEVELOPED A BASIN MODEL CONDITIONED ON CATEGORICAL REPRESENTATION OF LATERAL CONTRIBUTING  EFFECTS IN ADDITION TO ISOSURFACE DEPTHS THAT PROVIDES A MORE ACCURATE REPRESENTATION OF THE MEAN  AMPLIFICATION AND REDUCED UNCERTAINTIES IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. THIS RESEARCH FURTHER EXPLORES ALTERNATIVE  MEANS FOR DESCRIBING LATERAL AND OTHER 3D FEATURES IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF REGION SPECIFIC MODELS TO IMPROVE  THE CHARACTERIZATION OF SITE RESPONSE IN SEDIMENTARY BASINS. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY DEVELOPING BASIN  GEOMETRIC PARAMETERS METADATA TO BE USED IN BASIN SITE RESPONSE ANALYSIS. THE PROJECT INVOLVES  THREE STEPS   DEFINING THE SEDIMENTARY BASINS  THE PRIMARY COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODELS (CVMS) IN SOUTHERN  CALIFORNIA (CVM H AND CVM S4) WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE THE BASIN SHAPE. THIS WILL BE VALIDATED  AND CONSTRAINED USING GRAVIMETRIC DATA, CHRONOSTRATIGRAPHIC MODELS, AND AVAILABLE PRIOR SUBSURFACE  INVESTIGATIONS.  DERIVING BASIN GEOMETRIC PARAMETERS  FOR STATIONS IN THE CURRENT CALIFORNIA GROUND MOTION SITE  DATABASE, ESTIMATES OF A SUITE OF GEOMETRIC PARAMETERS METADATA WILL BE ESTIMATED SIMILAR TO  PROTOCOLS USED FOR EVENT DISTANCE METADATA.  EVALUATION OF PARAMETERS AND MODEL DEVELOPMENT  THE PERFORMANCE OF THE PARAMETERS AS PREDICTIVE  FEATURE FOR SITE RESPONSE ANALYSIS WILL BE EVALUATED USING SITE TERM RESIDUALS AND THE SELECT  PARAMETERS WITH HIGH EFFICACY WILL SERVE AS THE PARAMETERS FOR UPDATED BASIN MODELS.THE PERFORMANCE OF THE MODELS WILL BE EVALUATED BY ASSESSING THEIR ABILITY TO REDUCE BIAS AND  UNCERTAINTY. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WAS SELECTED AS THE REGION OF STUDY DUE TO THE IMMEDIATE AVAILABILITY OF  DATA AND RESOURCES NEEDED TO CONDUCT THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATION. IN ADDITION, IT PROVIDES THE MEANS TO  EVALUATE MODEL PERFORMANCE IN URBAN SEDIMENTARY BASINS. THE STAKEHOLDERS TO BENEFIT FROM THE SUCCESS OF  THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE LOCAL AND REGIONAL MUNICIPALITIES, POLICY MAKERS, AND THE COMMUNITY AT LARGE AS  IMPROVEMENTS TO SITE RESPONSE ANALYSIS INDICATES ENHANCEMENTS TO OUR CURRENT DESIGN AND EVALUATION  PROCEDURES WITH REGARDS TO RESILIENCY. THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE NEW DATA IN THE FORM OF NEW SITE PARAMETERS  THAT WILL BE COMPILED AND MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH A DOI. IN ADDITION, THE INTERPRETATIONS OF THE DATA  AND MODEL DEVELOPMENT WILL BE PUBLISHED IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS SUCH AS EARTHQUAKE SPECTRA, BULLETIN OF THE  SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA, SEISMOLOGICAL RESEARCH LETTERS, AND OTHERS

PROJECT TITLE  USGS EHP DENDROSEISMOLOGY  ASSESSING THE TIMING OF THE PENULTIMATE EARTHQUAKE OF THE NORTHERNSECTION OF THE SAN ANDREAS FAULT USING DENDROCHRONOLOGYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE   1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023PROJECT DESCRIPTION  A DENDROSEISMOLOGICAL INVESTIGATION OF TREES GROWING ON THE NORTH COAST SEGMENT OF THE SAN ANDREAS FAULT (SAF) TO IMPROVE DATING OF PAST EARTHQUAKES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  TREE RING INDICATORS OF EARTHQUAKES WILL BE USED TO CONSTRAIN THE DATE OF THE PENULTIMATE EARTHQUAKE AND TO ASSESS VARIATION OF THE WITHIN TREE IMPACT OF THE 1906 AND EARLIER EARTHQUAKES. RESULTANT DATES WILL BE COMPARED TO THE PALEOSEISMIC RECORD FOR THE REGION. TO DATE EVENTS, INTERNAL INDICATORS WILL BE LOOKED AT (E.G., CHANGES IN GROWTH PATTERNS, INITIATION OF REACTION WOOD, PRESENCE OF ANATOMICAL MARKERS) AT MULTIPLE HEIGHTS AND POSITIONS ON THE TREE, AS WELL AS DATING REITERATED TOPS IF POSSIBLE. A TARGET OF 6 TREES GROWING ON THE SURFACE RUPTURE NEAR GUALALA AND FORT ROSS, CA WILL BE SAMPLED, BASED ON EXTERNAL INDICATORS AND PROXIMITY TO THE FAULT AND TRENCHES. TREES WILL BE CLIMBED WITH FREE HANGING ROPES TO COLLECT 2 4 CORES AT HEIGHTS ALONG THE TRUNK. TO CROSSDATE SAMPLES, THE RECIPIEINT WILL USE AN EXISTING 812 YEAR REFERENCE CHRONOLOGY FOR S. SEMPERVIRENS GROWING 27 KM AWAY (CARROLL ET AL., 2022 IN REVIEW) AND IF POSSIBLE 1 2 CONTROL TREES. PLUNGE CUTS WILL BE TAKEN FROM AT LEAST FIVE STUMPS TO INVESTIGATE FOR EARTHQUAKE EVIDENCE. TREE RING DELIVERABLES INCLUDE CROSSDATING SUMMARIES, ASSESSMENTS OF INTERNAL EARTHQUAKE INDICATORS OF 1906 AND PRIOR EVENTS, AND DIGITAL AND PHYSICAL ARCHIVES. IN ADDITION,EXTERNAL INDICATORS OF SAMPLED TREES WILL BE SYSTEMATICALLY DESCRIBED (E.G., CANDELABRA GROWTH, TILTING) AND RELATE THEM TO TECTONIC GEOMORPHOLOGY.DELIVERABLE OUTCOMES  A GIS DATABASE OF SAMPLED TREES WILL INCLUDE LOCATION, GEOMORPHOLOGY, AND EXTERNAL INDICATORS. WE PLAN TO PUBLISH FINDINGS IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL AS WELL AS A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT. IT IS EXPECTED THAT S. SEMPERVIRENS WILL BE A CHALLENGING SPECIES TO CROSSDATE, BUT THE SAMPLING APPROACH AND ACCUMULATED EXPERIENCE PROVIDE AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO REFINE DATING OF THE PENULTIMATE EARTHQUAKE.BENEFICIARIES  IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF THE SAF EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE HISTORY WILL BE USED TO REFINE SEISMIC HAZARD MODELS AND ULTIMATELY WILL BENEFIT ALL THOSE WHO MAKE USE OF REGIONAL AND LOCAL EARTHQUAKE HAZARD INFORMATION, SUCH AS MUNICIPALITIES, UTILITIES, INSURANCE COMPANIES, DEVELOPERS, AND BUILDING ENGINEERS. FINDINGS WILL ALSO IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW TREES RESPOND TO EARTHQUAKES, REFINING THE USE OF DENDROSEISMIC INDICATORS FOR FUTURE INVESTIGATIONS.SUBRECIPIENTS  N A

PROJECT TITLE  DELINEATION OF THE FREQUENCY DEPENDENT GULF COAST  CEUS GROUND MOTION BOUNDARYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023THE USGS NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL (NSHM) DIVIDES THE CONTINENTAL U.S. INTO A HANDFUL OF DIFFERENT REGIONS. DIFFERENT PARAMETERS ARE USED TO SIMULATE FUTURE EARTHQUAKES, ESPECIALLY THE MAXIMUM MAGNITUDE CONSIDERED POSSIBLE, THE RATE OF RANDOMLY DISTRIBUTED BACKGROUND SEISMICITY, AND THE EQUATIONS USED TO PREDICT GROUND MOTIONS DUE TO EARTHQUAKES. FOR INSTANCE, THE GULF COASTAL PLAIN (GCP) IS SEPARATED FROM THE  CRATON  PORTION OF THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN U.S. (CEUS). IN NSHM SIMULATIONS, THE LARGEST EARTHQUAKE ALLOWED (BY ENERGY) AND DEFAULT RATE OF THE RANDOM SEISMICITY ARE BOTH 3 TIMES HIGHER ON THE GCP. THESE DIFFERENCES UNDERSTANDABLY INFLUENCE HAZARD FOR  15 MILLION AMERICANS ALONG THE CEUS GCP BOUNDARY IN TEXAS ALONE, YET THE BOUNDARY MOSTLY FOLLOWS GEOLOGIC AGE AS UNDERSTOOD IN 1995 RATHER THAN ANY METRIC OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING. A NEARLY IDENTICAL PROBLEM WITH THE CEUS WESTERN U.S. (WUS) BOUNDARY WAS RECENTLY RECTIFIED BY MAPPING DIFFERENCES IN SHAKING AMPLITUDE FROM THOUSANDS OF RECORDINGS OF SMALL EARTHQUAKES. THE DATABASE USED FOR THAT DELINEATION ALSO CONTAINS THOUSANDS OF RECORDS CROSSING THE GCP CRATON BOUNDARY. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL APPLY THE SAME METHODS USED ON THE CEUS WUS BOUNDARY AND THE ALREADY COMPILED AND QUALITY CONTROLLED DATABASE TO DELINEATE THE GCP CEUS GROUND MOTION BOUNDARY. THE DERIVED BOUNDARY CURVE CAN BE IMMEDIATELY IMPLEMENTED IN THE NSHM AND WILL SERVE TO REDUCE UNCERTAINTY IN THE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE EARTHQUAKE SHAKING, IMPROVING HAZARD ASSESSMENTS AND EARTHQUAKE PREPAREDNESS.

PROJECT TITLE DETERMINING GNSS STRAIN RATE AND UNCERTAINTY IN LOW STRAIN RATE REGIONS  APPLICATION TO THE NEWMADRID SEISMIC ZONE AND NORTHEASTERN OKLAHOMAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023THIS PROJECT IS FOR FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH TOWARDS IMPROVING GPS DEFORMATION RATE ESTIMATES AND UNCERTAINTIES IN INTRAPLATE SEISMIC ZONES, WITH FOCUS ON THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE, WHICH HAS A HISTORY OF TECTONIC EARTHQUAKES, AND NORTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA, WHICH IS HISTORICALLY WITHOUT TECTONIC EARTHQUAKES BUT HAS HAD INDUCED EARTHQUAKES. IT HAS BEEN 7 YEARS SINCE THE LAST NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE FOCUSED GPS STUDY AND DURING THAT TIME MANY GPS SITES HAVE BEEN UPGRADED TO GLOBAL NAVIGATION SATELLITE SYSTEM, KNOWN AS GNSS, EQUIPMENT THAT RECEIVE DATA FROM ALL THE GPS LIKE SYSTEMS CURRENTLY IN OPERATION  THE RUSSIAN GLONASS, EUROPEAN UNION GALILEO, AND CHINESE BIEDOU SYSTEMS. THE GNSS PROVIDES OVER 4 TIMES AS MANY SATELLITES AS GPS ALONE AND SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVED RESULTS. THE NUMBER OF GPS SITES IN THE CENTRAL US HAS ALSO GROWN, AND BOTH PROCESSING AND GEODYNAMIC ANALYSIS SOFTWARE HAS IMPROVED. ACTIVITIES PERFORMED WILL BEGIN WITH PROCESSING THE FULL GNSS DATA SET FROM THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN US TO ESTIMATE DEFORMATION RATES AND THEIR UNCERTAINTIES. THE RESULTS WILL THEN BE ANALYZED TO ADDRESS TWO OVERARCHING QUESTIONS IN INTRAPLATE SEISMIC ZONES WHERE THE STRAIN RATES ARE VERY LOW  WHAT TECTONIC STRAIN DRIVES THE SEISMICITY, AND HOW WELL CAN GNSS DATA ESTIMATE ITS RATE AND UNCERTAINTY. ANSWERING THE LATTER REQUIRES A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF GNSS DATA NOISE, ESPECIALLY THAT FROM A PROPOSED RANDOM WALK OF GNSS MONUMENTS. THE ANSWER TO LATTER CONTRIBUTES TO HOW WELL ANSWER THE FORMER. THE RECIPIENT WILL USE THEIR UPDATED CENTRAL AND EASTERN US GNSS RESULTS TO EXAMINE STRAIN RATE USING RELATIVE POSITIONING BASELINE LENGTH TIME SERIES WITH NEW ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES. FOR LOW STRAIN RATES, RANDOM WALK IS THE MOST SIGNIFICANT NOISE THREAT DUE TO TWO INTRINSIC PROPERTIES, NON STATIONARITY, AND TEMPORAL CORRELATION. THESE PROPERTIES CAUSE THE RESULTS TO DEPEND ON THE TIME THE MEASUREMENT WAS MADE AND THE DURATION OF THE MEASUREMENT. ADDITIONALLY, MEASUREMENT UNCERTAINTIES INCREASE WITH MEASUREMENT DURATION. FOCUS ON GNSS DATA FROM TWO STABLY MONUMENTED CENTRAL AND EASTERN US GPS ARRAYS  THE GPS ARRAY FOR MID AMERICA, FOCUSED ON EXAMINING STRAIN RATE IN AND AROUND THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE AND A GEODETIC NETWORK INSTALLED AFTER THE 2016, M 5.8, PAWNEE, OK, EARTHQUAKE, FOCUSED ON ITS POSTSEISMIC DEFORMATION. SITES FROM THE INTERNATIONAL GEODYNAMICS SERVICE AND US CONTINUOUSLY OPERATING REFERENCE STATION NETWORKS WILL ALSO BE INCLUDED.DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES RANGE FROM THE INTRAPLATE EARTHQUAKE ENIGMA DEEPENING WITH NO STATISTICALLY SIGNIFICANT DEFORMATION OBSERVED, IN WHICH CASE UPPER LIMITS ON DEFORMATION RATES MAY BE ESTIMABLE BASED ON THE NOISE LEVEL, TO THE FIRST ACCEPTED INTRA PLATE ESTIMATES OF DEFORMATION RATES AND THEIR UNCERTAINTIES. THE RESULTS WILL BE USEFUL TO STAKEHOLDERS AND BENEFICIARIES SUCH AS ENGINEERS, INSURANCE COMPANIES, PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICIALS, AND CONTRIBUTE TO ESTIMATION AND MITIGATION OF SEISMIC HAZARD IN THE CENTRAL US. THE RESULTS WILL BE TIMELY IN PROVIDING UPDATED ESTIMATES OF CRUSTAL STRAIN IN THE CENTRAL U.S. FOR TESTING GEODYNAMIC MODELS. THE IMPROVED CONSTRAINTS ON UNCERTAINTIES WILL CONTRIBUTE TO UNDERSTANDING EARTHQUAKE GENERATION AND SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSIS IN THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE AND NORTHERN OKLAHOMA AND PROVIDE NEW TOOLS FOR APPLICATION TO OTHER SEISMIC ZONES.

PROJECT TITLE HIGH RESOLUTION SUBSURFACE IMAGINGUSING INTERFEROMETRY OF DASAMBIENT NOISE STRAIN RATEMEASUREMENTS ALONG A DARK FIBERLINE IN DOWNTOWN RENO, NVPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023THIS PROJECT AIMS TO USE THE METHOD OF SEISMIC INTERFEROMETRY TO GENERATE HIGH RESOLUTION TWO DIMENSIONAL SUBSURFACE SHEAR WAVE VELOCITY PROFILES AND BASIN GEOMETRY EMPLOYING DISTRIBUTED ACOUSTIC SENSING TECHNOLOGY ALONG A 12 KM SPAN OF A DARK FIBER LINE GOING THROUGH DOWNTOWN RENO, NV. THE DISTRIBUTED ACOUSTIC SENSING TECHNOLOGY ENABLES GATHERING AMBIENT NOISE SEISMIC DATA ALONG THE ENTIRE LENGTH OF A FIBER OPTIC CABLE AT THE METER SCALE SPACING BETWEEN EACH CHANNEL. SUCH HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTIONS OF RECORDING AMBIENT NOISE DATA OVER LONG DISTANCES HAVE NOT BEEN POSSIBLE USING TRADITIONAL METHODS DUE TO LIMITED HARDWARE RESOURCES AND SECURITY CONCERNS IN AN URBAN ENVIRONMENT, LIMITING THE RESOLUTION OF THE PREVIOUSLY GENERATED VELOCITY PROFILES IN THE RENO AREA BASIN. IN THIS PROJECT, AN ENSEMBLE OF NOISE CROSS CORRELATIONS WILL BE GENERATED FIRST ACROSS A MOVING WINDOW CONTAINING A SUBSET OF CHANNELS ALONG THE 12 KM LINE SPAN. THEN, THE GENERATED NOISE CROSS CORRELATIONS WILL BE USED TO EXTRACT DISPERSION CURVES FOR EACH MOVING WINDOW AND INVERT THEM TO ESTIMATE THE ONE DIMENSIONAL REPRESENTATION OF THE UNDERLYING SHEAR WAVE VELOCITY AND BASIN GEOMETRY. FINALLY, THE INVERTED RESULTS WILL BE INTERPOLATED TO GENERATE THE TWO DIMENSIONAL VELOCITY STRUCTURE OF THE UNDERLYING FEATURES AND WILL BE COMPARED TO PREVIOUS STUDIES WITHIN THE REGION. THE OUTCOME OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS EXPECTED TO REFINE AND COMPLEMENT THE EXISTING SHEAR WAVE VELOCITY PROFILES AND SUBSURFACE STRUCTURE OF THE RENO AREA BASIN IN AN URBAN CORRIDOR ALONG THE DARK FIBER LINE. SUCH A REFINEMENT IN THE SUBSURFACE VELOCITY STRUCTURE MAY HELP IMPROVE THE RESOLUTION OF THE SIMULATED GROUND MOTIONS AND SITE AMPLIFICATION FACTORS IN THE SEDIMENTARY RENO BASIN, WHICH HELPS CITY PLANNERS AND THE PUBLIC BETTER PREPARE FOR POSSIBLE LARGE MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKES IN THIS REGION. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT, INCLUDING THE DEVELOPED FRAMEWORK AND IMPROVED VELOCITY MODELS AND BASIN GEOMETRY, WILL BE WIDELY DISSEMINATED AND MADE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC ACCESS BY PUBLISHING IN HIGH IMPACT JOURNALS AND FILE SHARING USING AVAILABLE ONLINE RESOURCES.

PROJECT TITLE TOWARDS AN IMPROVED SALT LAKE VALLEY COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL THROUGH SEISMIC AND GRAVITY JOINTINVERSION  COLLABORATIVE PROPOSAL WITH UNIVERSITY OF UTAH AND UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEYPEROID OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023THE RECENT M5.7 MAGNA EARTHQUAKE WITHIN THE SALT LAKE VALLEY OFFERS A STARK REMINDER THAT DEVASTATING EARTHQUAKES ARE A REAL THREAT IN THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST. THERE IS A 43  PROBABILITY OF AN M 6.75 OR LARGER SURFACE RUPTURING EARTHQUAKE IN THE NEXT 50 YEARS ON THE WASATCH FRONT REGION. APPROXIMATELY 80  OF UTAH S POPULATION AND MUCH OF ITS ECONOMIC INFRASTRUCTURE ARE LOCATED WITHIN THE WASATCH FRONT URBAN CORRIDOR. WHILE MUCH HAS BEEN LEARNED ABOUT THE SALT LAKE BASIN OVER THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS, ITS DETAILED GEOMETRY AND THE OVERALL SUBSURFACE DENSITY AND SEISMIC VELOCITY STRUCTURE REMAIN POORLY CONSTRAINED. TO BETTER ASSESS POTENTIAL SEISMIC HAZARDS, A MORE ACCURATE COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL (CVM) IS NEEDED FOR REALISTIC EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTION SIMULATIONS FOR VARIOUS FAULT RUPTURE SCENARIOS. BECAUSE THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE REGIONAL SEISMICITY WAS LIMITED, GRAVITY DATA PLAYED AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN THE PREVIOUS CVM DEVELOPMENTS. A RECENT STUDY (AFTER THE MAGNA EARTHQUAKE) MEASURED SEISMIC WAVES TO CONSTRAIN THE 3D BASIN STRUCTURE ACROSS THE SALT LAKE VALLEY. THE RECIPIENT WILL LEVERAGE THE COMPLEMENTARY SENSITIVITY OF GRAVITY, SEISMIC, AND OTHER RELEVANT GEOLOGIC DATA BY PERFORMING A JOINT SEISMIC AND GRAVITY INVERSION TO CONSTRUCT A NEW 3D MODEL OF THE SALT LAKE BASIN.TO THIS END, THE RECIPIENT WILL 1) USE EXISTING GEOPHYSICAL AND GEOLOGICAL DATASETS 2) CARRY OUT A TELESEISMIC RECEIVER FUNCTION ANALYSIS TO ADD NEW CONSTRAINTS TO THE BASIN GEOMETRY 3) UNDERTAKE ADDITIONAL GRAVITY MEASUREMENTS TO VALIDATE THE LEGACY GRAVITY MEASUREMENTS AND IMPROVE MEASUREMENT ACCURACY. 4) PERFORM A JOINT INVERSION OF THE GRAVITY AND SEISMIC DATA INCLUDING HISTORIC DATA AND THAT WHICH IS COLLECTED DURING THIS STUDY 5) COMPARE THE NEW 3D MODEL WITH THE CURRENT CVM AND EVALUATE POTENTIAL SHORTCOMINGS OF THE CURRENT MODEL.IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE NEW MODEL WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO FUTURE CVM REVISION. THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE COMPLEMENTARY EXPERTISE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF UTAH AND THE UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEY ON GRAVITY AND SEISMIC MODELING INVERSION AND COALESCE WITH GEOLOGIC HAZARD MAPPING KNOWLEDGE. THE ULTIMATE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN IMPROVED 3D MODEL OF THE SALT LAKE BASIN THAT WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS INCLUDING A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT TO THE USGS AND A FINAL REPORT ONLINE AT THE UGS SURVEY PUBLICATION REPOSITORY WITH DATA AND SUBSURFACE MODELS FROM THIS PROJECT IN DIGITAL FORM. ALL SEISMIC DATA THAT WILL BE USED IN THIS PROJECT EITHER HAS BEEN OR IS CURRENTLY BEING ACHIEVED WITH THE IRIS DATA MANAGEMENT CENTER. THE FINAL 3D SALT LAKE VALLEY MODEL WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE THROUGH IRIS EARTH MODEL COLLABORATION AND UGS COMMUNITY VELOCITY MODEL (CVM) WEB PAGE. THIS MODEL WILL BENEFIT THE 3.3 MILLION PEOPLE LIVING WITHIN THE WASATCH FRONT URBAN CORRIDOR AND DECISION MAKERS PLANNING THE GROWTH OF THIS COMMUNITY.

PROJECT TITLE COMPREHENSIVE SEISMOLOGICAL INVESTIGATION OF THE 2020 MW 5.1 SPARTA,NORTH CAROLINA, EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023AWARD PURPOSE  ON AUGUST 9, 2020, A MW 5.1 EARTHQUAKE SHOOK THE BLUE RIDGE MOUNTAINS NEAR SPARTA, NORTH CAROLINA, CAUSING DAMAGE TO ROADS, UTILITY LINES, AND MASONRY STRUCTURES. THIS EARTHQUAKE CAUSED A MAXIMUM INTENSITY OF MMI VII IN THE EPICENTRAL AREA, AND WAS FELT ACROSS THE EASTERN UNITED STATES (EUS) AND INTO THE GREAT PLAINS AND CANADA ACCORDING TO THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS)  DID YOU FEEL IT   INTENSITY MAP.DESPITE ITS MODERATE SIZE, THIS EARTHQUAKE GENERATED THE FIRST DOCUMENTED SURFACE RUPTURE DUE TO FAULTING IN THE EUS. IT REMAINS UNCLEAR IF THIS IS THE SAME SURFACE THAT RUPTURED AT DEPTH OR WHETHER SURFACE DEFORMATION IS A SUBSIDIARY FAULT. NOTABLY, THE SPARTA EARTHQUAKE WAS PRECEDED BY 8 FORESHOCKS WITHIN THE 25 HOURS BEFORE THE MAINSHOCK AND FOLLOWED BY HUNDREDS OF LOCATABLE AFTERSHOCKS. OUR PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS OF THE MAINSHOCK FOCAL MECHANISM SUGGESTS THAT THE MAPPED SURFACE DEFORMATION IS LIKELY ASSOCIATED WITH THE MAINSHOCK RUPTURE. HOWEVER, IT IS STILL UNCLEAR HOW THE MAINSHOCK RUPTURE INITIATED AND PROPAGATED. IT IS OF PARTICULAR INTEREST TO EXAMINE THE ROLE OF THE FORESHOCKS IN THE NUCLEATION PROCESS OF THE MAINSHOCK.IN THIS STUDY, THE RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT DETAILED SEISMOLOGICAL ANALYSES ON THE DATA COLLECTED FOR THIS UNUSUAL FORESHOCK MAINSHOCK AFTERSHOCK SEQUENCE TO HELP RESOLVE DETAILS OF THE MAINSHOCK FAULTING PROCESS, AS WELL AS REVEAL THE LOCATIONS AND ORIENTATIONS OF OTHER SEISMOGENIC FAULTS IN THE SOURCE ZONE. THIS WORK IS ABSOLUTELY ESSENTIAL FOR IMPROVING SEISMIC SOURCE CHARACTERIZATION IN THIS VERY LOW STRAIN RATE INTRAPLATE SETTING FOR SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED 1. COLLECT AND PROCESS ALL AVAILABLE DATA RECORDED BY LOCAL AND REGIONAL SEISMIC STATIONS2. DERIVE A RUPTURE MODEL FOR THE MW 5.1 MAINSHOCK3. PERFORM HIGH RESOLUTION EARTHQUAKE DETECTION AND RELOCATION TO OBTAIN A COMPLETE EARTHQUAKE CATALOG FOR THE SEQUENCE4. DETERMINE SOURCE PARAMETERS INCLUDING FOCAL MECHANISM, CORNER FREQUENCY, STRESS DROP, MOMENT MAGNITUDE, RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY5. PREPARE REPORT AND DISSEMINATE RESULTSDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE MAIN DELIVERABLE IS A FINAL REPORT THAT DOCUMENTS THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT. THE RESULTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE EARTHQUAKE SOURCE CHARACTERISTICS AND THE ASSOCIATED SEISMIC HAZARD IN THIS INTRAPLATE ENVIRONMENT. IN ADDITION TO THE REPORT, THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL BE PRESENTED AT ONE OR MORE NATIONAL MEETING OF EITHER THE AMERICAN GEOPHYSICAL UNION OR THE SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL BE SUBMITTED IN AT LEAST TWO PAPERS FOR PUBLICATION TO A PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL, SUCH AS THE BULLETIN OF THE SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA OR SEISMOLOGICAL RESEARCH LETTERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  SEISMOLOGISTS AND GEOLOGISTS WORKING ON SOURCE PARAMETERS AND SEISMIC HAZARD IN THE CEUS, INCLUDING THE GROUPS DEVELOPING NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS FOR INCORPORATION IN BUILDING CODES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  N A

PROJECT TITLE UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECTS OF WILLAMETTE VALLEY SEDIMENTARY STRUCTURE ON SHAKINGPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  3 15 2023 THROUGH 3 14 2024AWARD PURPOSE  ACCURATELY ESTIMATING GROUND MOTIONS FOR POSSIBLE  EARTHQUAKES UNDERPINS SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS. SITE CHARACTERISTICS PLAY A DEFINING ROLE IN EITHER  AMPLIFYING, OR ATTENUATING SHAKING AT FREQUENCIES OF ENGINEERING INTEREST, AS WELL AS ALTERING THE  FREQUENCY CONTENT OF GROUND MOTIONS. IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST, THE BASINS NEAR SEATTLE AND PORTLAND  HAVE BEEN THE SUBJECT OF STUDY FOR SITE EFFECTS, IN PARTICULAR THE AMPLIFYING EFFECTS OF BASINS. HOWEVER, IN  OREGON, THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY SOUTH OF PORTLAND IS ONE OF THE MORE POPULATED REGIONS IN OREGON, IS LESS  STUDIED, AND NOT REPRESENTED AS SHOWING AMPLIFICATION TO SHAKING. THE STEPHENSON ET AL. (2017) SEISMIC  VELOCITY MODEL IS LESS DEVELOPED IN THIS REGION AND DOES NOT CONTAIN DEEP SEDIMENTS. HOWEVER, GEOLOGIC  AND GEOPHYSICAL EVIDENCE SUGGESTING LOW ( 2.5 KM S) VELOCITIES DOWN TO  2 4KM DEPTH, OVERLYING A  SEISMICALLY FASTER BASEMENT. THIS MEANS THAT THE REGION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO ACT AS A BASIN AND AMPLIFY  GROUND MOTIONS DURING EARTHQUAKES. YET, THERE ARE LIMITED SEISMIC OBSERVATIONS TO DEFINE THIS  EMPIRICALLY, AND PALEO PROXIES OF SHAKING IN THE REGION ARE LIMITED AND SIMULTANEOUSLY SUGGEST THAT  GROUND MOTIONS MAY IN FACT BE ATTENUATED IN THE REGION. IN THIS STUDY, THE OBJECTIVE IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW CURRENT OBSERVATIONS AND MEASUREMENTS OF THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY S STRUCTURE AFFECT REGIONAL SHAKING.  Q1. DOES THE REGION AMPLIFY, OR ATTENUATE GROUND MOTIONS DURING EARTHQUAKES  Q2. IF SO, BY HOW MUCH,  AND WHAT IS THE SPATIAL VARIABILITY IN THESE SITE EFFECTS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  ANSWERING THESE QUESTIONS WILL REQUIRE THREE MAIN STEPS. (1) CREATE A STRUCTURALLY BASED SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL WITH AVAILABLE GEOLOGIC, AND GEOPHYSICAL OIL AND GAS  WELL DATA TO MORE ACCURATELY REPRESENT THE SEDIMENTARY STRUCTURES IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY, OREGON. (2)  USING 3D SIMULATIONS OF A FEW SMALL CRUSTAL EARTHQUAKES WITH THE FINITE DIFFERENCE SOFTWARE SW4, VALIDATE AND UPDATE OUR VELOCITY MODEL BY AIMING TO IMPROVE FITS TO EXISTING WAVEFORM OBSERVATIONS IN  COMPARISON TO USING THE STEPHENSON ET AL. (2017) MODEL. (3) WITH MODIFIED WILLAMETTE VALLEY  SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL, PERFORM NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS OF SMALL TO MODERATE (4   M   6)  SUBDUCTION ZONE INTERFACE AND CRUSTAL EARTHQUAKES TO CONSTRAIN HOW THE REGION AFFECTS GROUND MOTIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  USING THE RESULTS OF THESE SIMULATIONS AND COMPARING SHAKING  INSIDE AND OUTSIDE THE VALLEY, WE WILL PRODUCE MAPS OF ANTICIPATED SITE EFFECTS THAT CAN BE USED AS  PROXIES OR SITE CONDITIONS IN ESTIMATING GROUND MOTIONS FOR REGIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD. LASTLY, WE WILL  EXAMINE HOW THE VALLEY MIGHT RESPOND TO AZIMUTHAL VARIABILITY IN EARTHQUAKE SOURCES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK ARE ANTICIPATED TO ADDRESS BOTH NATIONAL, PNA, AND  SUBDUCTION ZONE SCIENCE PLAN PRIORITIES ABOUT IMPROVED SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS, AND  OBSERVATIONALLY VALIDATED GROUND MOTION MODELS THAT INCORPORATE COMPLEX WAVE PROPAGATION EFFECTS.  RESULTS OF THIS WORK CAN BE APPLIED TO FUTURE SEISMIC HAZARD STUDIES, AND CAN PROVIDE  RECOMMENDATIONS ON WHETHER FURTHER INVESTIGATION INTO SITE EFFECTS IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY ARE  NEEDED TO IMPROVE GROUND MOTION ESTIMATES, AND CAN SUGGEST CHANGES TO IMPROVE THE SEISMIC VELOCITY  MODEL OF STEPHENSON ET AL. (2017) IN THIS REGION.SUBRECIPIENTS  N A

PROJECT TITLE IMPLICATIONS OF SPATIAL VARIATIONS IN EARTHQUAKE STRESSDROP FOR FAULT MECHANICS AND STRONG GROUND MOTIONPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023PROJET DESCRIPTION   EARTHQUAKES VARY WIDELY IN THEIR PROPERTIES. ONE KEY PARAMETER USED BY SEISMOLOGISTS TO DESCRIBE EARTHQUAKES IS THEIR STRESS DROP, A MEASURE OF THE FORCES UNLEASHED DURING FAULT RUPTURE. HIGH STRESS DROP EARTHQUAKES ARE PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS BECAUSE THEY GENERATE STRONGER GROUND MOTIONS THAN LOW STRESS DROP EVENTS OF THE SAME SIZE. THIS PROPOSAL WILL EXAMINE WHY SOME PARTS OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA ARE MORE PRONE TO HIGH STRESS DROP EARTHQUAKES AND TEST WHETHER SMALL EARTHQUAKES ARE PREDICTIVE OF FUTURE LARGE EARTHQUAKE BEHAVIOR IN THE SAME REGION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   RESEARCH CONCERNING EARTHQUAKE STRESS DROPS, COORDINATED BETWEEN THE PI AND A GRADUATE STUDENT WORKING ON THE PROJECT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   PROJECT REPORTS AND AT LEAST ONE NEW PUBLICATION IN THE PEER REVIEWED LITERATURE. CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE RIDGECREST STRESS DROP VALIDATION PROJECT.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES   THE SEISMOLOGY AND GEOPHYSICAL RESEARCH COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE CENTER AND THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES   NONE

PROJECT TITLE INFORMING PREDICTIONS FROM ABOVE WITH DATA FROM BELOW  A HIERARCHICAL GEOSPATIAL LIQUEFACTION MODEL FOR RAPID RESPONSE AND SIMULATIONPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023GEOSPATIAL MODELS FOR PREDICTING EARTHQUAKE INDUCED SOIL LIQUEFACTION INFER SUBSURFACE SOIL TRAITS VIA SATELLITE REMOTE SENSING AND MAPPED INFORMATION, RATHER THAN DIRECTLY MEASURE THEM WITH SUBSURFACE GEOTECHNICAL TESTS. THESE MODELS SERVE AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN REGIONAL SCALE EARTHQUAKE APPLICATIONS (E.G., RAPID RESPONSE AND SCENARIO PLANNING) AND ARE IMPLEMENTED IN POST EARTHQUAKE DATA PRODUCTS. AS PART OF A PRIOR PROJECT, THE PI EVALUATED THE PERFORMANCE OF POPULAR GEOSPATIAL LIQUEFACTION MODELS USING GLOBAL CASE HISTORIES, WHICH ELUCIDATED BOTH THE PROMISING POTENTIAL AND SIGNIFICANT SHORTCOMINGS OF EXISTING MODELS. IN RESPONSE, THE PI RECENTLY DEVELOPED GEOSPATIAL MODELS THAT ARE DRIVEN BY ALGORITHMIC LEARNING BUT PINNED TO AN ESTABLISHED GEOTECHNICAL FRAMEWORK, THEREBY BENEFITING BOTH FROM MACHINE LEARNING, WHICH PROVIDES GREATER POTENTIAL FOR GEOSPATIAL DATA TO BE EXPLOITED, AND FROM THE KNOWLEDGE OF LIQUEFACTION MECHANICS DEVELOPED OVER THE LAST 50 YEARS, WHICH PROVIDES MECHANISTICALLY SENSIBLE RESPONSE AND SCALING. IN EFFECT, THE MODELS PREDICT SUBSURFACE TEST DATA IN THE CONTEXT OF ESTABLISHED MODELS THAT PREDICT GROUND FAILURE PROBABILISTICALLY. THE MODELS WERE CODED IN WINDOWS SOFTWARE, RAPIDLIQ, AND WERE SHOWN VIA UNBIASED TESTING TO PERFORM AS WELL AS, OR BETTER THAN, THE CURRENT LEADING GEOSPATIAL MODEL.THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF RAPIDLIQ AND THE MODELS AVAILABLE THEREIN. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY TO BE PERFORMED IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MACHINE LEARNING MODEL FOR PREDICTING LIQUEFACTION INDUCED GROUND FAILURE USING GEOSPATIAL DATA. THIS MODEL WILL BE TRAINED USING  (I) A MUCH LARGER SET OF IN SITU TESTS  (II) AN EXPANDED SET OF PREDICTOR VARIABLES  (III) MORE GEOTECHNICAL MODELS, SUCH THAT THEIR INSIGHTS ARE ENSEMBLED  AND (IV) PROBABILISTIC ALGORITHMS, SUCH THAT THE ULTIMATE PREDICTION OUTPUT   THE PROBABILITY OF GROUND FAILURE   HAS UNCERTAINTY QUANTIFICATION. IN ADDITION, REGRESSION KRIGING OR THE MULTIVARIATE NORMAL METHOD WILL BE USED TO UPDATE GEOSPATIAL PREDICTIONS IN THE VICINITY OF GEOTECHNICAL DATA, THEREBY CORRECTING FOR LOCAL OR REGIONAL PREDICTION BIAS. THE PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE MODELS, MAPS, AND SOFTWARE, WHICH WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR THE U.S. AND ELSEWHERE, AND WHICH CAN BE USED TO PREDICT THE PROBABILITY OF LIQUEFACTION INDUCED GROUND FAILURE. PROVIDED A MAP OF GROUND MOTION INTENSITIES   AVAILABLE MINUTES AFTER AN EVENT, OR FOR ENUMERABLE SCENARIO EVENTS   RAPIDLIQ V.2 WILL PREDICT THE PROBABILITY OF GROUND FAILURE AT REGIONAL SCALE, WHEREIN PREDICTIONS FAR FROM IN SITU TESTS ARE THOSE OF THE NEW MODEL AND PREDICTIONS NEAR IN SITU TESTS ARE INFLUENCED BY GEOTECHNICAL MODELS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS AN IMPROVED ABILITY TO PREDICT THE OCCURRENCE AND CONSEQUENCES OF SOIL LIQUEFACTION, TO INCLUDE IN NEAR REAL TIME AFTER AN EARTHQUAKE. THIS WILL BENEFIT PRACTICING ENGINEERS, EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS, REGIONAL PLANNERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO CAN USE THE DELIVERABLES TO PREDICT THE IMPACTS OF LIQUEFACTION AT REGIONAL SCALE, EITHER FOR A FUTURE SCENARIO EVENT (THEREBY INFORMING PLANNING AND MITIGATION), OR FOR AN EVENT THAT HAS JUST OCCURRED (THEREBY INFORMING EMERGENCY RESPONSE). THE PROJECT HAS NO SUBRECIPIENTS.

PROJECT TITLE RELATIVE MAGNITUDE CALCULATION AND VARIATIONS IN MAGNITUDE FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION FOR EARTHQUAKESIN THE DELAWARE BASINPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE  1 1 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2023FORECASTING THE HAZARDS OF ONGOING EARTHQUAKES IN THE DELAWARE BASIN IN TEXAS AND NEW  MEXICO POSES A PRESSING ISSUE, AS MORE THAN 1000 M 2.5 EARTHQUAKES OCCURRED IN THE REGION FOR  THE PAST TWO YEARS. NEW ANALYSIS THAT CAN RAPIDLY AND RELIABLY CHARACTERIZE INDUCED SEISMICITY ARE  REQUIRED TO EVALUATE THE EARTHQUAKE HAZARD POTENTIAL OF THE REGION AND ASSESS WHETHER THESE  EVENTS ARE FORESHOCKS OF EVEN LARGER EARTHQUAKES. THE MAGNITUDE FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION (MFD)  OF EARTHQUAKES IS AN IMPORTANT FIRST STEP TO DETERMINING EARTHQUAKE RECURRENCE TIMES AND SEISMIC  HAZARDS. UNDERSTANDING HOW THE MFDS CHANGE SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY CAN PROVIDE VITAL  INFORMATION ABOUT VARIATIONS IN THE SEISMIC HAZARD FOR A GIVEN REGION  HOWEVER, THE ESTIMATION OF  THE MFDS OF SMALL INDUCED EARTHQUAKES SUFFERS FROM THE UNCERTAINTIES IN EARTHQUAKE MAGNITUDES,  WHICH ARE USUALLY LARGE FOR SMALL EVENTS. THE INACCURATE MAGNITUDE ESTIMATES DIRECTLY TRANSLATE TO  UNRELIABLE CALCULATION OF THE SLOPES OF THE MFDS, I.E., THE B VALUES THAT QUANTIFY THE RELATIVE  ABUNDANCE OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES TO SMALL EARTHQUAKES IN THE REGION. THIS PROJECT WILL RECALCULATE THE MAGNITUDES OF EARTHQUAKES IN THE DELAWARE BASIN AND  CHARACTERIZE THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIATION IN THE MFDS OF EARTHQUAKES. INSTEAD OF RELYING ON  ABSOLUTE MAGNITUDE SCALES THAT MAY INTRODUCE LARGE ERRORS, THE RECIPIENT WILL USE A RELATIVE MAGNITUDE  APPROACH THAT IS BASED ON THE AMPLITUDE RATIOS OF EVENT PAIRS WITH SIMILAR WAVEFORMS AND DOES  NOT REQUIRE PRIOR KNOWLEDGE OF THE VELOCITY STRUCTURE AND SITE EFFECTS. THEY WILL ALSO BENCHMARK THE  RELATIVE MAGNITUDE ESTIMATES WITH THE CODA ENVELOPE DERIVED MAGNITUDES THAT CAN BE MORE  RELIABLY DETERMINED FOR A SUBSET OF THE EVENTS. WITH THE NEW RELATIVE MAGNITUDES, THEY WILL  CALCULATE THE MAGNITUDE FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION USING THE POSITIVE MAGNITUDE DIFFERENCES (VAN DER  ELST, 2021), WHICH ALSO HELPS MINIMIZE THE BIAS INTRODUCED BY INACCURATE MAGNITUDE ESTIMATES. THEY WILL EXAMINE THE TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL CHANGES IN THE B VALUES TO DETERMINE WHETHER WE CAN  IDENTIFY ANY CHANGES THAT INDICATE INCREASED EARTHQUAKE HAZARD. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE NEW METHODS WILL HELP RECONCILE THE DIFFERENCE IN MAGNITUDES OF  SMALL EARTHQUAKES REPORTED IN THE ADVANCED NATIONAL SEISMIC SYSTEM (ANSS) COMCAT CATALOG  AND CONTRIBUTE TO RAPID HAZARD ASSESSMENT OF INDUCED SEISMICITY, ESPECIALLY WHEN LOCATIONS AND  OPERATING PARAMETERS OF INJECTION WELLS VARY TEMPORALLY. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL ALSO ADDRESS  THE CRITICAL ISSUE OF WHETHER B VALUE REDUCTION IS A ROBUST INDICATOR OF ELEVATED SEISMIC HAZARD  WHEN EARTHQUAKE MAGNITUDES HAVE LARGE UNCERTAINTIES.

PROJECT TITLE:INVESTIGATION OF PALEOLIQUEFACTION OF THE GRAND RIVER TECTONIC ZONE (CENTRAL MISSOURI)PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 7/31/2023THIS STUDY WILL ASSESS INDICATIONS OF PREHISTORIC EARTHQUAKE EFFECTS IN NORTH-CENTRAL MISSOURI, NEAR THE CONFLUENCE OF THE GRAND RIVER WITH THE MISSOURI RIVER. THE STUDY AREA ENCOMPASSES APPROXIMATELY 80 KM2 (NEAR THE TOWN OF TRIPLETT, MO) AND IS LOCATED ALONG THE NORTHWESTERN END OF THE GRAND RIVER TECTONIC ZONE (GRTZ) - A PROMINENT ALIGNMENT OF GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES THAT TREND NW-SE ACROSS MISSOURI. LIKELY LIQUEFACTION FEATURES (SAND BLOWS, CLASTIC DIKES) SUGGEST STRONG GROUND MOTION, AND SUBTLE TOPOGRAPHY SIGNATURES MAY BE INDICATIVE OF RECENT TECTONIC DEFORMATIONS. OWING TO THE DISTANCE FROM THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE, WE BELIEVE THE FEATURES IN THIS STUDY AREA REFLECT A MORE PROXIMAL, AND PREVIOUSLY UNDOCUMENTED, POTENTIAL SEISMIC SOURCE.TO INVESTIGATE THIS SITE, WE WILL PERFORM DETAILED MAPPING OF LIQUEFACTION FEATURES AND SOIL CHARACTER IN AND AROUND THE "TRIPLETT" TERRACE SURFACE USING A COMBINATION OF MULTI-SPECTRAL AND THERMAL IMAGERY, ALONG WITH HIGH-RESOLUTION TOPOGRAPHY FROM LIDAR. AS NECESSARY, WE WILL ACQUIRE HIGH-RESOLUTION TOPOGRAPHIC DATA USING DRONE-BASED PHOTOGRAMMETRY AND/OR LIDAR. ANOTHER TASK WILL INVOLVE A COMPREHENSIVE EXPLORATION OF CUT-BANK EXPOSURES ALONG A 25-KM-LENGTH OF THE GRAND RIVER. THIS WILL EXAMINE THE SPATIAL EXTENT OF FILLED FISSURES AND LIQUEFACTION FEATURES, AS WELL AS PROVIDE A MEANS OF COLLECTING MATERIAL FOR DATING. FINALLY, WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT SUB-SURFACE INVESTIGATIONS OF THE POTENTIAL DEFORMATION OF THE TRIPLETT TERRACE SURFACE USING SHALLOW SEISMIC IMAGING, AS WELL AS TARGETED EXCAVATIONS OF LIQUEFACTION FEATURES. AGE CONSTRAINTS WILL BE PROVIDED BY RADIOCARBON AND LUMINESCENCE DATING TECHNIQUES.EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS STUDY WILL INCLUDE INITIAL CONSTRAINTS ON THE TIMING OF LIQUEFACTION-INDUCED GROUND SHAKING. SPATIAL EXTENT OF LIQUEFACTION FEATURES WILL ALSO ALLOW INITIAL ESTIMATES OF THE SOURCE AREA AND POTENTIAL MAGNITUDE OF HOLOCENE SEISMICITY. THESE EFFORTS WILL HELP GUIDE FUTURE EFFORTS TO CHARACTERIZE THE FREQUENCY AND INTENSITY OF LIQUEFACTION CAUSING EARTHQUAKES IN THIS REGION INCLUDING IDENTIFYING CANDIDATE SITES FOR FUTURE TRENCHING STUDIES. OTHER DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ACQUIRED GEOSPATIAL DATA (POINT CLOUDS) AND SEISMIC DATA. THE INTENDED DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PRELIMINARY STUDY WILL BE THOSE CONDUCTING EARTHQUAKE HAZARD ASSESSMENTS IN THE CENTRAL UNITED STATES.

PROJECT TITLE:HYBRID EMPIRICAL GROUND-MOTION MODELS WITH SIMULATED-BASED AMPLIFICATION FACTORS FOR THE ISLAND OFHAWAII BASED ON AN UPDATED STRONG GROUND MOTION DATABASEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 7/31/2023THE MAIN PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP GROUND MOTION MODELS (GMMS) WITH SITE  AMPLIFICATION FACTORS FOR THE ISLAND OF HAWAII. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP GMMS USING THE HYBRID  EMPIRICAL METHOD (HEM) WITH A COMPANION SIMULATION-BASED SITE AMPLIFICATION MODEL FOR THE  VS30 REQUIREMENTS OF THE NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPPING (NSHM) PROGRAM (VS30 IS TIME  AVERAGED SHEAR WAVE VELOCITY IN THE UPPER 30 M OF THE SITE). STOCHASTICALLY SIMULATED GROUND  MOTION INTENSITY MEASURES (GMIMS) IN THE HOST AND TARGET REGIONS ARE UTILIZED IN HEM TO DEVELOP  ADJUSTMENT FACTORS THAT ARE APPLIED TO EMPIRICAL GMIM PREDICTIONS IN THE HOST REGION. THE ISLAND  OF HAWAII, THE TARGET REGION IN THIS STUDY, HAS BEEN THE SITE OF NUMEROUS LARGE EARTHQUAKES WITH A  GROWING DATABASE OF STRONG GROUND MOTION OBSERVATIONS. THE CRUSTAL EARTHQUAKES ON THE ISLAND OF  HAWAII ORIGINATE FROM VOLCANIC ACTIVITY AND INCLUDE BOTH SWARMS OF SMALL-MAGNITUDE VOLCANIC  EVENTS AND LARGER TECTONIC EVENTS. GROUND MOTION MODELING ON THE ISLAND OF HAWAII IS CHALLENGING  DUE TO THE DEPTH DISTRIBUTION OF EVENTS AND DIFFERENT ANELASTIC ATTENUATION CHARACTERISTICS. ONLY A  FEW GMMS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED FOR THE ISLAND OF HAWAII, WHICH THEY SUFFER FROM SEVERAL  LIMITATIONS. THE APPLICABILITY OF HEM TO DEVELOP GMMS FOR THE ISLAND OF HAWAII AND THE GROWING  STRONG GROUND MOTION DATA WILL RESULT IN FURTHER IMPROVEMENTS IN THE CAPABILITY OF GMMS. IN  ADDITION, NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS WILL BE PRODUCED FOR A RANGE OF SITE CONDITIONS (AS  REPRESENTED BY VS30) INSTEAD OF A SINGLE REFERENCE CONDITION. IN THE ABSENCE OF AN AMPLIFICATION  MODEL FOR THE ISLAND OF HAWAII, THE PROPOSED SIMULATION-BASED AMPLIFICATION MODEL CAN BE USED  NOT ONLY FOR THE PROPOSED GMMS BUT FOR ALL OTHER PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED GMMS THAT WILL BE  CONSIDERED IN THE UPCOMING NSHM UPDATES.  OUR PROPOSED GMMS DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORK INCLUDES FIVE MAJOR PHASES: A  COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF THE PUBLISHED GMMS (PHASE I), STRONG GROUND MOTION DATABASE COLLECTION  AND PROCESSING (PHASE II), DEVELOPING GMMS AND A SIMULATION-BASED SITE AMPLIFICATION MODEL  (PHASE III), CALIBRATING THE PROPOSED MODELS AND PERFORMING RESIDUAL ANALYSES (PHASE IV), AND  COMPARING THE RESULTS WITH THE AVAILABLE GMMS FOR THE ISLAND OF HAWAII (PHASE V).  SINCE THE HAZARD COMES BOTH FROM SHALLOW CRUSTAL EARTHQUAKES AND FROM DEEP EVENTS FOR  THE ISLAND OF HAWAII, WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP TWO SEPARATE GMMS. FOLLOWING THE HAWAII STATE  HAZARD MAPS, WE WILL CONSIDER THE FOCAL DEPTH OF 20 KM TO DISTINGUISH BETWEEN SHALLOW CRUSTAL AND  DEEP EARTHQUAKES (KLEIN ET AL., 2001). THE PROPOSED GMMS WILL BE DERIVED FOR THE 5%-DAMPED  PSEUDO-ACCELERATION LINEAR-ELASTIC RESPONSE SPECTRA USING ORIENTATION-INDEPENDENT DEFINITIONS OF  HORIZONTAL GROUND MOTION FOR A REFERENCE ROCK SITE WITH VS30 = 760 M/SEC LIKE THE SHEAR-WAVE  VELOCITY IN THE NEAR-SURFACE FOR LAVA SITES IN THE ISLAND OF HAWAII (ABOUT 600 M/SEC). A MOMENT  MAGNITUDE RANGE OF 4.0 TO 7.5 AND JOYNER-BOORE DISTANCES OF UP TO 400 KM WILL BE CONSIDERED.  CONSIDERING WESTERN NORTH AMERICA AS THE HOST REGION, WE WILL USE FIVE NGA-WEST2 GMMS  DEVELOPED BY THE PACIFIC EARTHQUAKE ENGINEERING RESEARCH CENTER. FOR THE REQUIRED SEISMOLOGICAL  PARAMETERS IN WNA, WE WILL USE ZANDIEH ET AL. (2018) RESULTS IN WHICH A SET OF POINT-SOURCE  INVERSIONS HAVE BEEN PERFORMED TO MATCH THE MEDIAN NGA-WEST2 GMMS FOR A NEHRP SITE CLASS  B/C (VS30 = 760 M/SEC). FOR THE REQUIRED SEISMOLOGICAL PARAMETERS IN THE ISLAND OF HAWAII, WE WILL  USE WONG ET AL. (2020) RESULTS

PROJECT TITLE:GROUND MOTION SELECTION FOR ANALYSIS OF NEAR-FAULT CIVIL STRUCTURES USING BROADBAND PHYSICS-BASEDEARTHQUAKE SIMULATIONSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 7/31/2023NONLINEAR ANALYSIS OF CIVIL STRUCTURES SUBJECTED TO EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTIONS IS A CRITICAL PART OF  PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT OF EXISTING STRUCTURES, AND PERFORMANCE-BASED DESIGN OF NEW STRUCTURES.  PROPER SELECTION OF EARTHQUAKE RECORDS FOR A PARTICULAR DESIGN OR ASSESSMENT STUDY IS A KEY  COMPONENT OF NONLINEAR STRUCTURAL RESPONSE ANALYSIS. BECAUSE OF THE SPARSITY OF RECORDED  EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTIONS AT LOCATIONS CLOSE TO ACTIVE FAULTS, THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THESE MOTIONS  ARE DIFFICULT TO UNDERSTAND AND SYSTEMATICALLY ACCOUNT FOR, AND GROUND MOTION PREDICTION MODELS  CONTAIN SIGNIFICANT UNCERTAINTIES FOR LARGE EARTHQUAKES AT SHORT DISTANCES. CONSEQUENTLY, LITTLE  GUIDANCE IS CURRENTLY AVAILABLE ON THE APPROPRIATE SELECTION OF EARTHQUAKE RECORDS FOR PERFORMANCE  ASSESSMENT OF STRUCTURES NEAR ACTIVE FAULTS. AMONG THE CHALLENGES THAT PRECLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT  AND EVALUATION OF SUCH SELECTION PROCEDURES ARE: (1) POOR UNDERSTANDING OF THE LIKELIHOOD AND  PROPERTIES OF STRONG GROUND VELOCITY PULSES IN NEAR-FAULT GROUND MOTIONS, AND THEIR IMPACTS ON  STRUCTURES, (2) DIFFICULTY QUANTIFYING THE LIKELIHOOD AND IMPACTS OF GROUND DISPLACEMENT PULSES ON  NEAR-FAULT STRUCTURES, AND (3) LACK OF UNDERSTANDING OF THE INTERACTION BETWEEN SITE CONDITIONS AND  FAULT RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY EFFECTS AT SHORT DISTANCES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE  AFOREMENTIONED CHALLENGES THROUGH ANALYSIS OF PHYSICS-BASED BROADBAND EARTHQUAKE FAULT RUPTURE  SIMULATIONS, AND THEIR IMPACTS ON MODERN BUILDING STRUCTURES. THE PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE EARTHQUAKE  AND STRUCTURAL SIMULATIONS TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING: (1) IDENTIFY THE CHARACTERISTICS OF NEAR-FAULT  SHAKING THAT ARE MOST IMPORTANT IN PRODUCING HIGH DEMANDS ON STRUCTURES, (2) QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS  OF THE DIFFERENT NEAR-FAULT GROUND MOTION CHARACTERISTICS ON THE RESPONSE OF MODERN LOW-, MID- AND  HIGH-RISE REINFORCED CONCRETE BUILDINGS OF VARIOUS DYNAMIC PROPERTIES, AND (3) DEVELOP STATISTICAL  MODELS AND GENERATE A SET OF GUIDELINES FOR SELECTION OF EARTHQUAKE RECORDS WHICH APPROPRIATELY  REPRESENT THE RISKS EXPECTED FOR STRUCTURES LOCATED IN URBAN AREAS NEAR EARTHQUAKE FAULTS. THE PROJECT  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ANALYSIS OF A LARGE SUITE OF SIMULATED EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTION RECORDS,  ASSESSMENT OF THE SENSITIVITY OF THE RESPONSE OF ARCHETYPICAL BUILDINGS TO NEAR-FAULT GROUND SHAKING,  AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEAR-FAULT EARTHQUAKE RECORD SELECTION MODEL AND GUIDELINES. A TECHNICAL  REPORT WILL BE PRODUCED TO SUMMARIZE THE GUIDANCE AND BEST-PRACTICE CRITERIA FOR SELECTING  EARTHQUAKE RECORDS FOR ENGINEERING RISK ASSESSMENT OF NEAR-FAULT STRUCTURES. IN ADDITION, THE  FINDINGS OF THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLEMENT THE EXISTING PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSIS  PROCEDURES AND THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY HAZARD TOOLS, AND FACILITATE WIDER-SCALE USE OF SIMULATED  EARTHQUAKE GROUND MOTIONS IN ENGINEERING ASSESSMENTS. THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT BOTH  PRACTICING ENGINEERS AND THE EARTHQUAKE RESEARCH COMMUNITY AT THE INTERFACE OF SEISMOLOGY AND  STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING.

PROJECT TITLE:LEVERAGING MACHINE-LEARNING DETECTION AND DETAILED EVENT RELOCATION TO PROBE NEW MADRID SEISMOGENESIS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH SOUTHERN METHODIST UNIVERSITY AND UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 7/31/2023DECADES OF RESEARCH HAS FAILED TO DETERMINE THE PHYSICAL MECHANISM(S) LEADING TO REACTIVATION OF  THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE, THE LARGEST NATURAL EARTHQUAKE ZONE EMBEDDED WITHIN NORTH  AMERICA AND THE LARGEST FOCUS OF SEISMIC HAZARD STUDIES IN THE CENTRAL UNITED STATES. RECENT  ADVANCES IN EARTHQUAKE DETECTION AND ASSOCIATION, FUELED BY RAPID ACCESS TO LARGE VOLUMES OF  CONTINUOUS SEISMIC DATA AND HIGH-PERFORMANCE COMPUTING, ARE POISED TO TRANSFORM OUR  UNDERSTANDING OF INTRAPLATE FAULTS. RECENT FOCUS ON HUMAN-INDUCED EARTHQUAKES ON INTRAPLATE  FAULTS HAS ONLY HIGHLIGHTED THE PUZZLING AND UNANSWERED QUESTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH REACTIVATION OF  FAULTS FAR FROM PLATE BOUNDARIES. THIS STUDY PROVIDES NEW, FUNDAMENTAL EARTHQUAKE DATASETS  THROUGH APPLICATION OF STATE-OF-THE-ART IMPROVEMENTS IN DETECTION, ASSOCIATION AND LOCATION. THE  NEW CATALOG WILL ALLOW FOR UPDATED EARTHQUAKE STATISTICS, IDENTIFICATION OF REPEATING AND CLUSTERED  EARTHQUAKES, AND IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF EARTHQUAKE PHYSICS IN INTRAPLATE FAULT ZONES.  WE WILL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES AND PRODUCTS AS PART OF THIS PROJECT. 1) APPLICATION OF A  MACHINE-LEARNING APPROACH TO BUILD OUT AN EARTHQUAKE CATALOG SENSITIVE TO SMALLER MAGNITUDES  EARTHQUAKE AND EXTENDING IN TIME FROM THE MID-1990S TO PRESENT. THIS WORK TAKES ADVANTAGE OF  THE UNITED STATES ARCHIVE OF PERMANENT AND HIGH-QUALITY TEMPORARY SEISMIC NETWORKS. PRODUCTS: EARTHQUAKE COUNTS, MAGNITUDES, ASSOCIATION, INITIAL LOCATION. 2) EARTHQUAKE MATCHING APPROACHES  TO IMPROVE INPUT DATA ACCURACY FOR HIGH-RESOLUTION EARTHQUAKE LOCATION. PRODUCTS: REDUCED  UNCERTAINTY EARTHQUAKE CATALOG TO SMALLER MAGNITUDE, UPDATED IDENTIFICATION OF SWARM AND  REPEATING EARTHQUAKE SOURCES. 3) HIGH-RESOLUTION EARTHQUAKE LOCATION WITH UPDATED THREEDIMENSIONAL WAVESPEED AND EARTHQUAKE MECHANISM CATALOG. PRODUCTS: COMPRESSIONAL AND SHEAR  CRUSTAL VELOCITY MODELS. 4) INTERPRETATION AND PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT. THE STUDY PROVIDES CORE DATA PRODUCTS AND INTERPRETATIONS REQUESTED FOR THE NATIONAL EARTHQUAKE  HAZARD REDUCTION PROGRAM TO BETTER MITIGATE EARTHQUAKE HAZARD FROM INTRAPLATE EARTHQUAKES IN  THE CENTRAL UNITED STATES. THE UPDATED CATALOG OF NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE EARTHQUAKES WILL  BETTER IMAGE ACTIVE FAULTS AND ALLOW FOR SYSTEMATIC TIME AND SPACE UNDERSTANDING OF FORESHOCKMAINSHOCK-AFTERSHOCK SEQUENCES. DETERMINING THE PHYSICAL MODELS TRIGGERING EARTHQUAKES ALONG  THESE NATURAL INTRAPLATE FAULTS IS KEY TO UNDERSTANDING WHY NEIGHBORING FAULTS DO NOT ACTIVATE. AN  OPEN QUESTION THAT IS ALSO RELEVANT TO HUMAN-INDUCED EARTHQUAKES IS WHY LESS SEISMICALLY ACTIVE  AREAS DO NOT HOST EARTHQUAKES IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES. MITIGATION OF EARTHQUAKE HAZARD OF THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE BENEFITS THE POPULATIONS IN THE  CENTRAL UNITED STATES, PARTICULARLY IN MISSOURI, ILLINOIS, KENTUCKY, TENNESSEE, AND ARKANSAS. POTENTIAL  BENEFITERS INCLUDED THE POPULATIONS IN ALL STATES IN THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN UNITED STATES AND  PARTICULARLY THOSE STATES SUCH AS OKLAHOMA, TEXAS, NEW MEXICO AND COLORADO CURRENTLY  EXPERIENCING EARTHQUAKES INDUCED BY ENERGY INDUSTRY PRACTICES.
