PROJECT TITLE:MAPPING OF A BROAD DEFORMATION ZONE BENEATH SALT LAKE CITYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/15/2022 THROUGH 7/14/2023IMAGING AND CHARACTERIZING ACTIVE FAULTS BENEATH THE WASATCH FRONT URBAN CENTERS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A HIGH PRIORITY BY THE WORKING GROUP ON UTAH EARTHQUAKE PROBABILITIES (WGUEP) TO IMPROVE PROBABILISTIC EARTHQUAKE FORECAST MODELS FOR THE DENSEST POPULATION AREA ALONG THE WASATCH FRONT. I PROPOSE TO IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE ACTIVE FAULTS WITHIN THE SALT LAKE CITY (SLC), UTAH REGION USING SEISMIC IMAGERY. AFTER IDENTIFYING ACTIVE FAULTING ALONG DOWNTOWN SLC PROFILES (LIBERTY ET AL, 2018; 2021A), I PROPOSE TO ADDRESS THREE QUESTIONS WITH A FOCUS ON UNDERSTANDING THE LENGTH, WIDTH AND SLIP HISTORY OF THE WARM SPRINGS FAULT OF THE SALT LAKE CITY SEGMENT OF THE WASATCH FAULT ZONE: OBJECTIVE #1) WHAT IS THE SOUTHERN LIMIT OF THE WARM SPRINGS FAULT(S) THAT EXTENDS THROUGH DOWNTOWN SLC?; OBJECTIVE #2) ARE LATE QUATERNARY-ACTIVE FAULTS DISTRIBUTED ACROSS THE SALT LAKE BASIN OR IS THERE A CLEAR SEPARATION BETWEEN KNOWN INTRABASIN FAULTS (E.G., TAYLORSVILLE) AND THE WARM SPRINGS/EAST BENCH FAULTS?; OBJECTIVE #3) WHAT IS THE LATE QUATERNARY SLIP RATE AND GEOMETRY OF HOLOCENE-ACTIVE FAULTS NEAR THE HALL OF JUSTICE (HJ) EXCAVATION TRENCH SITE? IN ADDITION TO A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT SUBMITTED TO THE USGS THAT DESCRIBES THE OBJECTIVE OUTCOMES, I WILL PREPARE A TECHNICAL MANUSCRIPT FOR JOURNAL PUBLICATION. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL BE PROVIDED TO WGUEP AND RELEVANT RESULTS WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO EARTHQUAKE HAZARD MODELS FOR THE WASATCH FRONT. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS OF THIS AWARD.

PROJECT TITLE:DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF DAMAGE MATRICES FOR UNITED STATES BUILDINGS IN ACCORDANCE WITHEMS-98: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH APPLIED TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL AND USGSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/15/2022 THROUGH 7/14/2023THE EXTENT OF THE FELT AREA AND THE GEOGRAPHICAL DISTRIBUTION OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING ARE  ESSENTIAL INFORMATION NEEDED IN EARTHQUAKE RESPONSE. THESE ARE OBTAINED WITH THE USE OF  MACROSEISMIC INTENSITY, WHICH DESCRIBES THE DEGREE OF GROUND SHAKING USING DIFFERENT MEASURES,  INCLUDING THE EXTENT OF THE BUILDING DAMAGE. MACROSEISMIC INTENSITY IS ALSO USED WITHIN U.S.  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) SHAKEALERT EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING (EEW) SYSTEM.  MACROSEISMIC INTENSITY IS ASSIGNED USING MACROSEISMIC SCALES THAT DESCRIBE OBSERVATIONS AT  DIFFERENT INTENSITY LEVELS (USUALLY I TO XII) BASED ON EARTHQUAKE EFFECTS ON PEOPLE, OBJECTS,  BUILDINGS, AND THE ENVIRONMENT. THE MODIFIED MERCALLI INTENSITY (MMI) SCALE IS MOST COMMONLY  USED IN THE UNITED STATES. THE USGS "DID YOU FEEL IT" (DYFI) SYSTEM RELIES ON RAPIDLY  COLLECTING MACROSEISMIC INTENSITY DATA FROM INTERNET USERS' SHAKING AND DAMAGE REPORTS FOR  GENERATING INTENSITY MAPS IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING FELT EARTHQUAKES. THE SYSTEM HAS BEEN IN  OPERATION FOR OVER TWO DECADES, AND OVER THE PAST 15 YEARS, SEVERAL INTERNATIONAL SEISMOLOGICAL INSTITUTIONS HAVE ALSO IMPLEMENTED SIMILAR ALGORITHMS. HOWEVER, THIS APPROACH HAS A KNOWN  LIMITATION: IT IS INADEQUATE FOR ASSIGNING INTENSITY VALUES GREATER THAN VIII WHEN SIGNIFICANT  BUILDING DAMAGE OCCURS. ABOVE THIS INTENSITY, ROBUST INTENSITY ASSIGNMENTS REQUIRE ENGINEERING  KNOWLEDGE OF BUILDING TYPE AND DAMAGE LEVELS, SUCH AS ENGINEERING OR PRESS REPORTS AND FIELD  RECONNAISSANCE. WITH THE NEED TO HAVE SEISMOLOGISTS AND ENGINEERS REVIEW THE HIGHER INTENSITY  ASSIGNMENTS, THE PROBLEM OF HOW TO AUTOMATICALLY EVALUATE AND ASSIGN HIGHER SHAKING INTENSITIES  HAS NOT YET BEEN FULLY SOLVED. THE EUROPEAN MACROSEISMIC SCALE (EMS-98, GRUNTHAL, 1998) PROVIDES DETAILED GUIDELINES ON  ASSIGNING INTENSITIES ABOVE VIII AND HAS BEEN IN USE FOR OVER 15 YEARS. HOWEVER, EMS-98 IS NOT  APPLICABLE IN THE UNITED STATES (AND NEW ZEALAND, AMONG OTHER COUNTRIES) BECAUSE DOMESTIC  STRUCTURE TYPES ARE NOT REPRESENTED IN THE DAMAGE MATRICES THAT FORM THE BASIS OF THE METHOD. THIS  LIMITATION ALSO INHIBITS IMPLEMENTATION OF A GLOBALLY APPLICABLE MACROSEISMIC INTENSITY SCALE. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP NECESSARY EXTENSIONS TO EMS-98 METHODOLOGY FOR USE WITH THE U.S.  BUILDING STOCK. THE WORK WILL INCLUDE A REVIEW OF THE COMMON BUILDING TYPES IN THE U.S. AND ASSIGNMENT OF EACH TO A VULNERABILITY CLASS; A REVIEW OF THE INTENSITY DEFINITIONS IN EMS-98;  DEFINITIONS OF DAMAGE GRADES THAT ARE APPROPRIATE FOR THE STRUCTURE TYPES IDENTIFIED; AND AN  EVALUATION OF THE PROPOSED INTENSITY LEVELS AGAINST INTENSITY LEVELS ASSIGNED BY EXISTING METHODS FOR PAST EARTHQUAKE EVENTS. THE WORK WILL ALSO INCLUDE EXTENSION OF THE EMS-98 METHODOLOGY FOR  USE WITH THE NEW ZEALAND BUILDING STOCK TO BENEFIT FROM THE SIMILARITIES IN STRUCTURE TYPES, AS WELL  AS AVAILABILITY OF DOCUMENTED DAMAGE INFORMATION IN THIS COUNTRY FROM RECENT EARTHQUAKES. THE PROJECT RESULTS, IMPLEMENTED IN CONJUNCTION WITH EXISTING EMS-98 GUIDANCE, WILL ALLOW  ASSIGNMENT OF MACROSEISMIC INTENSITIES FOR MODERATE-TO-LARGE EARTHQUAKES IN THE UNITED STATES AND  NEW ZEALAND, CONSISTENT WITH INFORMATION COLLECTED IN EUROPE FOR THE LAST 15 YEARS. THE PROJECT  FINDINGS WILL BE DOCUMENTED IN A COMPREHENSIVE AND ILLUSTRATED GUIDE TO ENABLE ASSIGNING A  RELIABLE INTENSITY LEVEL FOR THE AREA OF INTEREST. THIS CAPABILITY WILL FACILITATE FAST GEOGRAPHICAL  DAMAGE DISTRIBUTIONS FOLLOWING A DAMAGING EARTHQUAKE. MOREOVER, RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT CAN  BE USED IN DISCUSSIONS TOWARDS THE GENERATION OF AN INTERNATIONAL MACROSEISMIC SCALE TO USE AT A  GLOBAL LEVEL AND IDENTIFY NECESSARY TOOLS FOR POST-EARTHQUAKE MACROSEISMIC DATA COLLECTION.

PROJECT TITLE:GEOPHYSICAL AND PALEOSEISMOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS OF THE MARIANNA EARTHQUAKE SOURCE IN EAST-CENTRAL ARKANSASPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 8/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THIS PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO FURTHER ELUCIDATE THE EARTHQUAKE HISTORY OF THE SOURCE OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES NEAR MARIANNA, ARKANSAS, AND THEREBY IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE  RECURRENCE TIMES OF LARGE-MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKES AND THE LONG-TERM BEHAVIOR OF THE MARIANNA  SOURCE. THE NORTHWEST-ORIENTED DAYTONA BEACH LINEAMENT, MARKED BY LARGE SAND BLOWS, APPEARS  TO BE THE SURFACE EXPRESSION OF A FAULT ZONE IMAGED BELOW IN SEISMIC REFLECTION PROFILES. THE  SAND BLOWS FORMED AS THE RESULT OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES CIRCA 4.8, 5.5, AND 9.9 KA, AND AT LEAST TWO  EARLIER EVENTS BETWEEN 11 KA AND 41 KA, AND LIKELY RECORD SLIP EVENTS ON THE UNDERLYING FAULT  ZONE. RESULTS OF OUR RECENT INVESTIGATIONS AT TWO LIQUEFACTION SITES ALONG THE LINEAMENT ADD  CONFIDENCE IN THESE INTERPRETATIONS AND ALSO POINT TO THE NEED FOR MORE DATING OF LATE PLEISTOCENE  SAND BLOWS IN ORDER TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE PALEOEARTHQUAKE HISTORY AND BEHAVIOR OF THE FAULT  ZONE. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE EARTHQUAKE HISTORY OF THE MARIANNA AREA ALSO WILL PROVIDE  INSIGHTS REGARDING SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL MIGRATION OF SEISMICITY ACROSS THE REGION, INCLUDING THE  NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE, WHICH WILL HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPLICATIONS FOR EARTHQUAKE HAZARD  ASSESSMENT IN THE CENTRAL UNITED STATES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE GEOPHYSICAL AND PALEOSEISMOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS OF THREE  LIQUEFACTION SITES, AS WELL AS COLLECTION AND DATING OF SAMPLES AT TWO PREVIOUSLY STUDIED SITES, TO  FURTHER ASSESS THE EARTHQUAKE POTENTIAL OF THE FAULT ZONE BENEATH THE DAYTONA BEACH LINEAMENT  SOUTHWEST OF MARIANNA, ARKANSAS.  PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: - THREE-DIMENSIONAL GPR PROFILES OF LARGE SAND BLOWS AND RELATED DIKES USED TO POSITION PALEOSEIMIC TRENCHES AT 3-5 SITES; - TRENCH LOGS AND DESCRIPTIONS OF LIQUEFACTION FEATURES, FAULTS, AND HOST DEPOSITS; - PHOTOGRAPHS OF SIGNIFICANT FEATURES INCLUDING LIQUEFACTION FEATURES AND FAULTS EXPOSED IN  TRENCHES;  - TABLES OF THE RESULTS OF RADIOCARBON AND OSL DATING OF SAMPLES COLLECTED IN THE TRENCHES; - UPDATED PALEOLIQUEFACTION DATABASE AND UPDATED REGIONAL AND LOCAL MAPS SHOWING  LOCATIONS, SIZES, AND AGE ESTIMATES OF SAND BLOWS AND RELATED SAND DIKES FOR THE MARIANNA  AREA; - A MAP ILLUSTRATING THE PALEOEARTHQUAKE HISTORY OF THE MARIANNA SOURCE AND OTHER  SEISMIC SOURCES IN THE REGION, INCLUDING THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE; - A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT SUBMITTED TO THE EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS PROGRAM AND A SCIENTIFIC  ARTICLE SUBMITTED TO THE BULLETIN OF THE SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA OR THE EASTERN  SECTION OF SEISMOLOGICAL RESEARCH LETTERS FOR PUBLICATION. THIS PROJECT IS LIKELY TO PRODUCE NEW INFORMATION ABOUT THE TIMING, MAGNITUDE, AND RECURRENCE OF  PALEOEARTHQUAKES IN THE MARIANNA AREA THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE NATIONAL PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC  HAZARD MAP, THE NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL, AND REGIONAL ASSESSMENTS OF EARTHQUAKE  HAZARDS INCLUDING THE METROPOLITAN AREAS OF MEMPHIS, TENNESSEE, AND LITTLE ROCK, ARKANSAS.

PROJECT TITLE:DYNAMIC RUPTURE INTERACTIONS IN THE NEW MADRID FAULT SYSTEMPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE (NMSZ) IS CHARACTERIZED BY A COMPLEX SYSTEM OF STRIKE-SLIP AND THRUST  FAULTS WITH THE ABILITY TO PRODUCE LARGE DAMAGING EARTHQUAKES. THE 1811-12 EARTHQUAKES, AS WELL AS  PALEOSEISMIC EVIDENCE OF PRIOR EVENTS, SUGGESTS THAT LARGE EARTHQUAKES IN THE NMSZ OCCUR AS SEQUENCES OF  MULTIPLE DISCRETE RUPTURES AND IMPLIES THAT THE COMPLEXITY AND SEVERITY OF THESE LARGE EVENTS DEPENDS ON  FAULT GEOMETRY AND PRE-STRESS CONDITIONS. UNRAVELING THE 1811-1812 EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCE WILL PROVIDE  INSIGHT INTO IMPORTANT PARAMETERS THAT INFLUENCE THE RUPTURE PROCESS AND FAULT INTERACTION IN THE NMSZ.  THEREFORE, SPECIFYING THE MOSTLY LIKELY RUPTURE SCENARIOS IN THE NMSZ INCLUDING THE NUCLEATION LOCATIONS  AND MAGNITUDES CAN HELP IMPROVE ESTIMATES OF THE SEISMIC HAZARD AND MAXIMIZE MITIGATION EFFORTS. WE  PROPOSE TO RUN A SERIES OF DYNAMIC RUPTURE SIMULATIONS TO EXPLORE THE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN THE MAJOR FAULTS  IN THE NMSZ AND THE LIKELIHOOD OF MULTI-FAULT RUPTURE SCENARIOS. WE WILL SYSTEMICALLY INVESTIGATE RUPTURE  PARAMETERS SUCH AS FAULT PRE-STRESS CONDITIONS, EARTHQUAKE NUCLEATION LOCATION, FAULT GEOMETRY, AND GEOLOGIC  LAYERING AND EVALUATE THEIR EFFECTS ON THE RUPTURE PROPAGATION AND FINAL SLIP (MAGNITUDE). THIS WORK DIRECTLY  ADDRESSES CEUS ELEMENT I REGIONAL EARTHQUAKE HAZARD ASSESSMENTS "ASSESS THE SEISMIC POTENTIAL OF  EARTHQUAKE SOURCE ZONES AND ACTIVE FAULTS IN THE CEUS USING GEOLOGICAL, PALEOSEISMOLOGICAL, PALEOTSUNAMI,  SEISMOLOGICAL, MACHINE LEARNING, AND GEOPHYSICAL STUDIES, AND ANALYSES OF HISTORICAL ACCOUNTS" AS WELL AS  CEUS ELEMENT II: EARTHQUAKE INFORMATION, MONITORING AND NOTIFICATION "ESTIMATE EARTHQUAKE SOURCE  CHARACTERISTICS, CALIBRATE SEISMIC MAGNITUDE SCALES, AND CHARACTERIZE WAVE PROPAGATION AND ATTENUATION IN  THE CEUS INCLUDING BASIN EFFECTS"

PROJECT TITLE:INVESTIGATION OF LIQUEFACTION MANIFESTATIONS IN SEARLES LAKE DURING THE 2019 RIDGECREST EARTHQUAKESEQUENCEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO INVESTIGATE SOIL CONDITIONS WITHIN THE PERIMETER OF SEARLES LAKE, WHERE PATTERNS OF GROUND FAILURE / NON-GROUND FAILURE WERE OBSERVED FOLLOWING THE 2019 RIDGECREST EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCE. WE POSTULATE THAT THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF GROUND FAILURE IS THE RESULT OF VARIATIONS IN THE CONSISTENCY OF THE SOIL WITHIN THE LAKEBED DEPOSITS, WHERE CLAYEY LACUSTRINE DEPOSITS ARE INTERMINGLED WITH SANDY ALLUVIAL DEPOSITS. CLAYEY SOILS ARE CONSIDERED NON-SUSCEPTIBLE TO LIQUEFACTION WHILE SANDY SOILS ARE CONSIDERED SUSCEPTIBLE. HOWEVER, THE TRANSITION BETWEEN THE TWO IS CURRENTLY NOT WELL-INFORMED BY FIELD OBSERVATIONS AND LABORATORY TEST DATA. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO OBTAIN IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THE CONSISTENCY OF THE SOILS WITHIN THE MARGIN OF SEARLES LAKE ACROSS TRANSITIONS WHERE GROUND FAILURE WAS OBSERVED TO HAVE OCCURRED AND TO HAVE NOT OCCURRED.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WE PLAN TO PERFORM A GEOTECHNICAL SITE INVESTIGATION CONSISTING OF CONE PENETRATION TESTING AND SHEAR WAVE VELOCITY MEASUREMENTS. THESE TESTS WILL BE PERFORMED IN COORDINATION WITH SEARLES VALLEY MINERALS, WHO OPERATES A MINE WITHIN THE MARGIN OF THE LAKEBED. WHILE AT THE SITE, WE WILL PERFORM GROUND MOTION MEASUREMENTS OF MICROTREMORS (I.E., SMALL EARTHQUAKES) TO GAIN INSIGHTS INTO THE MANNER IN WHICH SOILS AT THE SITE AMPLIFY GROUND MOTIONS. WE WILL USE THESE DATA TO INFORM MODELING OF GROUND MOTION INTENSITIES WITHIN THE MARGIN OF SEARLES LAKE THAT OCCURRED DURING THE TWO PRIMARY EARTHQUAKES IN 2019. WE PLAN TO CURATE AND PUBLISH OUR COLLECTED DATA AND MAKE IT PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH THE NEXT GENERATION LIQUEFACTION WEBSITE (HTTPS://WWW.NEXTGENERATIONLIQUEFACTION.ORG/). FINALLY, WE WILL SYNTHESIZE OUR FINDINGS, DRAW CONCLUSIONS ABOUT SUSCEPTIBILITY OF THE SOILS AT SEARLES LAKE, AND PUBLISH THOSE FINDINGS IN A FINAL PROJECT REPORT, JOURNAL PAPERS, AND POTENTIALLY CONFERENCE PAPERS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DELIVERABLES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A PUBLISHED DATASET CONTAINING ALL OF THE GEOTECHNICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL MEASUREMENTS PERFORMED AS PART OF THE PROJECT. THESE DATASETS WILL BE CURATED, PUBLISHED, AND ASSIGNED A DIGITAL OBJECT IDENTIFIER (DOI) SO THAT THEY ARE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE. WE WILL ALSO PRODUCE REPORTS AND PAPERS FROM THIS WORK TO DISSEMINATE OUR FINDINGS TO THE COMMUNITY.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES OF THE WORK WILL BE GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEERS, WHO OFTEN STRUGGLE WITH DECISIONS REGARDING SUSCEPTIBILITY OF SOILS TO LIQUEFACTION BASED ON THEIR CONSISTENCY. LIQUEFACTION SUSCEPTIBILITY CONTAINS SIGNIFICANT UNCERTAINTY, AND CLARIFYING THESE ASPECTS OF BEHAVIOR AT SEARLES LAKE WILL PROVIDE AN IMPORTANT DATA POINT TO HELP CLARIFY GROUND FAILURE POTENTIAL.

PROJECT TITLE:SITE AMPLIFICATION IN SAN FRANCISCO BAY REGION SEDIMENTARY BASINS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITHUCLA AND USCPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023SEISMIC SITE RESPONSE IS INFLUENCED BY AMPLIFICATION ABOVE IMPEDANCE CONTRASTS, RESONANCE, NONLINEARITY, TOPOGRAPHIC EFFECTS, AND AMPLIFICATION RELATED TO TWO- OR THREE-DIMENSIONAL WAVE PROPAGATION IN SEDIMENTARY BASINS. ERGODIC SITE RESPONSE MODELS AVERAGE THESE EFFECTS OVER MANY SITES GLOBALLY WITH CONDITIONING ON TIME-AVERAGED VELOCITY IN THE UPPER 30 M (VS30) AND, IN SOME CASES, ON BASIN DEPTH PARAMETERS. THE CONTRIBUTION OF BASIN AMPLIFICATION CAN BE LOOSELY ASSOCIATED WITH AN AVERAGE DEPTH CONDITIONAL ON VS30. BASIN AMPLIFICATION MODELS ARE 'CENTERED', IN THE SENSE THAT THEY PREDICT CHANGES IN AMPLIFICATION AT LONG PERIODS FOR DEPTHS DIFFERENT FROM THAT AVERAGE. FOR LONG-PERIOD GROUND MOTIONS, SUCH MODELS PREDICT DE-AMPLIFICATION (LESS THAN PROVIDED BY THE VS30-SCALING FUNCTION) FOR SHALLOWER DEPTHS, AND AMPLIFICATION FOR LARGER DEPTHS. THIS PROPOSAL IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH TO DEVELOP REGIONAL ERGODIC MODELS FOR THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA (SFBA) REGION OF CALIFORNIA, IN CONSIDERATION OF LOCAL GEOLOGICAL CONDITIONS.THE NGA-WEST2 VS30-BASED SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS FORM THE PRIMARY BASIS FOR ERGODIC SITE EFFECT MODELING IN THE USGS SEISMIC HAZARDS MAPS FOR THE WESTERN US. THE 2018 VERSION OF THE MAPS INCORPORATED FOR THE FIRST TIME SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS CONDITIONED IN PART ON SEDIMENT DEPTHS DERIVED FROM REGIONAL SEISMIC VELOCITY MODELS (PETERSEN ET AL. 2020; POWERS ET AL. 2021). MODEL COMPONENTS REQUIRED FOR SUCH ANALYSES, AND THEIR LIMITATIONS FOR SFBA, ARE AS FOLLOWS:- CENTERING: THE DEPTH COMPONENT OF THE SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS USES DIFFERENTIAL DEPTH (DEPTH MINUS VS30-CONDITIONED MEAN). CURRENT RELATIONS FOR MEAN DEPTH APPLY FOR BROAD REGIONS (CALIFORNIA, JAPAN), AND ARE LIKELY BIASED FOR SFBA.- MEAN AMPLIFICATION: THE DEPTH COMPONENT OF THE SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS WERE DERIVED USING A COMBINED DATA SET FOR JAPAN AND CALIFORNIA. REGIONAL VARIATIONS ARE NOT CAPTURED.- ALEATORY VARIABILITY: NGA-WEST2 ALEATORY VARIABILITY MODELS DO NOT SEPARATE BASIN FROM NON-BASIN SITE CONDITIONS, WHICH ARE NOW RECOGNIZED AS HAVING DIFFERENCES (LOWER SITE-TO-SITE VARIABILITIES ARE ENCOUNTERED IN BASINS).WE HAVE RECENTLY REGIONALIZED EACH OF THE ABOVE ISSUES FOR SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, PROVIDING MORE ACCURATE MEAN AMPLIFICATION MODELS AND REDUCED UNCERTAINTIES. THIS RESEARCH WILL DEVELOP REGIONAL MODELS FOR MEAN SITE AMPLIFICATION AND ALEATORY VARIABILITY FOR APPLICATION TO SFBA.THERE ARE TWO PHASES OF PROPOSED WORK - (1) DATA COLLECTION AND SYNTHESIS AND (2) GROUND MOTION ANALYSIS AND INTERPRETATION. THE DATA ELEMENT WILL BENEFIT FROM ONGOING WORK INVESTIGATING SITE AMPLIFICATION FOR THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA REGION. THAT DATA SET CONSISTS OF 14,327 THREE-COMPONENT RECORDINGS FROM 199 NORTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKES WITH M > 4 AND WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED IN THE PRESENT WORK. USING SEISMIC VELOCITY MODELS FROM AAGAARD ET AL. (2021), WE WILL WE WILL INVESTIGATE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN VS30 AND MEAN DEPTH FOR SFBA. THIS WILL REGIONALIZE THE CENTERING COMPONENT.THE ANALYSIS COMPONENT WILL ESTIMATE MEAN SITE AMPLIFICATION AND ITS UNCERTAINTY FOR SFBA SITES USING NON-ERGODIC PROCEDURES. USING THESE RESULTS, NGA-WEST2 VS30-SCALING MODELS WILL BE CHECKED FOR REGIONAL ACCURACY AND ADJUSTED AS NEEDED. PORTIONS OF THE SITE AMPLIFICATION NOT EXPLAINED BY VS30 WILL BE RELATED TO DIFFERENTIAL DEPTH IN CONSIDERATION OF POTENTIAL VARIATIONS ACROSS GEOMORPHIC PROVINCES. THE RESULTING MODELS ARE LIKELY TO MODIFY SITE AMPLIFICATION AT LONG PERIODS, SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTING SEISMIC DESIGN IN SFBA.

PROJECT TITLE:SITE AMPLIFICATION IN SAN FRANCISCO BAY REGION SEDIMENTARY BASINS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITHUCLA AND USCPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023SEISMIC SITE RESPONSE IS INFLUENCED BY AMPLIFICATION ABOVE IMPEDANCE CONTRASTS, RESONANCE, NONLINEARITY, TOPOGRAPHIC EFFECTS, AND AMPLIFICATION RELATED TO TWO- OR THREE-DIMENSIONAL WAVE PROPAGATION IN SEDIMENTARY BASINS. ERGODIC SITE RESPONSE MODELS AVERAGE THESE EFFECTS OVER MANY SITES GLOBALLY WITH CONDITIONING ON TIME-AVERAGED VELOCITY IN THE UPPER 30 M (VS30) AND, IN SOME CASES, ON BASIN DEPTH PARAMETERS. THE CONTRIBUTION OF BASIN AMPLIFICATION CAN BE LOOSELY ASSOCIATED WITH AN AVERAGE DEPTH CONDITIONAL ON VS30. BASIN AMPLIFICATION MODELS ARE 'CENTERED', IN THE SENSE THAT THEY PREDICT CHANGES IN AMPLIFICATION AT LONG PERIODS FOR DEPTHS DIFFERENT FROM THAT AVERAGE. FOR LONG-PERIOD GROUND MOTIONS, SUCH MODELS PREDICT DE-AMPLIFICATION (LESS THAN PROVIDED BY THE VS30-SCALING FUNCTION) FOR SHALLOWER DEPTHS, AND AMPLIFICATION FOR LARGER DEPTHS. THIS PROPOSAL IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH TO DEVELOP REGIONAL ERGODIC MODELS FOR THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA (SFBA) REGION OF CALIFORNIA, IN CONSIDERATION OF LOCAL GEOLOGICAL CONDITIONS.THE NGA-WEST2 VS30-BASED SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS FORM THE PRIMARY BASIS FOR ERGODIC SITE EFFECT MODELING IN THE USGS SEISMIC HAZARDS MAPS FOR THE WESTERN US. THE 2018 VERSION OF THE MAPS INCORPORATED FOR THE FIRST TIME SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS CONDITIONED IN PART ON SEDIMENT DEPTHS DERIVED FROM REGIONAL SEISMIC VELOCITY MODELS (PETERSEN ET AL. 2020; POWERS ET AL. 2021). MODEL COMPONENTS REQUIRED FOR SUCH ANALYSES, AND THEIR LIMITATIONS FOR SFBA, ARE AS FOLLOWS:- CENTERING: THE DEPTH COMPONENT OF THE SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS USES DIFFERENTIAL DEPTH (DEPTH MINUS VS30-CONDITIONED MEAN). CURRENT RELATIONS FOR MEAN DEPTH APPLY FOR BROAD REGIONS (CALIFORNIA, JAPAN), AND ARE LIKELY BIASED FOR SFBA.- MEAN AMPLIFICATION: THE DEPTH COMPONENT OF THE SITE AMPLIFICATION MODELS WERE DERIVED USING A COMBINED DATA SET FOR JAPAN AND CALIFORNIA. REGIONAL VARIATIONS ARE NOT CAPTURED.- ALEATORY VARIABILITY: NGA-WEST2 ALEATORY VARIABILITY MODELS DO NOT SEPARATE BASIN FROM NON-BASIN SITE CONDITIONS, WHICH ARE NOW RECOGNIZED AS HAVING DIFFERENCES (LOWER SITE-TO-SITE VARIABILITIES ARE ENCOUNTERED IN BASINS).WE HAVE RECENTLY REGIONALIZED EACH OF THE ABOVE ISSUES FOR SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, PROVIDING MORE ACCURATE MEAN AMPLIFICATION MODELS AND REDUCED UNCERTAINTIES. THIS RESEARCH WILL DEVELOP REGIONAL MODELS FOR MEAN SITE AMPLIFICATION AND ALEATORY VARIABILITY FOR APPLICATION TO SFBA.THERE ARE TWO PHASES OF PROPOSED WORK - (1) DATA COLLECTION AND SYNTHESIS AND (2) GROUND MOTION ANALYSIS AND INTERPRETATION. THE DATA ELEMENT WILL BENEFIT FROM ONGOING WORK INVESTIGATING SITE AMPLIFICATION FOR THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA REGION. THAT DATA SET CONSISTS OF 14,327 THREE-COMPONENT RECORDINGS FROM 199 NORTHERN CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKES WITH M > 4 AND WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED IN THE PRESENT WORK. USING SEISMIC VELOCITY MODELS FROM AAGAARD ET AL. (2021), WE WILL INVESTIGATE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN VS30 AND MEAN DEPTH FOR SFBA. THIS WILL REGIONALIZE THE CENTERING COMPONENT.THE ANALYSIS COMPONENT WILL ESTIMATE MEAN SITE AMPLIFICATION AND ITS UNCERTAINTY FOR SFBA SITES USING NON-ERGODIC PROCEDURES. USING THESE RESULTS, NGA-WEST2 VS30-SCALING MODELS WILL BE CHECKED FOR REGIONAL ACCURACY AND ADJUSTED AS NEEDED. PORTIONS OF THE SITE AMPLIFICATION NOT EXPLAINED BY VS30 WILL BE RELATED TO DIFFERENTIAL DEPTH IN CONSIDERATION OF POTENTIAL VARIATIONS ACROSS GEOMORPHIC PROVINCES. THE RESULTING MODELS ARE LIKELY TO MODIFY SITE AMPLIFICATION AT LONG PERIODS, SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTING SEISMIC DESIGN IN SFBA.

PROJECT TITLE:PALEOSEISMIC TRENCHING OF THE WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONE, UTAHPERIOD OF PERFOMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023IN UTAH, MORE THAN 75% OF THE STATE'S POPULATION AND ECONOMY ARE CONCENTRATED ALONG THE  WASATCH URBAN CORRIDOR, WHICH PARTIALLY CORRESPONDS WITH THE LOCATION OF EARTHQUAKE-PRODUCING  FAULT SYSTEMS LIKE THE WASATCH AND WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONES. URBAN DEVELOPMENT DOMINATES THE  LANDSCAPE, MEANING STUDYING THE GEOLOGY OF PAST EARTHQUAKES IS DIFFICULT. THE WEST VALLEY FAULT  ZONE CUTS THROUGH A HIGHLY URBANIZED PART OF THE SALT LAKE VALLEY AND YET HAS HAD LIMITED  KNOWLEDGE OF WHEN PAST EARTHQUAKES HAPPENED AND HOW STRONG THEY WERE. PREVIOUS SCIENTIFIC  INVESTIGATIONS HAVE SHOWN RECURRENT SURFACE RUPTURING EARTHQUAKES IN THE PAST 11,700 YEARS, AND  SUGGEST THE LIKELIHOOD OF SYNCHRONOUS RUPTURE OF THE WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONE DURING FUTURE LARGEMAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKES ON THE WASATCH FAULT ZONE. ADDITIONALLY, THE LOCATION OF AFTERSHOCKS FROM  THE 2020 MAGNITUDE 5.7 MAGNA, UTAH EARTHQUAKE SUGGEST A CONNECTION BETWEEN THE WASATCH AND  THE WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONES. OUR INVESTIGATION WILL EXCAVATE INTO A SMALL HILL CREATED BY MULTIPLE  EARTHQUAKES ON THE WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONE, AND EXPOSE SOIL AND SEDIMENTS THAT PRESERVE THE  GEOLOGICAL CONTEXT OF PAST EARTHQUAKES. DOCUMENTING, SAMPLING, AND STUDYING THESE "FOSSILIZED  EARTHQUAKES" WILL HELP US DETERMINE WHEN AND HOW LARGE PAST EARTHQUAKES HAVE BEEN ON THE  TAYLORSVILLE FAULT OF THE WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONE. WE WILL EXCAVATE ONE TRENCH AND USE STATE-OFTHE-ART DOCUMENTATION TO DETERMINE THE SIZE OF PAST EARTHQUAKES, AND SOIL DATING TECHNIQUES TO  DETERMINE TIMING. THE RESULTS OF THIS INVESTIGATION WILL BENEFIT BOTH THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY BUT  ALSO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY LIVING AND WORKING ON THE WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONE THROUGH PROVIDING  NEW DATA TO IMPROVE MODELING OF WEST VALLEY FAULT ZONE EARTHQUAKE BEHAVIOR AND BETTER  UNDERSTANDING OF THE SEISMIC HAZARD TO THE GREATER SALT LAKE CITY AREA. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL HIRE  TWO STUDENTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF UTAH'S MASTER OF SCIENCE FOR SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS  (MSSST) PROGRAM WHO TEACH IN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. MSSST SUPPORTS MOTIVATED TEACHERS TO  EARN A MASTER OF SCIENCE DEGREE WHILE STILL ACTIVELY ENGAGING IN CLASSROOM TEACHING. THIS  PROPOSED WORK WILL HELP MSSST STUDENTS BRING THEIR RESEARCH EXPERIENCE AND EXPERTISE IN  EARTHQUAKE GEOLOGY INTO THEIR SECONDARY SCHOOL CLASSROOM CURRICULUMS IN THE VERY COMMUNITIES  THAT WOULD BE AFFECTED BY A LARGE-MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKE ON THE WASATCH FAULT ZONE. FINALLY, WE  PLAN TO PERFORM FIELD REVIEWS FOR TECHNICAL AS WELL AS PUBLIC AUDIENCES, INCLUDING PRESS,  GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, AND SPANISH LANGUAGE NEWS OUTLETS AND GROUPS.

PROJECT TITLE: INVESTIGATING CONTROLS OF FAULT-DIP CHANGES ON RUPTURE BEHAVIOR ALONG THE MOJAVE SECTION OF THE SAN ANDREAS FAULTPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023A "BIG ONE" EARTHQUAKE HAS BEEN FORECASTED TO OCCUR ON THE SOUTHERN SAN ANDREAS FAULT (SSAF) IN CALIFORNIA, BASED ON HISTORICAL EARTHQUAKE RECORDS AND GEOLOGIC (PALEOSEISMIC) DATA. THIS BIG ONE IMPOSES SIGNIFICANT HAZARDS TO SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AND THE SURROUNDING AREAS. UNDERSTANDING PHYSICAL CONTROLS ON RUPTURE BEHAVIORS OF PAST EARTHQUAKES HAS IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR FORECASTING POSSIBLE RUPTURE EXTENTS AND PATTERNS OF FUTURE EVENTS, WHICH WILL DETERMINE LEVELS AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTIONS OF STRONG GROUND MOTION THAT CAN CAUSE DESTRUCTION AND DAMAGE TO THE SOCIETY. A PUZZLING FEATURE IN PAST EARTHQUAKE RUPTURES IS THAT THE RELATIVELY STRAIGHT MOJAVE SECTION OF THE SSAF (ALONG ITS SURFACE TRACE) EXPERIENCED FEWER EARTHQUAKES THAN ITS SURROUNDING SECTIONS, INCLUDING THE BIG BEND SECTION TO THE NORTHWEST AND THE SAN BERNARDINO SECTION TO THE SOUTHEAST WHERE FAULT TRACE GEOMETRY IS MORE COMPLEX. SUBSURFACE FAULT-DIP CHANGES ALONG THE STRIKE OF SSAF REVEALED BY PREVIOUS GEOPHYSICAL STUDIES HAVE BEEN PROPOSED TO PLAY A DOMINANT ROLE IN SOLVING THIS PUZZLE. THIS QUALITATIVE HYPOTHESIS NEEDS TO BE TESTED AND INVESTIGATED.IN THIS PROJECT, THE PI'S GROUP WILL USE A NEWLY DEVELOPED PHYSICS-BASED NUMERICAL MODELING APPROACH TO ADDRESS THE QUESTION. IN THIS APPROACH, THE COSEISMIC DYNAMIC EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE IS PLACED IN THE CONTEXT OF AN EARTHQUAKE CYCLE THAT INCLUDES OTHER QUASI-STATIC DEFORMATION PROCESSES THAT LEAD TO DYNAMIC EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE. THEREFORE, DYNAMIC EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE EXTENTS AND PATTERNS WILL SPONTANEOUSLY EVOLVE OVER MULTIPLE EARTHQUAKE CYCLES AND WILL BE CONSISTENT WITH FAULT GEOMETRY AND RUPTURE HISTORIES IN THIS APPROACH. THEY WILL BUILD MULTICYCLE DYNAMIC MODELS OF GEOMETRICALLY COMPLEX SSAF AND RUN THESE MODELS ON HIGH-PERFORMANCE COMPUTING (HPC) SYSTEMS. BY SIMULATING THESE MODELS AND ANALYZING THE RESULTS FROM THESE MODELS, THEY WILL INVESTIGATE RUPTURE EXTENTS AND PATTERNS ALONG THE SSAF AND ROLES OF SUBSURFACE FAULT-DIP CHANGES IN CONTROLLING RUPTURE BEHAVIORS OF THE SSAF. THEY WILL VARY MODEL PARAMETERS, INCLUDING FAULT-DIP CHANGES ALONG THE STRIKE THAT HAVE UNCERTAINTIES BECAUSE OF LIMITED RESOLUTIONS OF GEOPHYSICAL DATA, TO EXPLORE EFFECTS OF DIFFERENT MODEL PARAMETERS ON MODEL OUTPUTS, NAMELY RUPTURE EXTENTS AND PATTERNS. IN ADDITION TO SHEDDING LIGHTS ONTO POSSIBLE FUTURE RUPTURE SCENARIOS ON THE SSAF, THEIR RESULTS AND FINDINGS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO GENERAL UNDERSTANDING OF HOW COMPLEX 3D FAULT GEOMETRY CONTROLS EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE BEHAVIORS. THEY WILL PUBLISH THEIR MODELS AND RESULTS IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. THE MODELS AND RESULTS MAY BE USED IN THE NEXT GENERATION OF SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSIS PRODUCTS BY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES INCLUDING USGS AND PRIVATE SECTORS SUCH AS INSURANCE COMPANIES WHO ISSUE EARTHQUAKE INSURANCE IN CALIFORNIA AND THE SURROUNDING AREAS, CONTRIBUTING TO SEISMIC HAZARD REDUCTION AND MITIGATION.

PROJECT TITLE:INTERSEISMIC DEFORMATION IN THE NORTHERN SAN FRANCISCO BAY AND SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTAREGIONS FROM SURVEY GNSS OBSERVATIONS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH MIT AND UC RIVERSIDEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THE RECIPIENT WILL GATHER GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) OBSERVATIONS AT SEVERAL TENS OF KNOWN, PREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED GEODETIC MEASUREMENT SITES THROUGHOUT THE NORTH SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AND THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN RIVER DELTA REGION TO UPDATE A SET OF PRECISE POSITION ESTIMATES THERE. THESE LATEST POSITIONS, COMBINED WITH RESULTS FROM PREVIOUS SURVEYS CONDUCTED BY US AND BY OTHER GROUPS, ALLOW US TO TRACK THE MOTION OF THE MEASUREMENT SITES OVER TIME, WHICH PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF THE TECTONIC MOTION OF THE EARTH'S SURFACE. THE DATA WE COLLECT, AND ANY EXISTING DATA FROM PAST SURVEYS, WILL BE REPROCESSED USING SPECIALIZED SOFTWARE IN A CONSISTENT AND RIGOROUS MANNER DURING THIS PROJECT. OUR SURFACE VELOCITY RESULTS WILL CONSTRAIN PHYSICAL MODELS OF THE POTENTIAL MOTION ON KNOWN FAULTS IN THE AREA AND HELP TO DETECT ANY ONGOING MOTION ASSOCIATED WITH THE 2014 SOUTH NAPA EARTHQUAKE, WHICH MAY PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO INVESTIGATE THE MATERIAL PROPERTIES OF THE LOWER CRUST.THESE NEW MEASUREMENTS FROM THE DELTA REGION WILL EXPAND EASTWARDS A REGION OVER WHICH WE HAVE PRODUCED SIMILAR RESULTS IN THE PAST, FROM THE PACIFIC COAST BETWEEN THE GOLDEN GATE OF SAN FRANCISCO AND POINT ARENA WHERE THE SAN ANDREAS FAULT GOES OFFSHORE, TO COVER THE LOCATIONS OF SEVERAL OTHER SHALLOW FAULTS IN THE EARTH'S CRUST THAT ARE FURTHER INLAND TOWARDS THE EDGE OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA. TOGETHER WITH UPDATED MEASUREMENTS ACROSS THE NORTH BAY SITES THAT WE HAVE PREVIOUSLY MEASURED MULTIPLE TIMES, THIS BROAD NETWORK OF OBSERVATION SITES IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF MOTION ACROSS THE TECTONIC PLATE BOUNDARY BETWEEN THE PACIFIC AND NORTH AMERICA, WHICH IS DEFINED BY THESE FAULTS, INCLUDING THE SAN ANDREAS FAULT. THIS WILL ALLOW US TO CONSTRAIN A MORE COMPLETE EVALUATION OF EARTHQUAKE HAZARD IN THE REGION, AND PARTICULARLY THE HAZARD BENEATH THE DELTA, WHICH REMAINS POORLY UNDERSTOOD AND IS A MOTIVATING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT.THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE NEW SURVEY GPS MEASUREMENTS, WHICH WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE PUBLICLY THROUGH A COMMUNITY REPOSITORY SUCH AS UNAVCO (HTTPS://WWW.UNAVCO.ORG/) OR ZENODO (HTTPS://WWW.ZENODO.ORG/), WITH AN ACCOMPANYING CITATION FOR REFERENCE OF THE FIELD SURVEY(S), FROM WHERE OTHER RESEARCHERS OR INTERESTED PARTIES MAY ACCESS THE DATA. THE DATA WILL BE PROCESSED TO PRODUCE UPDATED POSITIONS AND, IN COMBINATION WITH PREVIOUS POSITION MEASUREMENTS AT THE SAME LOCATIONS, POSITIONS OVER TIME (VELOCITIES), BOTH OF WHICH WILL ALSO BE MADE AVAILABLE IN A STANDARD COMMUNITY FORMAT AT THE SAME REPOSITORIES AND IN CONJUNCTION WITH PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE NUMEROUS. THE GPS DATA COLLECTED EXTEND THE TIME PERIOD AND INCREASE THE DENSITY OF SITE POSITION MEASUREMENTS COMPARED TO NETWORKS OF SUCH OBSERVATION SITES THAT OPERATE CONTINUOUSLY. EPISODIC, TEMPORARY GPS SURVEYS ARE A CHEAP, EFFICIENT AND NON-INTRUSIVE WAY OF ACHIEVING DENSIFICATION OF OBSERVATIONS FOR THE STUDY OF ACTIVE FAULTS BY THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND OTHER GEOPHYSICAL RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS. THESE DATA MAY ALSO BE USED BY ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT AND HIGHWAY AGENCIES, FOR EXAMPLE THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF WATER RESOURCES AND THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION, RESPECTIVELY, AND ANY OTHERS WHO RELY ON POSITIONING MEASUREMENTS, INCLUDING THE CONTINUOUSLY OPERATING GPS NETWORKS, FOR THEIR OWN PURPOSES

TITLE: PALEOSEISMIC INVESTIGATION OF THE LAFAYETTE FAULT AND THE CONTRA COSTA SHEAR ZONE: AN  UNCHARACTERIZED AND POTENTIAL TRANSFER STRUCTURE WITHIN THE EAST BAY HILLS, CONTRA COSTA COUNTY, CAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023AWARD PURPOSE THE LAFAYETTE FAULT IS ONE OF THE MOST PROMINENT STRUCTURES OF THE POORLY CHARACTERIZED CONTRA COSTA SHEAR  ZONE (CCSZ), LOCATED IN THE DENSELY POPULATED HIGHWAY 24 CORRIDOR OF CONTRA COSTA COUNTY. THE CCSZ  IS INCLUDED IN THE EXISTING STATE-WIDE SEISMIC SOURCE MODEL (UNIFORM CALIFORNIA EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE  FORECAST - UCERF3) AND REPRESENTS A POTENTIAL HAZARD TO LOCAL INFRASTRUCTURE. INFORMATION ON THE RECENCY  OF ACTIVITY, TIMING, AND RECURRENCE OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES FOR FAULTS COMPRISING THE CCSZ IS SPARSE TO NONEXISTENT. THE STATEWIDE MODELS INCLUDE THE CCSZ AS A PARTICIPANT FAULT IN RUPTURES INVOLVING THE WEST  NAPA FAULT TO THE NORTH, AND THE NORTHERN CALAVERAS FAULT TO THE SOUTH. THIS RESEARCH AIMS TO TEST THIS  MODEL OF POTENTIAL FAULT CONNECTIVITY WITH THE COLLECTION OF SEISMOTECTONIC AND PALEOSEISMIC DATA ON THE  LAFAYETTE FAULT AND CCFZ.  TO ACHIEVE THE STATED GOALS OF THIS STUDY, ONE TO TWO FAULT-NORMAL TRENCHES WILL BE EXCAVATED AT ONE OF TWO  POSSIBLE SITES ALONG THE LAFAYETTE FAULT: THE LAFAYETTE RIDGE SITE, OR THE MARISH LAGOON SITE. BOTH LOCATIONS  EXHIBIT PROMINENT TECTONIC GEOMORPHOLOGY ASSOCIATED WITH THE LAFAYETTE FAULT AND HOLOCENE  SEDIMENTATION THAT WILL LIKELY AID IN RECORDING FAULT ACTIVITY AND EVENT TIMING INFORMATION. THE GEOLOGIC  DATA COLLECTED FROM TRENCHES WILL HELP INFORM PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD MODELS (ESPECIALLY TIMEDEPENDENT PROBABILISTIC MODELS) THAT INCORPORATE THE CCSZ, AND WHICH RELY ON EARTHQUAKE TIMING AND SLIP  RATE DATA. CURRENTLY, THERE IS NO INFORMATION ON THE MOST BASIC NEEDS OF EARTHQUAKE FORECASTING FOR THE  CCSZ, SUCH AS HOLOCENE ACTIVITY AND AGE OF THE MOST RECENT EVENT (MRE). THIS INFORMATION IS IMPORTANT  TO ADDRESSING THE QUESTION OF A LINKED FAULT RUPTURE BETWEEN THE NORTHERN CALAVERAS FAULT AND WEST NAPA  FAULT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED 1. PERFORM SEISMICITY ANALYSIS.  2. ACQUIRE PERMITS TO ALLOW FOR EXCAVATION. 3. EXCAVATE TWO TRENCHES AND INTERPRET EXPOSED SEDIMENTS, SAMPLING FOR GEOCHRONOLOGIC ANALYSES  WHERE POSSIBLE. 4. REVIEW TRENCH INTERPRETATIONS WITH SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS. 5. SUBMIT SAMPLES FOR LAB ANALYSIS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY COMPILING FINDINGS FROM FIELD EFFORT. 6. PREPARE FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT (FTR), PREPARE DATA DELIVERABLES, AND DISSEMINATE FINDINGS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES TWO PRIMARY DELIVERABLES WILL BE GENERATED BY THIS STUDY: (1) THE RESULTS OF THE SEISMICITY ANALYSIS, IN THE  FORM OF A TABLE DETAILING THE LOCAL MICROSEISMICITY UTILIZED, AND GRAPHICAL REPRESENTATIONS OF THE RESULTS AND  (2) DATA GENERATED FROM TRENCH EXPOSURES, INCLUDING PHOTOMOSAICS, GRAPHICAL LOGS, MAPS, AND RESULTS OF  GEOCHRONOLOGICAL ANALYSIS. BOTH DELIVERABLES WILL BE REPORTED INCLUDED IN THE FTR.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES DATA DERIVED FROM THESE INVESTIGATIONS SHOULD BE USEFUL TO RESEARCHERS IN THE FIELDS OF SEISMIC HAZARD  ASSESSMENT AND PALEOSEISMOLOGY WITHIN THE SFBA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

PROJECT TITLE:TOWARDS A COMPREHENSIVE EARTHQUAKE CATALOG FOR THEPACIFIC NORTHWEST: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH THEUNIVERSITY OF OREGON AND BOSTON UNIVERSITYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2024DESPITE ITS ABILITY TO HOST M9 EARTHQUAKES, THE CASCADIA SUBDUCTION ZONE HAS AN EXCEPTIONALLY  LOW RATE OF EARTHQUAKE PRODUCTIVITY. THE EARTHQUAKES THAT DO OCCUR THERE ARE THOUGHT TO BE  INTIMATELY LINKED TO THE DISTRIBUTION OF FLUIDS IN THE CRUST, ON THE PLATE BOUNDARY, AND WITHIN THE  DOWNGOING PLATE. ADDITIONALLY, BECAUSE OF THE GEOGRAPHICALLY LIMITED DISTRIBUTION OF EARTHQUAKES,  CASCADIA PROVIDES A UNIQUE SETTING TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ROLE OF FLUIDS IN GENERATING  EARTHQUAKES. IN THIS WORK, WE WILL PERFORM A LARGE-SCALE EARTHQUAKE DATA MINING EFFORT TO  IDENTIFY MANY MORE SMALL MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKES AUGMENTING THE REGIONAL SEISMICITY CATALOG.  WE HAVE DEVELOPED DEEP-LEARNING TOOLS CAPABLE OF IDENTIFYING EARTHQUAKES WITH LOW SIGNAL-TO-NOISE RATIOS IN CONTINUOUS SEISMIC DATA, IDENTIFYING P AND S WAVE ARRIVALS, AND ASSIGNING THESE  ARRIVALS TO EARTHQUAKES. WE PROPOSE TO CREATE A NEW EARTHQUAKE CATALOG FOR THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST  BY APPLYING THESE TOOLS TO MUCH OF THE CONTINUOUS SEISMIC DATA COLLECTED THERE IN THE LAST 16  YEARS. ONCE IDENTIFIED EVENTS WILL BE LOCATED USING THREE-DIMENSIONAL VELOCITY STRUCTURE, ASSIGNED  MAGNITUDES, AND, WHEN POSSIBLE, FOCAL MECHANISMS. THIS HIGH RESOLUTION EARTHQUAKE CATALOG WILL  BE THE MAIN DELIVERABLE FOR THIS PROJECT.THE RESULTING CATALOG HAS MANY USES, BUT WE WILL FOCUS ON EXPLORING TWO NOTEWORTHY ASPECTS OF  SEISMICITY IN CASCADIA. FIRST, WE WILL EXPLORE THE SPACE-TIME MIGRATION AND CHARACTER OF  SEISMICITY IN REGIONS WHERE THE DOWNGOING PLATE HAS HIGH DOWN-DIP CURVATURE. THESE REGIONS,  LOCATED IN THE PUGET SOUND, OFFSHORE NORTHERN VANCOUVER ISLAND, AND SOUTHERN GORDA HAVE HIGH  CONCENTRATIONS OF INTRASLAB AND OVERLYING CRUSTAL SEISMICITY SUGGESTING THAT THE FAULT SYSTEMS THAT  HOST SUCH EVENTS INTERACT. WE PROPOSE TO EXPLORE THE NATURE OF THESE INTERACTIONS. SECOND, THERE  ARE HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF SWARM-LIKE SEISMICITY IN CALIFORNIA AND WASHINGTON STATE THAT LOCATE  IN THE SHALLOW CRUST BETWEEN THE DOWN DIP EDGE OF TREMOR AND THE ARC. THESE EVENTS ARE THOUGHT  TO BE DRIVEN BY FLUIDS GENERATED THROUGH DEHYDRATION REACTIONS IN THE DOWNGOING PLATE, BELOW THE  MANTLE WEDGE CORNER. WHETHER THESE FLUIDS ARE THE SOURCE OF SUCH SWARMS, HOW AND WHY THEY  TRAVERSE THE MANTLE WEDGE CORNER, LOWER CRUST, AND DRIVE SHALLOW SEISMICITY IS UNKNOWN. AS SUCH,  WE PROPOSE TO EXPLORE SPACE-TIME MIGRATION PATTERNS AND FOCAL MECHANISMS OF THESE SWARMS. OF  PARTICULAR INTEREST IS WHETHER COHERENT MIGRATION PATTERNS ARE EVIDENT, OVER WHAT TIMESCALES SUCH  SWARMS OCCUR, WHERE THEY ORIGINATE, AND WHICH STRUCTURES HOST THESE EVENTS.MORE BROADLY, INSIGHTS DERIVED FROM ANALYSIS OF SEISMICITY IN CASCADIA CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP  HYPOTHESES THAT CAN BE TESTED IN OTHER SUBDUCTION ZONE ENVIRONMENTS WITH GREATER NUMBERS OF  EARTHQUAKES FURTHERING OUR PROCESS-BASED UNDERSTANDING OF SEISMICITY IN GLOBAL SUBDUCTION ZONE  SETTINGS. THE ANALYSIS HERE WILL BENEFIT THE GROUP OF EARTHQUAKE SCIENTISTS INTERESTED IN SEISMICITY  IN CASCADIA AND THOSE INTERESTED IN GLOBAL SUBDUCTION ZONE SEISMICITY. THE CATALOG GENERATED  HERE IS A FOUNDATIONAL PRODUCT THAT CAN BE USED TO EXPLORE LINKS BETWEEN FLUIDS, VELOCITY STRUCTURE, CONDUCTIVITY STRUCTURE, AND EARTHQUAKES. IT CAN ALSO BE USED TO BETTER QUANTIFY  EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS IN CASCADIA, THROUGH REGION SPECIFIC GROUND MOTION MODEL.

PROJECT TITLE:TOWARDS A COMPREHENSIVE EARTHQUAKE CATALOG FORTHE PACIFIC NORTHWEST: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITHTHE UNIVERSITY OF OREGON AND BOSTON UNIVERSITYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2024DESPITE ITS ABILITY TO HOST M9 EARTHQUAKES, THE CASCADIA SUBDUCTION ZONE HAS AN EXCEPTIONALLY LOW RATE OF EARTHQUAKE PRODUCTIVITY. THE EARTHQUAKES THAT DO OCCUR THERE ARE THOUGHT TO BE INTIMATELY LINKED TO THE DISTRIBUTION OF FLUIDS IN THE CRUST, ON THE PLATE BOUNDARY, AND WITHIN THE DOWNGOING PLATE. ADDITIONALLY, BECAUSE OF THE GEOGRAPHICALLY LIMITED DISTRIBUTION OF EARTHQUAKES, CASCADIA PROVIDES A UNIQUE SETTING TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ROLE OF FLUIDS IN GENERATING EARTHQUAKES. IN THIS WORK, WE WILL PERFORM A LARGE-SCALE EARTHQUAKE DATA MINING EFFORT TO IDENTIFY MANY MORE SMALL MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKES AUGMENTING THE REGIONAL SEISMICITY CATALOG. WE HAVE DEVELOPED DEEP-LEARNING TOOLS CAPABLE OF IDENTIFYING EARTHQUAKES WITH LOW SIGNAL-TO-NOISE RATIOS IN CONTINUOUS SEISMIC DATA, IDENTIFYING P AND S WAVE ARRIVALS, AND ASSIGNING THESE ARRIVALS TO EARTHQUAKES. WE PROPOSE TO CREATE A NEW EARTHQUAKE CATALOG FOR THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST BY APPLYING THESE TOOLS TO MUCH OF THE CONTINUOUS SEISMIC DATA COLLECTED THERE IN THE LAST 16 YEARS. ONCE IDENTIFIED EVENTS WILL BE LOCATED USING THREE-DIMENSIONAL VELOCITY STRUCTURE, ASSIGNED MAGNITUDES, AND, WHEN POSSIBLE, FOCAL MECHANISMS. THIS HIGH RESOLUTION EARTHQUAKE CATALOG WILL BE THE MAIN DELIVERABLE FOR THIS PROJECT.THE RESULTING CATALOG HAS MANY USES, BUT WE WILL FOCUS ON EXPLORING TWO NOTEWORTHY ASPECTS OF SEISMICITY IN CASCADIA. FIRST, WE WILL EXPLORE THE SPACE-TIME MIGRATION AND CHARACTER OF SEISMICITY IN REGIONS WHERE THE DOWNGOING PLATE HAS HIGH DOWN-DIP CURVATURE. THESE REGIONS, LOCATED IN THE PUGET SOUND, OFFSHORE NORTHERN VANCOUVER ISLAND, AND SOUTHERN GORDA HAVE HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF INTRASLAB AND OVERLYING CRUSTAL SEISMICITY SUGGESTING THAT THE FAULT SYSTEMS THAT HOST SUCH EVENTS INTERACT. WE PROPOSE TO EXPLORE THE NATURE OF THESE INTERACTIONS. SECOND, THERE ARE HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF SWARM-LIKE SEISMICITY IN CALIFORNIA AND WASHINGTON STATE THAT LOCATE IN THE SHALLOW CRUST BETWEEN THE DOWN DIP EDGE OF TREMOR AND THE ARC. THESE EVENTS ARE THOUGHT TO BE DRIVEN BY FLUIDS GENERATED THROUGH DEHYDRATION REACTIONS IN THE DOWNGOING PLATE, BELOW THE MANTLE WEDGE CORNER. WHETHER THESE FLUIDS ARE THE SOURCE OF SUCH SWARMS, HOW AND WHY THEY TRAVERSE THE MANTLE WEDGE CORNER, LOWER CRUST, AND DRIVE SHALLOW SEISMICITY IS UNKNOWN. AS SUCH, WE PROPOSE TO EXPLORE SPACE-TIME MIGRATION PATTERNS AND FOCAL MECHANISMS OF THESE SWARMS. OF PARTICULAR INTEREST IS WHETHER COHERENT MIGRATION PATTERNS ARE EVIDENT, OVER WHAT TIMESCALES SUCH SWARMS OCCUR, WHERE THEY ORIGINATE, AND WHICH STRUCTURES HOST THESE EVENTS.MORE BROADLY, INSIGHTS DERIVED FROM ANALYSIS OF SEISMICITY IN CASCADIA CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP HYPOTHESES THAT CAN BE TESTED IN OTHER SUBDUCTION ZONE ENVIRONMENTS WITH GREATER NUMBERS OF EARTHQUAKES FURTHERING OUR PROCESS-BASED UNDERSTANDING OF SEISMICITY IN GLOBAL SUBDUCTION ZONE SETTINGS. THE ANALYSIS HERE WILL BENEFIT THE GROUP OF EARTHQUAKE SCIENTISTS INTERESTED IN SEISMICITY IN CASCADIA AND THOSE INTERESTED IN GLOBAL SUBDUCTION ZONE SEISMICITY. THE CATALOG GENERATED HERE IS A FOUNDATIONAL PRODUCT THAT CAN BE USED TO EXPLORE LINKS BETWEEN FLUIDS, VELOCITY STRUCTURE, CONDUCTIVITY STRUCTURE, AND EARTHQUAKES. IT CAN ALSO BE USED TO BETTER QUANTIFY EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS IN CASCADIA, THROUGH REGION SPECIFIC GROUND MOTION MODELS.

PROJECT TITLE:EARTHQUAKE SIMULATORS AND NEXT GENERATION HAZARD MODELS (UCERF4): COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITHCOLUMBIA UNIVERSITY AND USGS GOLDENPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023SEISMIC HAZARD ESTIMATES ARE IMPORTANT TO SOCIETY, FORMING THE BASIS OF BUILDING CODES AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES. YET THEY REST ON MANY UNCERTAIN ASSUMPTIONS, AND THIS IS INCREASING FURTHER AS MODELS COME TO INCORPORATE MORE FEATURES AND BECOME MORE COMPLEX. EXACERBATING THE ISSUE IS THE DIFFICULTY IN TESTING THE MODELS, DUE TO THE LONG RECURRENCE TIMES OF LARGE EARTHQUAKES, THE EVENTS MOST CRITICAL FOR LONG TERM HAZARD ESTIMATES. QUESTIONS HAVE ARISEN OF WHETHER THIS PATHWAY TOWARDS FURTHER REFINEMENT OF HAZARD MODELS INVOLVING FURTHER PIECES WITH FURTHER PARAMETERIZATIONS HAS REACHED ITS LIMIT, OR WHETHER THERE MIGHT BE OTHER WAYS TO FORGE AHEAD. ONE ALTERNATIVE NOTED IN PLANNING FOR NEXT GENERATION HAZARD MODEL IS THE POTENTIAL FOR PHYSICS-BASED EARTHQUAKE SIMULATORS TO CONTRIBUTE [FIELD, 2018]. THEY BRING A NUMBER OF ADVANTAGES WHICH COULD BE USEFUL, INCLUDING SELF-CONSISTENCY WITH A GIVEN SPECIFIED PHYSICS, AND NATURALLY ACCOMPLISHING MANY OF THE BOOKKEEPING FEATURES STATISTICAL MODELS HAVE BEEN WORKING HARD TO REPRESENT, INCLUDING MULTIFAULT RUPTURES, ELASTIC REBOUND, COULOMB STRESS COMPATIBILITY, AND SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL CORRELATIONS, AMONG OTHERS. ON THE OTHER HAND, SIMULATORS THEMSELVES HAVE THEIR OWN UNCERTAINTIES. WILL THE ARRAY OF UNCERTAINTIES THE SIMULATORS FACE, RATHER THAN HELPING TO NARROW UNCERTAINTIES IN HAZARD ESTIMATES, ONLY EXPAND THE UNCERTAINTIES? RECENT MAJOR PROGRESS HAS CHANGED THIS PICTURE DRAMATICALLY. PUSHING AHEAD WITH PHYSICSBASED SIMULATOR DEVELOPMENT AND COMPARISONS WITH THE LATEST HAZARD MODEL FOR CALIFORNIA, WE HAVE FOUND IMPRESSIVE AGREEMENT OF LONG TERM FAULT BASED HAZARD ESTIMATES ACROSS CALIFORNIA [SHAW, ET AL, 2018]. THIS ABILITY TO REPLICATE HAZARD ESTIMATES IS IMPORTANT FOR A VARIETY OF REASONS. ONE, IT ADDS STRONGLY INCREASED CONFIDENCE TO HAZARD ESTIMATES THROUGH A TRIANGULATION FORM OF REPLICATION BY VASTLY DIFFERENT METHODS. GIVEN THE PROLIFERATING UNCERTAINTIES IN THE STATISTICALLY BASED EARTHQAUAKE HAZARD MODELS, THIS IS OF MAJOR IMPORTANCE. IT ALSO GIVES US A NEW PATHWAY TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND REFINE AND EXAMINE ROBUSTNESS AND UNCERTAINTY QUESTIONS IN THE HAZARD ESTIMATES. BY HAVING A DIALOGUE BETWEEN THE TWO APPROACHES, ONE PHYSICS-BASED, ONE STATISTICALLYBASED, BOTH ARE STRENGTHENED AND IMPROVED. THIS WORK CONTINUES TO PUSH FORWARD THIS DIALOGUE AND COLLABORATION WHICH CAN INFORM AND SUPPORT NEXT GENERATION SEISMIC HAZARD MODELS. THE TOPIC OF THE WORK IS IMPROVING SEGMENTATION CONSTRAINTS, WHICH IMPACTS MULTIFAULT PROBABILITIES AND THE SIZES OF RUPTURES ON FAULT SYSTEMS. THE MAIN THEME OF THE PROJECTS ARE EXAMINING HOW JUMP DISTANCE AFFECTS SEGMENTATION AND HOW THIS CAN BE USED IN HAZARD MODELS. AN EXPECTED OUTCOME WOULD BE IMPROVED METHODS FOR SEGMENTATION CONSTRAINTS, WHICH IMPACT THE SIZES OF EARTHQUAKE RUPTURES ON FAULT SYSTEMS. THIS SHOULD IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE RANGE OF EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS. IMPROVED INFORMATION FOR PLANNING AND DESIGN FOR SEISMIC HAZARD IS AN INTENDED BENEFIT.

PROJECT TITLE:THE EXTENT OF SHALLOW SLIP DURING THE 2020 SIMEONOF EARTHQUAKE CONSTRAINED BY SEAFLOOR GEODESY ONTHE ALASKA-ALEUTIAN SUBDUCTION ZONEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CLARIFY THE SEISMIC AND TSUNAMI HAZARDS FOR THE ALASKA-ALEUTIAN SUBDUCTION ZONE. FUTURE LARGE EARTHQUAKES OFFSHORE ALASKA HAVE THE POTENTIAL FOR GENERATING LARGE TSUNAMI  THAT CAN PROPAGATE ACROSS THE PACIFIC OCEAN AND THREATEN COASTAL COMMUNITIES ALONG THE PACIFIC  RIM, AS WELL AS PACIFIC ISLANDS SUCH AS HAWAII. THE LARGEST TSUNAMI ARE GENERATED BY LARGE  EARTHQUAKES ALONG SUBDUCTION ZONES. THESE LARGE EARTHQUAKES RELEASE ENERGY THAT IS ACCUMULATED  BETWEEN MOVING TECTONIC PLATES. AS THE PLATES SUDDENLY SLIDE PAST ONE ANOTHER DURING AN EARTHQUAKE, THE SEAFLOOR IS WARPED, WHICH IN TURN DISPLACES THE OCEAN AND INITIATES A TSUNAMI.  EARTHQUAKES THAT RUPTURE THE SHALLOW CRUST HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO GENERATE THE LARGEST TSUNAMI.  THUS IT IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL FOR THIS SHALLOW FAULT SLIP.  OUR STUDY WILL EXAMINE THE AMOUNT AND DEPTH OF FAULT SLIP DURING THE 2020 SIMEONOF EARTHQUAKE (MAGNITUDE 7.8) AND EVALUATE WHETHER SIGNIFICANT SHALLOW FAULT SLIP COULD OCCUR FOR A FUTURE  EARTHQUAKE AT THIS LOCATION ALONG THE ALASKA-ALEUTIAN SUBDUCTION ZONE. THIS EARTHQUAKE IS THE  FIRST OF THREE LARGE EARTHQUAKES NEAR THIS LOCATION IN THE PAST FEW YEARS. THUS THIS SEGMENT OF THE  SUBDUCTION ZONE HAS BEEN VERY ACTIVE. THE SIMEONOF EARTHQUAKE IS ALSO ADJACENT TO A FAULT  SEGMENT THAT HAS NOT EXPERIENCED A LARGE EARTHQUAKE IN NEARLY 100 YEARS. IT IS IMPORTANT TO  DISCERN THE SPECIFIC AREA ALONG THE SUBDUCTION ZONE THAT RUPTURED DURING THE SIMEONOF EARTHQUAKE  SINCE THAT WILL HELP US TO UNDERSTAND WHERE LARGE EARTHQUAKES MAY STILL OCCUR IN THE NEAR FUTURE. WHILE LAND INSTRUMENTS PROVIDE SOME INFORMATION ABOUT THE SINEONOF EARTHQUAKE, THEY WERE RELATIVELY FAR FROM THE EARTHQUAKE, AND DID NOT PROVIDE ENOUGH INFORMATION ABOUT THE SHALLOW  FAULT SLIP. IN THIS WORK, WE UTILIZE NEW SEAFLOOR OBSERVATIONS USING A TECHNIQUE CALLED GNSS-ACOUSTIC. THESE SEAFLOOR INSTRUMENTS WERE FIRST INSTALLED IN 2018, AND ARE SENSITIVE ENOUGH TO  MEASURE THE MOTION OF THE SEAFLOOR TO THE CENTIMETER LEVEL. THESE INSTRUMENTS ARE SPECIAL BECAUSE  THEY ARE THE ONLY OBSERVATIONS OF THE EARTHQUAKE WE HAVE FROM OFFSHORE AND THUS THE BEST DATA  WITH WHICH TO CONSTRAIN THE SHALLOW SUBDUCTION ZONE RUPTURE. WE STUDY THESE OBSERVATIONS IN  COMBINATION WITH DATA FROM OTHER INSTRUMENTS ON THE ALEUTIAN ISLANDS TO CONSTRUCT A CLEARER  PICTURE OF WHERE FAULT SLIP OCCURRED DURING THE SIMEONOF EARTHQUAKE AND HOW MUCH OF THAT SLIP  WAS ALONG THE SHALLOW SUBDUCTION ZONE WHERE THE TSUNAMI RISK IS THE HIGHEST. OUR WORK HAS  IMPLICATIONS FOR THE SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS OF ALASKA AND THE TSUNAMI POTENTIAL FOR THE PACIFIC  BASIN.

PROJECT TITLE:FROM STRAIN RATE TO HAZARD: ESTIMATING FAULT SLIP DEFICIT RATE AND OFF-FAULT MOMENT RATE USINGGEODETIC DATAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/1/2022 THROUGH 5/31/2023PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYGEODETIC DATA ARE NOW BEING USED FOR PRODUCING THE US NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAP AND OTHER HAZARD MODELS AROUND THE WORLD. GENERALLY, GEODETIC DATA ARE USED IN TWO DIFFERENT WAYS IN THE LITERATURE THAT RELATE TO HAZARD. MOMENT DEFICIT RATE IS COMPUTED BY INTEGRATING SURFACE STRAIN RATES DERIVED FROM GEODETIC DATA OVER THE SEISMOGENIC VOLUME OF THE CRUST (SAVAGE & SIMPSON, 1997). ALTERNATIVELY, GEODETICALLY-DERIVED SURFACE VELOCITIES ARE USED TO ESTIMATE SLIP RATES ON CRUSTAL FAULTS USING KINEMATIC MODELS AND THE BACK-SLIP ASSUMPTION (E.G. SAVAGE & BURFORD, 1973; SAVAGE, 1983; SEGALL & HARRIS, 1987; MCCAFFREY, 2002; MEADE AND HAGAR, 2005). THE FIRST APPROACH BENEFITS FROM MAKING NO ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT FAULTS; THE ESTIMATED MOMENT RATE IS BASED DIRECTLY ON STRAIN-RATE OBSERVATIONS. THE SECOND APPROACH USES ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT FAULT GEOMETRY TO ESTIMATE SLIP RATES ON SPECIFIC FAULTS. THE KINEMATIC DEFORMATION MODELS MAKE VARIOUS ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT HOW FAULT SLIP RATES RELATE TO MEASURED SURFACE VELOCITIES. HOWEVER, BEST PRACTICES FOR THE USE OF GEODETIC DATA IN THE HAZARD MODELS ARE STILL UNDER CONSIDERATION AND CHALLENGES REMAIN, ESPECIALLY IN AREAS OF DIFFUSE FAULTING AND DISTRIBUTED DEFORMATION, IN INFERRING FAULT SLIP RATES USING GEODETIC DATA. IT ALSO CONTINUES TO BE CHALLENGING TO DIFFERENTIATE DEFORMATION ASSOCIATED WITH INTERSEISMIC COUPLING ON FAULTS AND OFF-FAULT DEFORMATION THAT MAY BE EITHER ELASTIC OR INELASTIC.AN ALTERNATIVE APPROACH IS TO USE GEODETICALLY-DERIVED STRAIN RATES TO ESTIMATE FAULT SLIP RATES DIRECTLY, WITHOUT INTRODUCING A KINEMATIC MODEL FOR SURFACE VELOCITIES. THIS DIRECT IMPLEMENTATION OF STRAIN RATE HAS BEEN SHOWN TO BE VALUABLE IN IMPROVING SEISMIC HAZARD FORECASTS (E.G., BIRD ET AL., 2015). HERE WE PROPOSE TO SYSTEMATICALLY INVESTIGATE STRAIN RATES IN THE WESTERN US USING THREE CLASSES OF INTERPOLATION METHODS FOR COMPUTING STRAIN RATE FROM GEODETICALLY-DERIVED VELOCITIES AND COMBINING THESE WITH GEOLOGIC SLIP RATES TO DETERMINE ON- AND OFF-FAULT MOMENT DEFICIT RATES. USING UNCERTAINTIES DERIVED FROM EACH METHOD, WE WILL SYSTEMATICALLY COMPARE STRAIN RATE ESTIMATES FOR THE WESTERN US THROUGH THE CONSTRUCTION OF POSTERIOR PROBABILITY DISTRIBUTIONS OF STRAIN RATE AND QUANTIFY EPISTEMIC AND ALEATORIC UNCERTAINTY IN THE RESULTING MOMENT RATE.DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE:? A LARGE NUMBER OF STOCHASTIC REALIZATIONS (ORDER THOUSANDS) OF WESTERN US STRAIN RATE MAPS USING METHODS AMONG THE THREE CLASSES DESCRIBED PREVIOUSLY: (1) BASIS APPROACH (E.G., SPLINES), (2) ELASTICITY GREEN'S FUNCTION APPROACH (OUR BODY FORCE METHOD), AND (3) DISTANCE-WEIGHTED APPROACHES (OUR KRIGING METHOD).? CRUSTAL MOMENT RATES USING BOTH KOSTROV-TYPE AND FAULT-BASED METHODS FOR ALL THE REALIZATIONS, RESULTING IN POSTERIOR PROBABILITY DISTRIBUTIONS OF TOTAL MOMENT BOTH ON AND OFF FAULTS IN THE WESTERN US.WE WILL PROVIDE THESE TO THE USGS AND THE NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAP PROJECT AND TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH OPEN-SOURCE DATA ARCHIVES.

PROJECT TITLE:COMPREHENSIVE 3D ASSESSMENT OF THE GEOMETRY, SEGMENTATION, AND SLIP ON THE NEWPORT-INGLEWOODFAULT, LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA, AND ITS IMPLICATIONS FOR REGIONAL EARTHQUAKE HAZARDSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THE NEWPORT-INGLEWOOD FAULT (NIF) CUTS OVER 40 MILES THROUGH DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES, RUNNING  THROUGH SOME OF THE NATION'S MOST DENSELY POPULATED RESIDENTIAL AREAS. THE NIF IS RESPONSIBLE FOR  SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA'S DEADLIEST EARTHQUAKE-AN M6.3 EVENT WHICH DEVASTATED NEIGHBORHOODS  ACROSS THE LOS ANGELES METROPOLITAN AREA IN 1933-AND IT IS CONSIDERED CAPABLE OF GENERATING  MUCH LARGER (M ?7.0) AND MORE DESTRUCTIVE EARTHQUAKES. AS THE CALIFORNIA DIVISION OF MINES AND  GEOLOGY DESCRIBED IT IN 1988, "A FUTURE MAJOR EARTHQUAKE ALONG THE DENSELY POPULATED NIF POSES  ONE OF THE GREATEST HAZARDS TO LIVES AND PROPERTY IN THE NATION."DESPITE OUR AWARENESS OF THE HIGH HAZARDS POSED BY THE NIF, FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS PERSIST ABOUT  ITS GEOMETRY, SLIP RATE, AND THE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN ITS SEGMENTS. IN REGIONAL MODELS, THE NIF IS  CURRENTLY REPRESENTED AS A HIGHLY SIMPLIFIED STRIKE-SLIP FAULT-BUT RECENT EARTHQUAKES, SUCH AS THE  2019 RIDGECREST SEQUENCE, HAVE SHOWN THAT STRIKE-SLIP FAULT GEOMETRIES CAN BE FAR MORE COMPLEX,  WITH UNRECOGNIZED AND SEEMINGLY DISCONTINUOUS SURFACE FAULT TRACES ACTUALLY CONNECTED AT DEPTH.  THESE GEOMETRIC DETAILS DIRECTLY INFLUENCE THE SIZE AND EXTENT OF EARTHQUAKES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED  ZONE OF GROUND SURFACE RUPTURE.WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A NEW, COMPREHENSIVE THREE-DIMENSIONAL MODEL OF THE NEWPORT-INGLEWOOD FAULT THAT CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF ITS GROUND SHAKING AND FAULT  DISPLACEMENT HAZARDS. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY INTEGRATING A BROAD RANGE OF DATASETS,  SPANNING EARLY 20TH CENTURY PETROLEUM WELL RECORDS TO MODERN, STATE-OF-THE-ART SEISMOLOGICAL  CATALOGS, INCLUDING THOSE RECENTLY DEVELOPED WITH MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES.RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVED REGIONAL EARTHQUAKE HAZARD ASSESSMENTS  AND SHAKING HAZARD MAPS. THIS FAULT MODEL WILL BE USED TO RE-ASSESS POTENTIAL LOCATIONS,  MAGNITUDES, AND OTHER CHARACTERISTICS OF FUTURE LARGE EARTHQUAKES THAT ARE EXPECTED TO OCCUR ON  THIS SYSTEM. IN ADDITION, FAULT MODELS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY TO  SUPPORT MODELING OF EARTHQUAKE RUPTURES AND THEIR STRONG GROUND MOTION, AS WELL AS TO ASSIST WITH  INTERPRETATION OF PALEOSEISMIC RESULTS THAT HELP TO CONSTRAIN EARTHQUAKE RECURRENCE AND FAULT SLIP RATES. THE REVISED FAULT GEOMETRIES WILL BE INCORPORATED IN THE SCEC COMMUNITY FAULT MODEL  (CFM), THE CALIFORNIA REFERENCE FAULT PARAMETER DATABASE, AND THE USGS QUATERNARY FAULT &  FOLD DATABASE. THUS, RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL FACILITATE IMPROVED DETERMINISTIC AND PROBABILISTIC  SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS, WHICH CAN SUPPORT RISK MITIGATION STRATEGIES TO REDUCE THE LOSS OF LIFE  AND PROPERTY IN FUTURE EARTHQUAKES ON THIS HIGHLY HAZARDOUS URBAN FAULT.

PROJECT TITLE:OPTIMIZING MACHINE LEARNING CAPABILITIES TO DETECT EARTHQUAKES IN DELAWARE BASIN, SOUTHEASTERN NEWMEXICOPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023DUE TO RECENT INCREASES IN ANTHROPOGENICALLY TRIGGERED EARHQUAKES, THE ABILITY TO RAPIDLY DETECT, LOCATE, AND CHARACTERIZE SEISMICITY HAS BECOME IMPORTANT IN SEVERAL AREAS OF THE COUNTRY. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR RAPID DETECTION OF THE DELAWARE BASIN, SOUTHEASTERN NEW MEXICO, AN AREA WHERE SEISMICITY INCREASES OVER THE LAST TWO YEARS HAVE OCCURRED ALONG WITH INCREASES IN WASTEWATER DISPOSAL. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY OF THE PROJECT IS TESTING OF SEVERAL AUTOMATED AND MACHING LEARNING TOOLS USING EXISTING SEISMIC WAVEFORM DATA AND EARTHQUAKE CATALOGS TO IMPROVE THE EVENT DECTION CAPABILITIES FOR THE REGION. THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE IMPVOED DETECTION STRATEGIES OPTIMIZED FOR THE CURRENT MONITORING NETWORK AND A MORE COMPLETE LIST OF EARTHQUAKE CATALOG. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE NEW MEXICO BUREAU OF GEOLOGY AND MINERAL RESOURCES, NEW MEXICO STATE REGULATORY AGENCIES, THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, AND MEMBERS OF THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY INTERSTED IN SEISMIC APPLICATIONS OF MACHINE LEARNING AND INDUCED SEISMICITY.

PROJECT TITLE:IMPROVING THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL FOR THE SAN FRANCISCO REGION WITH JOINT BODY ANDSURFACE WAVE TOMOGRAPHYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023AWARD PURPOSEONE OF THE APPROACHES USED BY SEISMOLOGISTS FOR ESTIMATING THE SEISMIC HAZARD IN A REGION  SUCH AS THE SAN FRANCISCO REGION IS BY MODELING THE EXPECTED GROUND SHAKING FROM PLAUSIBLE  FUTURE EARTHQUAKES ON KNOWN REGIONAL FAULTS. SUCH MODELING NORMALLY INVOLVES THE USE OF A  THREE-DIMENSIONAL (3D) MODEL FOR THE VELOCITY AT WHICH SEISMIC WAVES TRAVEL. THE PURPOSE OF THIS  AWARD IS TO MAKE IMPROVEMENTS TO THE USGS SEISMIC VELOCITY OF THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY (SFB) REGION USING NEW DATA AND STATE-OF-THE-ART COMPUTATIONAL METHODS. THE NEW MODEL WILL BE  EVALUATED BY CARRYING OUT COMPUTER SIMULATIONS OF GROUND MOTIONS TO BE COMPARED TO OBSERVED  GROUND MOTIONS FROM REGIONAL EARTHQUAKES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED; THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A REFINED VERSION OF THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL FOR THE  SFB REGION, AS WELL AS A SECOND, COMPETING 3D MODEL. THIS WILL BE DONE USING A COMPUTATIONAL  METHOD KNOWN AS JOINT BODY-WAVE AND SURFACE-WAVE TOMOGRAPHY. NEW MACHINE LEARNING PICKS  FROM RECENT NODAL SEISMIC ARRAY AND PERMANENT SEISMIC STATIONS WILL BE INCORPORATED IN OUR  MODELING WORK.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES; THE DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A REFINED VERSION OF THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL  FOR THE SFB REGION, AS WELL AS A SECOND, COMPETING 3D MODEL, WHOSE RELATIVE MERITS WILL BE  EVALUATED. MACHINE LEARNING PICKS FROM NODAL SEISMIC DATA WILL BE INCLUDED. THE PROJECT WILL  CONTRIBUTE TO THE ABILITY TO DETERMINE IMPROVED ESTIMATES OF GROUND MOTIONS CAUSED BY POTENTIAL  FUTURE EARTHQUAKES BY REFINING THE ACCURACY OF THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARY WILL BE RESEARCHERS AT THE USGS IN THEIR EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS  WORK FOR THE SFB REGION. OUR PROJECT EXPLICITLY ADDRESSES THE 2022 NEHRP RESEARCH PRIORITIES FOR NORTHERN CALIFORNIA (NC), ELEMENT I "UPDATE EXISTING SEISMIC TOMOGRAPHY MODELS USING  AMBIENT NOISE METHODS, SHEAR WAVE ARRIVAL TIMES FROM 3-COMPONENT STATIONS, AND DATA FROM NEW  NETWORK STATIONS ADDED FOR EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING, AND COLLABORATE TO ENSURE THESE MODELS  ARE USED IN MODIFYING THE 3D GEOLOGY AND VELOCITY MODELS." OUR PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES A SERIES OF  3D GROUND-MOTION SIMULATIONS FOR MODERATE-SIZED LOCAL EARTHQUAKES FOR THE PURPOSE OF VALIDATING THE RESULTING VELOCITY MODELS, WHICH WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO ONE OF THE NC RESEARCH TOPICS,  "VALIDATE, IMPROVE, AND INCORPORATE SEISMIC TOMOGRAPHY MODELS INTO THE COMMUNITY REGIONAL 3D  GEOLOGIC AND SEISMIC VELOCITY MODELS FOR THE BAY AREA AND NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, WITH EMPHASIS  ON BASINS." WE EXPECT THAT OUR RESEARCH RESULTS WILL ALSO BE BENEFICIAL FOR EARTHQUAKE RESEARCHERS  AT LAWRENCE LIVERMORE NATIONAL LABORATORY FOR THEIR EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS ASSESSMENT.

PROJECT TITLE:IMPROVING THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL FOR THE SAN FRANCISCO REGION WITH JOINT BODY ANDSURFACE WAVE TOMOGRAPHYPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023AWARD PURPOSEONE OF THE APPROACHES USED BY SEISMOLOGISTS FOR ESTIMATING THE SEISMIC HAZARD IN AN AREA SUCH AS THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY REGION IS BY MODELING THE EXPECTED GROUND SHAKING FROM PLAUSIBLE  FUTURE EARTHQUAKES ON KNOWN REGIONAL FAULTS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO MAKE IMPROVEMENTS TO THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY OF THE SAN  FRANCISCO BAY REGION USING NEW DATA AND STATE-OF-THE-ART COMPUTATIONAL METHODS.
