THIS WILL BE  DONE USING A COMPUTATIONAL METHOD KNOWN AS JOINT BODY-WAVE AND SURFACE-WAVE TOMOGRAPHY. A  LARGE VOLUME OF RECENTLY PRODUCED SEISMIC DATA WILL BE INCORPORATED IN OUR MODELING WORK. THE  NEW MODELS WILL BE ASSESSED USING SIMULATIONS OF OBSERVED GROUND MOTIONS DURING PAST  EARTHQUAKES IN THE REGION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES; THE DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A REFINED VERSION OF THE USGS 3D SEISMIC VELOCITY MODEL  FOR THE SFB REGION, AS WELL AS A SECOND, COMPETING 3D MODEL, WHOSE RELATIVE MERITS WILL BE  EVALUATED. THE PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ABILITY TO DETERMINE IMPROVED ESTIMATES OF GROUND  MOTIONS CAUSED BY POTENTIAL FUTURE EARTHQUAKES BY REFINING THE ACCURACY OF THE USGS 3D SEISMIC  VELOCITY MODEL.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARY WILL BE RESEARCHERS AT THE USGS IN THEIR EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS  WORK FOR THE SFB REGION. OUR PROJECT EXPLICITLY ADDRESSES THE 2022 NEHRP RESEARCH PRIORITIES  FOR NORTHERN CALIFORNIA (NC), ELEMENT I: "UPDATE EXISTING SEISMIC TOMOGRAPHY MODELS USING  AMBIENT NOISE METHODS, SHEAR WAVE ARRIVAL TIMES FROM 3-COMPONENT STATIONS, AND DATA FROM NEW  NETWORK STATIONS ADDED FOR EARTHQUAKE EARLY WARNING, AND COLLABORATE TO ENSURE THESE MODELS ARE  USED IN MODIFYING THE 3D GEOLOGY AND VELOCITY MODELS." OUR PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES A SERIES OF 3D  GROUND-MOTION SIMULATIONS FOR MODERATE-SIZED LOCAL EARTHQUAKES FOR THE PURPOSE OF VALIDATING THE  RESULTING VELOCITY MODELS, WHICH WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO ONE OF THE NC RESEARCH TOPICS: "VALIDATE, IMPROVE, AND INCORPORATE SEISMIC TOMOGRAPHY MODELS INTO THE COMMUNITY REGIONAL 3D  GEOLOGIC AND SEISMIC VELOCITY MODELS FOR THE BAY AREA AND NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, WITH EMPHASIS  ON BASINS." WE EXPECT THAT OUR RESEARCH RESULTS WILL ALSO BE BENEFICIAL FOR EARTHQUAKE RESEARCHERS AT LAWRENCE LIVERMORE NATIONAL LABORATORY FOR THEIR EARTHQUAKE HAZARDS ASSESSMENT WORK.

PROJECT TITLE:PROBABILISTIC IDENTIFICATION OF SEISMICITY TRIGGERED BY OIL AND GAS ACTIVITIES AND ITS EFFECTS ONUS NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/1/2022 THROUGH 5/31/2023IN THE PAST 12 YEARS, SEVERAL STATES IN THE UNITED STATES SUCH AS OKLAHOMA, KANSAS, TEXAS, OHIO, ARKANSAS AND COLORADO, HAVE EXPERIENCED UNPRECEDENTED SEISMICITY RATES, FOLLOWING AN INCREASE IN THE VOLUMES OF FLUIDS THAT ARE BEING INJECTED UNDERGROUND VIA HYDRAULIC FRACTURING STIMULATIONS AND THE DISPOSAL OF THE CO-PRODUCED WASTE-FLUIDS. THESE EARTHQUAKES MOSTLY AFFECT INFRASTRUCTURE THAT WAS DESIGNED WITH LITTLE TO NO CONSIDERATION OF SEISMIC DEMANDS CAUSING SOME DAMAGES AND WIDESPREAD UNREST IN THE PUBLIC. THE MAGNITUDES OF THESE EARTHQUAKES ARE NOT ALWAYS SMALL, WITH AT LEAST 5 EARTHQUAKES OF MAGNITUDE LARGER THAN 5 THAT HAVE BEEN LINKED TO OIL AND GAS ACTIVITIES IN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS. IN MANY OIL PLAYS, SUCH AS THE DELAWARE AND MIDLAND BASINS IN WEST TEXAS, THE SEISMICITY RATES HAVE BEEN RAPIDLY INCREASING IN RECENT YEARS, DEMONSTRATING THE URGENCY FOR IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE UNDERLYING PROCESSES IN ORDER TO FACILITATE MITIGATION EFFORTS AND POSSIBLE REGULATORY INTERVENTIONS.THE PRESENT STUDY AIMS TO EMPLOY AN ESTABLISHED SEMI-EMPIRICAL EARTHQUAKE RECURRENCE RELATION TO MODEL THE OBSERVED SEISMICITY GIVEN THE INJECTION TIME-HISTORY. THE MODEL IS FOUNDED ON PHYSICS-BASED PRINCIPLES THAT DIRECTLY TAKE INTO ACCOUNT THE TIME-DEPENDENT NATURE OF THE HUMAN ACTIVITIES VIA THE INJECTION RATES. ALTHOUGH THE MODEL IS GENERIC TO BE APPLICABLE IN ANY REGION AND COVERS BOTH HYDRAULIC FRACTURING AND WASTEWATER DISPOSAL CASES, IT MATCHES WELL THE EARTHQUAKE TIME-HISTORY ACROSS VARIOUS SCALES AND REGIONS, FOR BOTH INCREASING AND DECREASING INJECTION RATES. BESIDES HINDCASTING PAST SEISMICITY RATES, OUR MAIN GOAL IS TO EMPLOY THE MODEL TO DISTINGUISH THE CAUSAL FACTORS OF INDUCED SEISMICITY ACROSS THE US, INCLUDING AREAS WITH OVERLAPPING OIL AND GAS ACTIVITIES (E.G. DELAWARE BASIN), SOMETHING THAT HAS ALWAYS BEEN A CHALLENGING ISSUE THAT IS LACKING A HOMOGENEOUS RESPONSE IN THE EXISTING LITERATURE. THE RELEASE OF NATIONAL MAPS IDENTIFYING AREAS WITH INDUCED SEISMICITY, WHERE THE LONG-TERM US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY SEISMIC HAZARD MODELS MIGHT DEVIATE SIGNIFICANTLY FROM THE NEAR-TERM RATES, WOULD BENEFIT THE PUBLIC, VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS, INSURANCE COMPANIES, AND STATE-REGULATORS.ONCE THE CAUSAL FACTORS BEHIND THE ELEVATED SEISMICITY RATES HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED ON A SPATIAL GRID ACROSS THE AREAS OF INTEREST, WE WILL PROCEED IN FORECASTING FUTURE SEISMICITY RATES AND MAGNITUDE EXCEEDANCE PROBABILITIES FOR VARIOUS SCENARIOS OF FUTURE OIL AND GAS OPERATIONS. ANY EXISTING MODELS FOR STATES THAT ALREADY EXPERIENCED ELEVATED SEISMICITY RATES, WILL BE UPDATED USING THE LATEST SEISMICITY AND INJECTION DATA, SINCE MOST PUBLISHED STUDIES HAVE NOT INCLUDED DATA AFTER 2017 (DUE TO REPORTING LAGS WITHIN THE REGULATORY AGENCIES). NEXT, WE WILL PAIR THESE RESULTS WITH SUITABLE GROUND MOTION MODELS AND SITE-EFFECTS MAPS TO PRODUCE SHORT-TERM SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS THAT CAN INFORM THE PUBLIC, INDUSTRY ASSOCIATES AND REGULATORY AGENCIES ABOUT HOTSPOTS OF ELEVATED SEISMIC HAZARD RELATIVE TO THE LONG-TERM ESTIMATES OF THE 2018 NATIONAL US MODEL. STUDIES HAVE ALREADY DEMONSTRATED THAT THE SEISMIC HAZARD FROM INDUCED SEISMICITY CAN LARGELY EXCEED THE LONG-TERM TECTONIC HAZARD IN LOW SEISMICITY REGIONS. NATIONAL SHORT-TERM FORECASTS FOR INDUCED SEISMICITY WERE PREVIOUSLY PRODUCED BY THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, BUT WERE DISCONTINUED IN 2018, CREATING A GAP IN THE LITERATURE THAT THIS PROJECT AIMS TO FILL.

AWARD PURPOSE -THE 18 MARCH 2020 M 5.7 EARTHQUAKE THAT OCCURRED WEST OF SALT LAKE CITY IS THE BEST-EVER RECORDED EARTHQUAKE IN THE BASIN AND RANGE PROVINCE IN TERMS OF STRONG MOTION DATA. MORE THAN 160 STRONG MOTION/BROADBAND SEISMIC STATIONS RECORDED THE MAINSHOCK. THE EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCE APPEARS TO HAVE OCCURRED ON A WEST-DIPPING LISTRIC NORTHERN PORTION OF THE SALT LAKE CITY SEGMENT OF THE WASATCH FAULT. THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO EVALUATE THE SITE EFFECTS AT 25 SELECTED STRONG MOTION SITES THAT SAMPLE THE SALT LAKE CITY METROPOLITAN AREA AND ADJACENT POPULATED AREAS. UNDERSTANDING HOW SITE EFFECTS MAY VARY IN THE POPULATED AREAS ALONG THE WASATCH FRONT IS AN IMPORTANT GOAL IN EARTHQUAKE HAZARD REDUCTION. IN THIS STUDY, WE PROPOSE TO ANALYZE THE STRONG MOTION RECORDS OF THE MAINSHOCK AND THE LARGEST AFTERSHOCKS AND COMPARE OUR PREDICTED GROUND MOTIONS BASED ON SITE RESPONSE ANALYSES WITH THE RECORDED GROUND MOTIONS TO EVALUATE SITE EFFECTS. WE WILL DEVELOP SUITES OF SHALLOW SITE AMPLIFICATION FACTORS FOR THE SITE CATEGORIES ALREADY DEFINED FOR SALT LAKE VALLEY. THESE AMPLIFICATION FACTORS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE GREATER EARTHQUAKE ENGINEERING COMMUNITY FOR THEIR USE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF SEISMIC DESIGN GROUND MOTIONS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -1. COMPILE AND PROCESS ADDITIONAL STRONG MOTION DATA.2. CHARACTERIZE SHEAR-WAVE VELOCITY STRUCTURE AT THE 25 STRONG MOTION STATIONS.3. PERFORM SITE RESPONSE ANALYSES AND COMPARE PREDICTED VERSUS OBSERVED GROUND MOTIONS FOR THE MAINSHOCK AND LARGEST AFTERSHOCKS.4. COMPUTE AMPLIFICATION FACTORS.5. PREPARE FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESTHE MAIN DELIVERABLE IS THE FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT THAT DOCUMENTS THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT AND WHICH WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO RESEARCHERS AND PRACTITIONERS WORKING ON GROUND-MOTION CHARACTERIZATION AND SEISMIC HAZARD IN UTAH. A JOURNAL PAPER WILL BE PREPARED AND SUBMITTED TO THE BULLETIN OF THE SEISMOLOGICAL SOCIETY OR EARTHQUAKE SPECTRA. THE AMPLIFICATION FACTORS WILL BE MORE SITE-SPECIFIC THAN THE NEHRP SITE AMPLIFICATION FACTORS THAT ARE USED IN THE BUILDING CODE AND THUS WILL BE MORE USEFUL FOR SITE-SPECIFIC DESIGN.INTENDED BENEFICIARIESENGINEERS AND SEISMOLOGISTS WORKING ON SEISMIC HAZARD AND DESIGN IN UTAH, INCLUDING THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY DEVELOPING NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPS FOR INCORPORATION IN BUILDING CODES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES N/A
EARTHQUAKE ACCELEROGRAM SYNTHESIS VIA CONDITIONAL GENERATIVE ADVERSARIAL NETWORKS FOR ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS, DATED 6/1/2021, REVISED 4/29/2022

LARGE AND DESTRUCTIVE EARTHQUAKES ON MATURE FAULTS IN THE EARTH'S CRUST OCCUR AS SLIP IN A LAYER OF  A FINE GRANULAR MATERIAL - FAULT GOUGE - PRODUCED BY COMMINUTION DURING SLIDING. FRICTIONAL  RESISTANCE OF THE FAULT - ONE OF THE MAIN FACTORS CONTROLLING EARTHQUAKE NUCLEATION, DYNAMIC  PROPAGATION, AND ARREST, AND HENCE THE DESTRUCTIVE GROUND SHAKING OF EARTHQUAKES - HAS MOSTLY BEEN  STUDIED IN EXPERIMENTS WITH UNIFORM SLIP IMPOSED IN RELATIVELY SMALL SAMPLES.WITH PRIOR USGS SUPPORT, WE HAVE RECENTLY DEVELOPED LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS THAT FEATURE  SPONTANEOUSLY DEVELOPING SEQUENCES OF DYNAMIC RUPTURES AND SLOWER SLIP IN FINE ROCK GOUGE AS  FOUND IN CORES OF MATURE FAULTS; THE RUPTURES ARE RESOLVED IN SPACE AND TIME BY RECENTLY DEVELOPED  HIGH-SPEED DIAGNOSTICS.WE PROPOSE TO FURTHER DEVELOP, ANALYZE, AND NUMERICALLY SIMULATE THE EXPERIMENTS FEATURING  SPONTANEOUS SEQUENCES OF DYNAMIC EVENTS AND DYNAMIC RUPTURE TRIGGERING ALONG ROCK-GOUGE  INTERFACES. (I) WE WILL IMPROVE OUR HYBRID LABORATORY SAMPLES AND PROCEDURES THAT COMBINE A BULK  ANALOG MATERIAL (HOMALITE) WITH ROCK GOUGE ON THE INTERFACE. THE HYBRID SAMPLES ALLOW US TO RETAIN  THE ADVANTAGE IN REDUCED NUCLEATION SIZES ASSOCIATED WITH THE ANALOG MATERIAL, WHILE ENABLING US  TO STUDY DYNAMIC RUPTURE PHENOMENA ON ROCK-GOUGE INTERFACES AS WELL AS TO INTERROGATE THE  EVOLVING DYNAMIC FRICTION OF ROCK GOUGE FOR SLIP RATES CHARACTERISTIC OF DYNAMIC RUPTURE. WE WILL  CONDUCT THE EXPERIMENTS UNDER DIFFERENT RESOLVED PRE-STRESS CONDITIONS; WITH DIFFERENT GOUGE GRAIN  SIZES; WITH REPEATED ATTEMPTS TO RUPTURE THE ROCK-GOUGE PORTION; AND WITH DIFFERENT TIME DELAYS TO  STUDY THE EFFECT OF HEALING.  (II) WE WILL USE OUR EXPERIMENTS TO STUDY HOW DYNAMIC RUPTURE BREAKS THROUGH INITIALLY  UNFAVORABLE, BARRIER-LIKE FAULT REGIONS. OUR RESULTS SO FAR INDICATE THAT THE GOUGE-FILLED INTERFACE  INITIALLY BEHAVES AS A BARRIER TO DYNAMIC RUPTURE, STOPPING DYNAMIC RUPTURE ORIGINATING ON RUPTUREPRONE HOMALITE INTERFACES, CONSISTENT WITH INITIALLY VELOCITY-STRENGTHENING FRICTION OF ROCK GOUGE.  HOWEVER, SLOWER SLIP LINGERS ON THE INTERFACE BETWEEN CLEAR DYNAMIC RUPTURES, WHICH MAKES THE  ROCK-GOUGE INTERFACE PRONE TO LOCALIZATION, DYNAMIC WEAKENING, AND DYNAMIC TRIGGERING. WE WILL  CONDUCT EXPERIMENTS WITH REPEATING RUPTURES ATTEMPTING TO PENETRATE THE SAME GOUGE-FILLED  INTERFACE TO STUDY THESE PHENOMENA IN MORE DETAIL. THE EXPERIMENTAL FINDINGS WILL INVESTIGATE THE  PLAUSIBILITY OF THE CONCEPT THAT DYNAMIC WEAKENING, COMBINED WITH DYNAMIC TRIGGERING, MAY  ENABLE EARTHQUAKE RUPTURE TO BREAK THROUGH STABLE, CREEPING FAULT REGIONS, WITH SIGNIFICANT  IMPLICATIONS FOR SEISMIC HAZARD.  (III) WE WILL NUMERICALLY SIMULATE THE EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS USING FRICTION FORMULATIONS THAT  COMBINE STANDARD RATE-AND-STATE FRICTION AT LOW SLIP RATES WITH FLASH HEATING AT HIGH SLIP RATES. IN  THE PROCESS, WE WILL DETERMINE THE CORRESPONDING FRICTION PARAMETERS OF THE ROCK GOUGE AND HOW  THEY EVOLVE DURING THE SEQUENCE OF DYNAMIC RUPTURES. THE MODELING MAY REVEAL THAT ADDITIONAL  PHYSICAL PROCESSES ARE NEEDED TO CAPTURE THE EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS. (IV) ADDITIONAL FRICTION EXPERIMENTS WILL BE PERFORMED ON HOMALITE AND ROCK GOUGE SAMPLES IN THE  DIRECT-DOUBLE-SHEAR (DDS) SETUP AT USGS MENLO PARK; SUCH EXPERIMENTS ON ROCKS HAVE BEEN  PREVIOUSLY ANALYZED AND COMPARED WITH NATURAL EARTHQUAKES. WE WILL PERFORM DETAILED LOCAL  MEASUREMENTS OF FRICTION USING OUR DIC-BASED APPROACH FOR HIGH SLIP RATES AND COLLABORATING WITH  USGS GEOPHYSICIST BRIAN KILGORE FOR LOW SLIP RATES. THE HIGH-SLIP-RATE MEASUREMENTS WILL BE  COMPARED WITH THE AVERAGED QUANTITIES OBTAINED DURING STICK-SLIP EVENTS IN THE DDS SETUP.  THE PROPOSED STUDY WOULD ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SLIP DYNAMICS, EARTHQUAKE TRIGGERING,  AND FRICTION EVOLUTION; IT IS WELL-ALIGNED WITH THE USGS PRIORITY TOPICS IN RESEARCH ON EARTHQUAKE PHYSICS.

PROJECT TITLE:EVALUATION AND IMPROVEMENT OF METHODS TO CONSIDERINFLUENCE OF SURFACE CLAY LAYERS ON LIQUEFACTION-INDUCEDSETTLEMENT FROM LARGE DATABASEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/15/2022 THROUGHT 6/14/2024RESEARCH PURPOSE: LIQUEFACTION OF LOOSE SANDS RESULTS IN SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE TO BUILDINGS, BRIDGES, PORTS, AND PIPELINES IN NEARLY EVERY MAJOR EARTHQUAKE. HOWEVER, THE PRESENCE OF A CLAY LAYER OVERLYING A LIQUEFIED LAYER HAS BEEN FOUND TO SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE LIQUEFACTION-INDUCED DAMAGE AT THE SURFACE. FOLLOWING THE 2010-2011 CANTERBURY EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCE IN NEW ZEALAND, ALMOST NO FOUNDATION PROBLEMS OCCURRED IN AREAS WITH AT LEAST A 10 FT-THICK SURFACE LAYER. HOWEVER, THIS BENEFICIAL EFFECT HAS NOT BEEN CONSISTENTLY OBSERVED IN ALL EARTHQUAKES. IMPROVED MODELS ARE NECESSARY TO PREDICT WHEN THESE SURFACE LAYERS CAN BE RELIED UPON TO REDUCE FOUNDATION SETTLEMENT. THE STUDY OBJECTIVES ARE: (1) BETTER UNDERSTAND THE NATURE OF NON-LIQUEFIABLE SURFACE LAYERS THAT PREVENT LIQUEFACTION DAMAGE BASED ON FIELD CASE HISTORIES, AND (2) EVALUATE AND IMPROVE MODELS FOR PREDICTING THE EFFECT OF THE SURFACE LAYER.ACTIVITIES: THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY COMPARING PREDICTED LIQUEFACTION PERFORMANCE USING CONE PENETRATION TESTS (CPTS) WITH OBSERVED LIQUEFACTION FEATURES AT 1700 SITES FROM DETAILED POST-EARTHQUAKE RECONNAISSANCE STUDIES DURING THE 2012 EMILIA ROMAGNA EARTHQUAKE SEQUENCE IN ITALY. ABOUT 10% OF THE CPTS ARE LOCATED IN NEAR A LIQUEFACTION FEATURE, WHILE THE REMAINING 90% ARE NOT. NEVERTHELESS, CPT-BASED LIQUEFACTION ANALYSES PREDICT LIQUEFACTION AT MANY SITES WHERE NO LIQUEFACTION WAS OBSERVED, PRESUMABLY DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF A SURFACE CRUST. ON THE OTHER HAND, LIQUEFACTION WAS OBSERVED AT SOME SITES WHERE THERE WAS A THICK CLAY SURFACE CRUST WHICH SHOULD HAVE PREVENTED SURFACE LIQUEFACTION FEATURES. THEREFORE, THIS DATASET PROVIDES AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO EVALUATE EXISTING MODELS THAT ACCOUNT FOR THE EFFECT OF NON-LIQUEFIABLE SURFACE CRUSTS AND THE PROPERTIES OF THE SURFACE LAYERS. TO FACILITATE THESE EVALUATIONS AND CREATE IMPROVED CRITERIA, WE WILL IMPORT THE CPT TESTS, SOIL PROPERTIES, AND LIQUEFACTION FEATURES INTO A GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) DATABASE. PROPERTIES OF THE SURFACE LAYERS WILL BE IDENTIFIED USING CPT AND DILATOMETER TEST (DMT) CORRELATIONS.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE STUDY WILL DOCUMENT THE ACCURACY OF METHODS FOR PREDICTING SURFACE LAYER EFFECTS. IT WILL ALSO REPORT ON IMPROVED MODELS FOR MAKING PREDICTIONS. DATA FROM THE DATASET WILL BE UPLOADED TO A LONG-TERM DATA ARCHIVING SERVICE. THIS NEW DATA SET WILL SIGNIFICANTLY EXPAND THE WORLDWIDE CASE HISTORY DATABASE AND PROVIDE NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF LIQUEFACTION MODELS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: CIVIL ENGINEERS, GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEERS, ENGINEERING GEOLOGISTS, AND LAND-USE PLANNERSSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NO SUBRECIPIENTS ON THIS AWARD.

PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: WE PROPOSE TO STUDY TWO FAULTS, THE POLARIS AND TRUCKEE FAULT ZONES, IN TRUCKEE, CALIFORNIA THATTRAVERSE THE SIERRA NEVADA AND CARSON RANGES. IN PARTICULAR, WE PLAN TO DETERMINE HOW FAST THESEFAULTS ARE MOVING, WHICH WILL ENABLE IS TO ESTIMATE THEIR POTENTIAL TO GENERATE EARTHQUAKES, BYMAPPING AND DATING FAULTED LANDFORMS. OUR STUDY WILL ALSO ENABLE US TO ESTIMATE THE POTENTIALMAGNITUDE OF PAST AND FUTURE EARTHQUAKES. MAPPING THESE FAULTS AND THEIR RATES OF MOVEMENT WILLALLOW US TO ESTIMATE THE POTENTIAL ZONES OF HIGHEST HAZARDS. OUR STUDY WILL ALSO ALLOW US TO MOREFULLY UNDERSTAND THE EVOLUTION OF THIS IMPORTANT AREA OF CRUSTAL DEFORMATION, THE NORTHERN WALKERLAKE, THAT ACCOMMODATES A SIGNIFICANT COMPONENT OF MOTION ALONG THE SAN-ANDREAS TRANSFORMPLATE BOUNDARY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:WE WILL CONDUCT SITE SPECIFIC DETAILED QUATERNARY GEOLOGIC MAPPING AND SLIP RATE INVESTIGATIONSTO EVALUATE THE POLARIS AND TRUCKER FAULTS ACTIVITY AND ESTIMATE THE FREQUENCY OF PAST EARTHQUAKES.IN ADDITION, WE WILL CRITICALLY EXAMINE, VERIFY, AND VALIDATE PREVIOUS FAULT TRACE MAPPING TOPRODUCE A NEW FAULT TRACE MAP. FAULTED LANDFORMS WILL BE DATED USING BE-10 COSMOGENIC NUCLIDEDATING IN THE GEOCHRONOLOGY LABORATORIES AT NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:WE WILL PROVIDE GEOLOGIC MAPS OF THE POLARIS AND TRUCKEE FAULTS AND DEFINE THEIR SLIP RATES.THESE MAPS WILL BE PUBLISHED IN AN INTERNATIONALLY PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL HIGHLIGHTING THEIRSEISMIC HAZARD AND TECTONIC SIGNIFICANCE. A COMPREHENSIVE REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE USGSAS PART OF OUR GRANT REQUIREMENT.INTENDED BENEFICIARIESINCLUDE THE GEOLOGIC SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, REGIONAL AND LOCALAUTHORITIES/PLANNERS, NEHRP, AND USDA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD - N/A

A REFRACTION/WIDE-ANGLE REFLECTION EXPERIMENT IS PROPOSED TO DETERMINE P- AND S-WAVE VELOCITY  AND ANELASTIC ATTENUATION OF A DEEP SECTION OF MISSISSIPPI EMBAYMENT SEDIMENTS IN THE  MISSISSIPPI RIVER PLAIN NEAR MEMPHIS, TN. THE EXPERIMENT WILL CONSIST OF DETONATING TWO 200LB  BURIED EXPLOSIVE SOURCES AT THE ENDS OF A 3KM LINEAR ARRAY OF 60 THREE-COMPONENT, 5 HZ  AUTONOMOUS NODAL SEISMOMETERS. THE IRIS SEISMIC SOURCE FACILITY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS,  EL PASO, WILL BE PROVIDING THE EXPLOSIVE SOURCES AND OVERSEEING ALL EMPLACEMENT AND CLEANUP  ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE. AN ADDITIONAL STRONG MOTION GRADIOMETER CONSISTING OF 16 MEMS THREECOMPONENT ACCELEROMETERS WILL BE DEPLOYED 50M FROM EACH EXPLOSION TO RECORD STRONG GROUND  MOTIONS AND ANALYZE THE SOURCE FUNCTIONS OF EACH EXPLOSION. SMALL SCALE REFRACTION AND  REFLECTION PROFILES WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED AT EACH SOURCE POINT TO CHARACTERIZE THE SHALLOW SOURCE  MEDIUM. WE WILL COLLECT A CANONICAL, HIGH SIGNAL-TO-NOISE, DENSELY SAMPLED DATASET OF BODY AND  SURFACE WAVES THAT WILL BE MODELED TO DETERMINE BOTH VELOCITY AND ATTENUATION STRUCTURE OF THE  SEDIMENTARY COLUMN. THIS RESEARCH DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THREE PRIORITY TOPICS FOR THE CEUS  INCLUDING 'IMPROVING AND REDUCING UNCERTAINTIES IN ESTIMATES OF STRONG GROUND MOTION FOR THE  NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL, AND IN PARTICULAR FOR AREAS WITH EXTENSIVE SEDIMENT LAYERS SUCH  AS THE ATLANTIC COASTAL PLAIN AND MISSISSIPPI EMBAYMENT REGIONS', 'CHARACTERIZE WAVE  PROPAGATION AND ATTENUATION IN THE CEUS INCLUDING BASIN EFFECTS', AND 'IMPROVE ESTIMATES OF SITE  RESPONSE AND LIQUEFACTION POTENTIAL USING FIELD EXPERIMENTS OR INSTRUMENTAL RECORDINGS, WITH AN  EMPHASIS ON GEOLOGIC UNITS THAT UNDERLIE LARGE AREAS OF THE CEUS.' ALTHOUGH IT HAS BEEN LONG  RECOGNIZED THAT THE VELOCITY AND ATTENUATION STRUCTURE OF EMBAYMENT SEDIMENTS ARE ESSENTIAL PARTS  OF ESTIMATING THE SHAKING HAZARDS OF EARTHQUAKES FROM THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE, IT IS  SURPRISING THAT THERE ARE NO CONTROLLED SOURCE SEISMIC DATASETS THAT HAVE BEEN COLLECTED TO  EXAMINE THE ENTIRE VELOCITY PROFILE OF THE SEDIMENTS AND HOW ACTUAL P AND S WAVES PROPAGATE  THROUGH THEM. IN THE PROPOSED ESEE 2022 RESEARCH, ANALYSIS METHODS FOR CONSTRUCTING INITIAL  VELOCITY MODELS INCLUDE SEISMIC RAY THEORY FOR OBSERVED P- AND S-WAVE BODY WAVE ARRIVALS AND  USE OF DISPERSION MEASUREMENTS FROM OBSERVED SURFACE WAVES. FINAL ATTENUATION AND VELOCITY  STRUCTURE WILL BE INFERRED FROM WAVEFORM AMPLITUDES AND PHASES USING FULL WAVEFORM INVERSION  OF THE ENTIRE DATASET. THE DATA COLLECTED IN ESEE 2022 WILL ENABLE A DETERMINATION OF THE IN-SITU  VELOCITY AND ATTENUATION STRUCTURE FOR BOTH P- AND S-WAVES AS GROUND TRUTH FOR MODELS OF  SEDIMENT AMPLIFICATION USED IN HAZARD STUDIES AND TO SERVE AS A PROTOTYPE EXPERIMENT FOR FURTHER  EXPLORATION OF STRUCTURE OF EMBAYMENT SEDIMENTS.

PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION AWARD PURPOSE: THE EFFECTS OF RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY ON NEAR-FAULT GROUND MOTIONS ARE KNOWN TO BE SIGNIFICANT AND  SHOULD BE INCLUDED TO ACCURATELY ESTIMATE THE HAZARD FROM LONG PERIOD GROUND MOTIONS  (ABRAHAMSON, 2000). HOWEVER, THESE EFFECTS ARE NOT EXPLICITLY ACCOUNTED FOR IN TYPICAL GROUND  MOTIONS MODELS, AND THEREFORE NOT IN TYPICAL PROBABILISTIC SEISMIC HAZARD ANALYSES (PSHAS)  BECAUSE SUBSTANTIAL CONFUSION EXISTS IN PRACTICE ABOUT WHICH DIRECTIVITY MODELS TO USE AND HOW TO  APPLY THEM, ESPECIALLY TO COMPLEX MULTI-SEGMENT RUPTURE MODELS (DONAHUE ET AL., 2019).  IN THE PROPOSED WORK, WE WILL BUILD UPON OUR RUPTURE DIRECTIVITY MODEL PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED UNDER  USGS AWARD G18AP00092 (BEA20). THE RESULT WILL BE A COMPREHENSIVE MODEL SUITABLE FOR USE  IN FUTURE PSHAS, INCLUDING THOSE PERFORMED AS PART OF THE USGS NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED WE WILL TEST AND REFINE BEA20 AND PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR USING THIS MODEL IN SEISMIC HAZARD  ANALYSES: FIRST, WE WILL INVESTIGATE THE IMPACT OF THE MODEL ON THE TOTAL ALEATORY VARIABILITY IN  PSHA, WHICH IS IMPLICITLY INCREASED RELATIVE TO A NON-DIRECTIVE PSHA DUE TO INTEGRATION OVER  MULTIPLE HYPOCENTER LOCATIONS. NEXT, WE WILL TEST AND PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR APPLYING THE MODEL TO  COMPLEX EARTHQUAKE SOURCE DESCRIPTIONS. FINALLY, WE WILL MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR  INCORPORATING THE MODEL INTO SEISMIC HAZARD CODES, BOTH FOR SITE-SPECIFIC STUDIES AND THE NATIONAL  SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL. IN ADDITION TO THESE GUIDELINES, WE WILL PROVIDE A SERIES OF PSHA EXAMPLES, INCLUDING DIRECTIVITY  MODEL COMPARISONS AND GROUND-MOTION SENSITIVITIES. WE WILL BEGIN WITH VERY SIMPLE SOURCE  DESCRIPTION EXAMPLES AND GRADUALLY INCREASE IN COMPLEXITY, CONCLUDING WITH EXAMPLE UTILIZATIONS  OF COMPLEX MULTI-SEGMENT SCENARIO EARTHQUAKES IN UCERF3 (FIELD ET AL., 2013).DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE COMPLETE DIRECTIVITY MODEL WILL INCLUDE FORMALIZED INSTRUCTIONS FOR USE IN PSHA, INCLUDING: - THE MEDIAN GROUND MOTION ADJUSTMENT - THE ALEATORY VARIABILITY ADJUSTMENT - HYPOCENTER LOCATION DISTRIBUTIONS - CODE IMPLEMENTATION INTO THE OPEN-SOURCE HAZARD SOFTWARE HAZ45 (HALE ET AL., 2018) WE WILL DEVELOP A TECHNICAL REPORT SUMMARIZING THESE AND WILL PREPARE A MANUSCRIPT FOR A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL BASED JOINTLY ON THIS REPORT AND THE FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT FROM AWARD  G18AP00092. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO A WIDE RANGE OF PRACTICING HAZARD ANALYSTS, AND TO THE USGS FOR THE NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MAPPING PROJECT. WE HAVE COMMUNICATED WITH THE USGS  AND WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH KYLE WITHERS AND MORGAN MOSCHETTI TO IMPLEMENT THE MODEL IN THE  USGS NATIONAL HAZARD MAPPING WORKFLOW.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES NO SUBCONTRACTORS ARE INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT

AWARD PURPOSE: INJECTION OF FLUIDS IN THE CRUST CAN INDUCE FAULT SLIP DUE TO AN INCREASE IN FLUID PRESSURE, WHICH DECREASES THE NORMAL STRESS AND HENCE FAULT STRENGTH. FAULT MOVEMENT MAY OCCUR THROUGH EARTHQUAKES OR SLOW SLIP; THE LATTER MAY IN TURN TRIGGER SEISMICITY. DISTINGUISHING BETWEEN THESE TWO MECHANISMS - DIRECT SEISMICITY INDUCED BY PORE PRESSURE OR AN INDIRECT RESPONSE MEDIATED BY PORE PRESSURES - IS AN IMPORTANT STEP TO MITIGATE THE SEISMIC RISK ASSOCIATED WITH ANTHROPOGENIC FLUID INJECTION. IN THE PROPOSED WORK WE WILL EXPLORE THE HYPOTHESIS THAT FAULT ROUGHNESS CAN PROVIDE A MECHANISM FOR LARGE SCALE SLOW SLIP INDUCED BY PORE PRESSURE PERTURBATIONS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE FIRST PART OF THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE EFFECT OF ROUGHNESS ON THE FRICTIONAL STABILITY OF THE FAULT WHICH CONTROLS ITS FAST (SEISMIC) OR SLOW MOTION. WE WILL USE EARTHQUAKE SIMULATIONS WITH PORE-PRESSURE VARIATIONS CONSISTENT WITH FLUID INJECTION, AND STUDY HOW THE FAULT RESPONSE WILL CHANGE WITH DIFFERENT LEVELS OF ROUGHNESS. WE WILL QUANTIFY THE AMOUNT OF FLUID PRESSURE NEEDED TO TRIGGER EARTHQUAKES OR SEISMIC SLIP, AND THE CONDITIONS LEADING TO LARGE SEISMIC EVENTS. SECONDLY, WE WILL EXPLORE HOW ROUGHNESS MODIFIES HYDROLOGICAL ROCK PROPERTIES IN THE VICINITY OF THE FAULT AND THUS AFFECTS FLUID FLOW. ROUGHNESS INDUCES CHANGES IN NORMAL STRESS WHICH MODULATE SURROUNDING PERMEABILITY BY CLOSING PORES AND FRACTURES. THIS EFFECT WILL ALLOW FLUID TO REACH CERTAIN PARTS OF THE FAULT EARLIER THAN OTHERS, AND IT MAY INCREASE THE FRACTION OF SLOW SLIP EARLY AFTER INJECTION, THUS DELAYING SEISMIC ACTIVITY.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO DETERMINING THE CONDITIONS UNDER WHICH FLUID INJECTION PRODUCES SEISMIC OR ASEISMIC SLIP, AND THE POTENTIAL FOR ASEISMIC SLIP TO IN TURN TRIGGER LARGE EARTHQUAKES. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE INTERPLAY BETWEEN THESE PROCESSES IS AN ESSENTIAL STEP TO GUIDE MONITORING EFFORTS AND REDUCING THE SEISMIC RISK POSED BY FLUID INJECTION.INTENDED BENEFICIARY: GENERAL PUBLIC (COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY INDUCED SEISMICITY).

PROJECT TITLE: THE ERODING ICEBERG LAKE SEDIMENT: A SHORT-LIVED OPPORTUNITY TO OBTAIN A PALEOSEISMIC RECORD FROM THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE ALASKA SUBDUCTION ZONEPROJECT PERIOD: 3/1/2022 - 2/28/2023GEOLOGICAL RECORDS OF PAST EARTHQUAKES ARE OF KEY IMPORTANCE FOR SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENTS. ON AND AROUND THE YAKUTAT TERRANCE SUCH PALEOSEISMIC RECORDS ARE SCARCE. CURRENTLY, ONLY COASTAL RECORDS EXIST WHICH PRESERVE EVIDENCE OF LAND-LEVEL CHANGE FROM MEGATHRUST EARTHQUAKES SUCH AS THE 1964 MW 9.2 PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND EARTHQUAKE. LAKES HAVE PROVEN TO PROVIDE VALUABLE ARCHIVES OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING BY RECORDING DIFFERENT TYPES OF DEPOSITS TRIGGERED BY EARTHQUAKES. SUCH DEPOSITS HAVE ALLOWED TO ESTIMATE THE STRENGTH AND CHARACTERISTICS OF SEISMIC SKAHING. AND BY PROVIDING COMBINING SUCH RESULTS WITH SO-CALL GROUND-MOTION PREDICTION EQUATIONS (GMPES), IT IS SOMETIMES EVEN POSSIBLE TO ATTRIBUTE SPECIFIC SEISMIC SOURCES AND FAULT SEGMENTS TO PREHISTORIC EARTHQUAKES. HERE, WE STUDY ICEBERG LAKE, WHICH OFFERS A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO OBTAIN PALEOSEISMIC RECORD FOR THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE ALASKAN-ALEUTIAN SUBDUCTION ZONE ENCOMPASSING THE LAST 1500 YEARS. WE WILL FIRST EXAMINE EXISTING DATASETS AND CORES FROM FIELDWORK EXECUTED BETWEEN 2001 AND 2003. NEXT WE PLAN FIELDWORK TO ICEBERG LAKE TO INVESTIGATE ADDITIONAL OUTCROPS WHICH WILL BE PROCEEDED BY CREATING A HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITIL TERRANE MODEL TO GUIDE THE FIELDWORK EFFORTS. WE  WILL THEN COMBINE DETAILED SEDIMENTOLOGICAL DESCRIPTIONS, PHOTOS, X-RAY COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY  (CT) SCANS, GRAIN-SIZE DATA AND OTHER PHYSICAL PARAMETERS TO IDENTIFY AND INTERPRET EARTHQUAKEINDUCED DEPOSITS. WE DATE THESE EVENT DEPOSITS BY COUNTING ANNUAL LAMINATIONS IN THE SEDIMENTS.  FINALLY, WE WILL MERGE ALL GATHERED DATA AND CONSTRUCT A PALEOSEISMIC RECORD OF ICEBERG LAKE.LASTLY, WE WILL ASLO COLLECT SHEAR-WAVE VELOCITY (VS) PROFILES FROM BOTH CLAYER AND SANDY SEDIMENTS. THESE WILL BE USED TO MODEL HOW THESE SEDIMENTS WILL REACT TO DIFFERENT TYPES OF EARTHQUAKE SHAKING. USING THIS GROUND-MOTION MODELLING, WE AIM TO TURN THE ICEBERG LAKE PALEOSEISMIC RECORD INTO AN EXCEPTIONALLY QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE RECORD WHICH WILL REFINE LOCAL SEISMIC HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND PUSH THE BOUNDARIES OF LAKE PALEOSEISMOLOGY. LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND INTERNATIONAL LAKE PALEOSEISMIC COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT.
